pada.s:
The good reputation of the energetic ones spreads to all corners of the world; (kā)
su ñom klyu , tsraṣiśśi ; śäk kälymentwaṃ , sätkatär :

With energy, one will receive honour, appreciation, ovations and adulation from everyone, yärk ynāñmune , nam poto ; tsraṣṣuneyā , pUkäṣ käl(pnā)
l :
one will soon overcome the enemies and soon attain prosperity. 1. yuknāl ymāräk , yäsluñcäs ; kälpnāl ymāräk , yātlune : 1

The energetic ones have many possessions, the energetic ones [also have] many followers, tsraṣiśśi māk , niṣpalntu ; tsraṣiśśi māk , (śkaṃ) (ṣña)
ṣṣeñ :
to the energetic ones the enemies submit, to the energetic ones distinction comes, nämseñc yäsluṣ , tsraṣisac ; kumseñc yärkant , tsraṣisac :

the energetic ones [are] the protection of the beings, the energetic ones do not know fear. tsraṣiñ waste , wrasa(śśi) ;
tsraṣiśśi mā , praski naṣ :
Therefore energy is good and superior to all in my opinion. 2. tämyo kāsu , tsraṣṣune ; pUkaṃ pruccamo , ñi pälskaṃ :

prose.s:
Due to his energy, then, in earlier times the son of the king Siddhārta, the Bodhisattva Sarvārthasiddha [“he succeeds in everything”] came down to the ocean || tsraṣṣuneyo täm(n)e (ne)
ṣ (pra)ṣtaṃ siddhārthes lānt se sarvārthasiddhe bodhisattu sāmudraṃ kārp
[and] went to the island of jewels. ñemiṣiṃ praṅkā yeṣ

(After having loaded? the ship) with pearls and [after having] dismissed the caravan to Jambudvīpa, during seven days he went up to the neck in water, ñemi
l·i sārth jambudvipac pe yāmuräṣ ṣpät koṃsā kñukac wraṃ kälk :

seven days he (swam?) with his arms, ṣpät koṃsā pokenā
(kä)lk
during seven days he went over mud, ṣpät koṃsā lyomaṃ kälk

moving around for seven days, stepping from one lotus to another, in a water with lotuses with a thousand leaves five miles he went over the ground covered with snakes. ṣpät koṃsā wälts pältwāyo oplāsyo wraṃ opläṣ oplā kārnm(āṃ) (kälkorä)
ṣ
päñ kursärwā ārplāsyo rarkusāṃ tkanā kälk :
Then he went to the island of the Rākṣasas, tmäṣ rākṣtsāśśi dvipaṃ yeṣ

then to that of the Yakṣas, (then) to Baladvīpa. tmäṣ yakṣāśśi
baladvipaṃ yeṣ
Thereupon he crossed the moats covered with four kinds of snakes, tmäṣ śtwar-wäknā ārṣlāslo rarkuñcäs iṣanäs kcäk

the four-fold nets, made by strings (?) of crystal, past the great [and] terrible Nāgas, who watched the palace of king Sāgara, he moved, and finally obtained as reward the cintāmaṇi-jewel from king Sāgara; śtwar-wäknā spe(ṣinä)
s«†ä» kluṃtsäsyo sopis sāgares lānt lāñci waṣt pāṣäntās śāwes empeles (n)ā(kā)
s āsuk kätkoräṣ sāgareṃ lāntäṣ cindāmaṇi wmār toriṃ kälpāt

the poverty of the whole Jambudvīpa he made disappear. poñcäṃ jambudvipis e(kro)
rñe wawik
Thus it is said: ślak śkaṃ

pada.s: The energetic ones cross the ocean that is hard to traverse, māski kätkāläṃ ; ktäṅkeñc tsraṣiñ , sāmuddrä :
The threefold world the good ones traverse due to energy. traidhātuk saṃs(ār) ; (tsra)

line.tr: Der gute Ruf der Energischen verbreitet sich in den zehn Weltgegenden.
The good reputation of those that have energy spreads over the ten directions

a4 a5 a6 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5
line.tr: Durch seine Energie stieg da in früherer Zeit der Sohn des Königs Siddhārtha, der Bodhisattva Sarvārthasiddha, zum Ozean herab, ... ging sieben Tage lang bis zum Hals im Wasser, ... ging sieben Tage lang im Schlamm und ging, nachdem er sieben Tage lang im Wasser mit tausendblättrigen Lotusblumen von Lotus zu Lotus steigend (gegangen) war, fünf Meilen weit auf von Schlangen bedeckter Erde. ... Dann überschritt er die vierfachen, mit Schlangen bedeckten Festungsgräben [und] nachdem er [auch] die Netze mit vierfachen Fäden (?) aus Bergkristall(?) [und] die großen, furchtbaren Nāgas, die den Palast des Königs Sāgara bewachten, durchschritten hatte, erlangte er schließlich(?) vom König Sāgara das Cintāmaṇi-Juwel.

Due to his energy, in a former time, the son of the king Siddhārtha, the bodhisattva Sarvārthasiddha, descended to the ocean, ... [he] went in the water up to his neck, for seven days, ... [he] went in the mud for seven days and, after having (gone) stepping from lotus to lotus in the water, with lotuses of a thousand leaves, he went five miles over ground covered with snakes. ... Then he passed over the fourfold moats covered with snakes [and] after passing the nets [made] from fourfold threads)?) of mountain crystal(?) [and] the huge, dreadful Nāgas who guard the palace of king Sāgara, he finally (?) obtained the Cintāmaṇi-jewel from the king Sāgara.

pada.s:
The threefold world the good ones traverse due to energy.
ṣṣuneyo , ktäṅkeñc kraṃś :
Eventually the strong ones attain Buddhahood. kälpnāntär toriṃ ; puttiśparäṃ , wärṣṣältse :

Not in the least must energy be decried. mā =pärmāt tsru yärm ; yātal ya(tsi) ,
tsraṣṣune

prose.s:
There is no other thing that has turned out to the detriment of the whole world [circle of existences] as much as inertia [has]. || mā täpreṃ saṃ poñcäṃ saṃsāris kāripac sāspärtwu ālak wram naṣ
kos ne ālā(su)
ne
:
For in earlier days the food of humans was rice, uncultivated and chaff-less, kyalte neṣ wrasaśśi sne wāwleṣu sne psäl klu śwātsi ṣeṣ

and clothes made ready on wishing trees were theirs to put on. kalpavṛkṣäntwaṃ ārwar pa(pyä)
tkunt wsālu yetweyntu waṣlaṃ ṣeñcäm

[But] due to the collecting of rice by a listless person the wishing trees disappeared for them, ālāsāp klu kropluneyā kalpavṛkṣänt(u)
(na)käntäm
the cotton plants became visible for them [in place of the wishing trees]. kappāñ pākär tākaräm
The uncultivated, chaff-less rice [also] disappeared for them, sne wāwleṣu sne psäl klu naktäm

it [only] became visible through great labour (and with) the chaff. śāwaṃ wlesaṃtyo psäl(aśśäl)
(ṣyak) (pākä)r (t)ākam
Of listlessness, however, energy is the opposite, cami ālāsuneyis nu tsraṣṣune pratipakṣ nāṃtsu

therefore in my opinion, energy is superior to all (in the world). tämyo tsraṣṣune ñi ā(rkiṣo)
(ṣyaṃ) pUk(aṃ) pruccamo pälskaṃ
Śilpavān [“the skillful one”] speaks: || śilpavāṃ träṅkäṣ
The skillfulness of humans is superior to all, amok wrasaśśi pUkaṃ pruccamo
because: kyalte

pada.s: || The good reputation of a craftsman is spread in region after region. kāsu ñom klyu , amoktsāp ; kälyme kälyme , sätkatär :
water, fire, kings and thieves certainly cut off the hope/security (?), wär por lāś lyśi , mñe kärṣneñc :

but the skill will never be lost. amok nu (mā) ,
näknäṣträ ;
and skill is the root of possession. niṣpalis«†ä» śkaṃ , amok tsmār :

prose.s:
And as often as an artist creates an art(istic) object, so often he has five advantages [from it]. || kospreṃ kospreṃ śkaṃ ne amokäts amo(kṣiṃ)
wram pyutkāṣtär : täprenäk täprenäk päñ pärkowäntu mäskaṃträṃ :
One advantage to him is the object created, sas pärko näṃ wāwleṣu wram
it comes into existence. pyutkäṣṣäṃ
The second is the pleasure arisen from the skill; wät amok«ä»ṣ tatmu kācke mäskaträṃ
the third, he receives friendship from the beings; trit wrassäṣ ortune kälpnāträ :

the fourth, [he obtains] students, śtärt āklä(ṣlye)
(s)

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6

line.tr: Besitz, [auch] wenn er behütet wird, muss zugrunde gehen: Wasser, Feuer, Könige [und] Diebe zerstören die Sicherheit(?); aber die Kunstfertigkeit geht nicht verloren.
Possessions, [even] when guarded, must perish: water, fire, kings [and] thieves destroy safety(?); but artistry is never lost.
Anytime an artist creates a work of art he has five advantages [from it]. (cf 5)

Und wie oft/immer ein Kunstfertiger ein Kunstwerk zustande bringt (Med.), ebenso oft/immer werden ihm fünf Vorteile [daraus]: Der erste Vorteil ist für ihn das ausgeführte Werk, es kommt ihm zustande (Akt.). Der zweite [Vorteil] ...
And as often/however as an artist creates a piece of art, just so often/always five benefits become [of it for] him.

[It is] Skill [that] one must acquire first, amok ne(ṣā) ,
kälyitär ;
then one must gather possessions; tmäṣ niṣpaltu , kropitär :
the gathered possessions, however, one must always divided into four parts: kākropuṃt nu , niṣpalntu ; ṣakk ats śtwar pāk , yāmiträ :

one part shall be enjoyed in the house, ṣo(m)

a fourth one is increasing the livestock, śtärt nu śemäl , tsmāṣlune ;

Possessions that are gathered in that way by day and night increase taṃne kropmāṃ , niṣpalntu ; ykoṃ oṣeñi , śamaṃtär :
like ... mäṃt ne ,
[but] one shall not keep possession for old age, moknac niṣpal , mā tāṣäl ;
not for those standing above the land, mā śu ypeyā , mskantāsac :

not for the cruel and evil ones, mā empe(les) ,
omskeṃsac ;

never let him do the thing one should not do; mā yaläṃ wram , mar (yā)
miṣ :

for the being who does the thing one should do shines like a glowing fire.

line.tr: Fertigkeit soll man zuerst erlangen, dann soll man Besitztümer sammeln.
Skill one shall acquire first, then one shall gather possessions.

line.n: a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6 m-a4.a1

line.tr: Die gesammelten Besitztümer aber soll man stets viermal teilen: Einen Teil soll man im Haus[halt] genießen, mit zweien soll man Gewerbe betreiben [und] mit Rücksicht auf spätere Not[zeiten] [wtl. für später Not erblickt habend] soll man den vierten gut bewahren.

The possessions gathered one should always divide in four parts: one part one shall enjoy in the house, with two [parts] one shall conduct trade, [and] having foreseen [times of] need later, one should keep the fourth [part] well.
Besitztümer, die so gesammelt werden, wachsen bei Tag [und] Nacht wie ...
Possessions that are gathered thus, grow by night [and] day like ...
Man tue immer nur das, was man tun soll, nicht tue man das, was man nicht tun soll: Denn der Mensch, der das tut, was man tun soll, leuchtet wie glühendes Feuer.
One should only ever do a thing to be done, never should one do a thing not to be done: for the person who does a thing to be done shines like a glowing fire.

[After] having given and received gift[s], as it is proper, a being [is] equal to all: if it comes in the reach of death, it attains the dwelling of the gods through its flawless perfection. (cf 7; 241)

Therefore in my opinion, human skill is superior to all. tämyo amok , ñi pälskaṃ ; pUkaṃ pruccamo , wrasaśśi :

prose.s: Prajñāvān [“the Wise”] speaks: || prajñavāṃ träṅkäṣ

There is no other thing that does so much good to the world as wisdom, mā tä(preṃ)
saṃ ālak wram ārkiśoṣṣis kāsu ypant naṣ kos ne knānmune

because ignorance is the root of the spread of all bad things and all damages. kyalte āktsune puk omäske(nā)
s wramnāśśi puk kāryapäṃtwāśśi sätkāluneyaṃ tsmār nāṃtsu

Wisdom, however, cuts off the root of foolishness. knānmune nu ākntsuneyis (tsmār) (kä)
rṣnānt

s.tr: Like that there is a plant named Krośavatī, in whatever earth it takes root, from there one krośa its stem will grow away far over the earth.
s.s: mäṃt ne krośavati ñomā okar naṣ

äntāṃ tkanā ne säm tsmār kärkñäṣ tmäṣṣ aci kro(ś)
(tka)naṃ lok or oktsiṣṣ-äṃ

prose.s: The krośa-plant is five hundred fathoms in size. päñ känt kaṣas kroś mäskatär
Having grown one krośa, it is cut down. kroś okṣiṃñuräṣ kotluneyaṃ yäṣ
(Undestroyed) it produces a new sprout. (tmā) (kākorä)ṣ nunak kom yatär
From there it grows again one krośa, tmäṣṣ aci nunak kroś oksiṣ

and undestroyed from there one krośa it grows. nunak nmā kākoräṣ (tmäṣṣ) (aci)
(nunak) kroś oksiṣ
Growing in this way it spreads up to 100 miles in the earth. taṃne tiryā oksismāṃ okāk känt kurtsru tkanaṃ lok sätkaträ
|| In the K.-tune: || || ku(swaṃ) (||)

pada.s: Even cut, even destroyed, the Krośavatī, with only a small piece left over, grows as much [as before]. (kärṣto)s penu ; kākos penu ; krośavati :
tsru kuc yärmaṃ ; lipos nunak ; nprenäk oksiṣ :

Just so are the ignorant ones: even beaten, even nipped, as soon as they have the possibility, they spread in badness. tämnek (ā)
kntsā(ñ) ; kākoṣtuṣ pe ; pāpläṅkuṣ pe :
tsru ke kälpoṣ ; nUnak sätkaṃtär ; omäskenaṃ :

prose.s:
On the mountain Himavant, however, there is a king [named] Vajramukha [“Diamond-mouth”]. || hi
mavant ṣulaṃ nu vacramukhe wäl naṣ

Where this one bites it, the plant Krośavatī dies completely. äntā ne säm trāskaṣäṃ sām krośavati o(ka)
r pUkäṣ puk nkaluneyaṃ yäṣ
Just so are the beings because of their ignorance. tämnek nṣaṃ ākntsuneyis cämpluneyā wrasañ

In all bad things and in all damages they spread. puk omäsku(ne)
yntwaṃ puk kāryapäṃtwaṃ śkaṃ sätkāluneyaṃ yäṣ
Well, when the foolishness (Krośavatī is bitten through) by the wisdom Vajramukha äntā ne nu knānmuneṣiṃ vajramukhenyo ākntsune(ṣiṃ)

line.tr: Wherever on earth it strikes root, from there on its wood grows on earth for krośas. (cf 7)
Auf solche Art und Weise wachsend, verbreitet es sich bis zu 100 Meilen weit auf der Erde fort.
Growing in this manner, it spreads up to a hundred miles over the earth.
Wherever he bites it through, the Krośavatī plant is ruined completely. (cf 7)
Well, when the foolishness Krośavatī is bitten through by the wisdom Vajramukha, at that moment the ruin of all harms is there, and the spread of all advantages. (cf 8)

prose.s: (Well, if the foolishness) Krośavatī is bitten through (by the wisdom Vajramukha), at that moment the ruin of all harms is there, krośavati tāträ«sku»s tāṣ tām praṣṭaṃ puk kāryapäṃtwāśśi nkalune mäskatär

and the spread of all advantages. puk pärkowäntwāśśi śkaṃ sätkā(lu)
ne mäskatär
Therefore human wisdom is superior to all, since it is the root of all excellent qualities.tämyo knānmune wrasaśśi pUkaṃ pruccamo puk kāswonen«t»wāśśi tsmār nāṃtsu

Even if a being is provided with a [beautiful] figure [and] lovely to look at, [but] it has no wisdom, then it looks exactly as if it were a fashioned or painted figure. || tāṣ penu (wra)
som arämpātyo kaknu lkātsi kāswe

line.tr: Even if a being is provided with a [beautiful] figure [and] lovely to look at, [but] it has no wisdom, then it looks exactly as if it were a fashioned or painted figure. (cf 8)
Ist auch ein Mensch mit Schönheit versehen [und] lieblich anzusehen, nur die Klugheit ist ihm nicht, [so] sieht er genau so [schön] aus, als ob er eine geformte oder gemalte Gestalt wäre.
Even if a person is equipped with beauty [and] lovely to look upon, but has no prudence, [then] he looks exactly as [beautiful] as if he was a formed or painted shape.

Darauf denkt der Maler, der infolge [seiner] Dummheit das hölzerne Mädchen für ein wirkliches Mädchen hielt, eben bei sich: "Ach diese Schönheit, ach diese Verschämtheit durch weibliche Schüchternheit! ..."
Thereupon the painter, who, due to [his] foolishness, took the wooden girl for a real girl, thought to himself: "Ah, this beauty, ah, this bashfulness because of female shyness! ...

line.tr: [But] anytime she stretches her arm when she serves me, she pulls [me] onto her lap, as it were. (cf 9; 258)
[Wenn] sie den Arm reckt, indem sie [mich] bedient, zieht [wtl. nimmt] sie [mich] gleichsam in [ihren] Schoß.
[When] she reaches out [her] arm in attending [to me], she pulls [lit. takes] takes me onto [her] lap, as it were.
Das Geschmeide auf ihren Brüsten bewegt sich kaum, es hebt sich eben nur.
The jewellery upon her breast hardly moves, it just so slightly heaves.

line.tr: Aber [wenn sie] auch schüchtern [ist], [so] macht sie doch mein Herz von Liebe froh.
But even [if she is] shy, she still gladdens my heart with love.
Who may she be? Is she the sister, the daughter, or the wife, or the servant of the mechanic, or has she come to him as a guest, just like me? (cf 9; 46)
Wer [ist] sie wohl? Ist sie des Mechanikers Schwester [oder] Tochter oder Frau oder Dienerin?
Who [may] she [be]? Is she the mechanic's sister [or] daughter or wife or servant?
(But) a guest would not have been charged to pay honour to [another] guest. (cf 9; 258)
Darauf [denkt] der Maler: "Durch (meine) Leidenschaft soll (sie nicht geschädigt(?)) sein", er gähnt [und] macht Miene, die Hand zu strecken.
Thereupon the painter [thinks]: "Through (my) passion (she) shall (not) be (harmed(?))", he yawns [and] is about to stretch [out his] hand.

What if perhaps she had seated herself right before [lit. manifestly] me to honour me? As long as I don't speak to [lit. honour] her with heart-felt affection [lit. honour], my dream [that] this gentle one serves me, does not get spoilt yet.

Wenn sie offenbar etwa nur, [um] mich zu verehren, vor mir sitzen (sollte), [so] stört diese Zarte, [mich] bedienend, [von sich aus] auch nicht meinen Traum, solange ich zu dieser nicht die Sprache des Herzens spreche.

When, apparently only to venerate me, she (should) sit before me, this tender one, attending [to me], will not disturb my dream [of her own accord], as long as I do not speak to her in the language of the heart.
Wiederum denkt er: "Im Hinblick auf große Gefahr ist ja hier Klugen nicht erlaubt, zu zehnerlei Frauen Liebe zu äußern ..."
Again he thinks: "With regard to great danger wise ones are not allowed here to speak [their] love to ten kinds of women ... "

internalComments.comment: The translation ist off. ime is a relational noun that takes an adjective in -ṣi and a noun in the locative to mean 'conception of X as Y', cf. A5 b5: tām orṣināṃ śominānaṃ yneś śomiṃṣiṃ ime kälpo. Thus, our passage would better be translated as 'Not the self has been conceived of as the self by the beings'.

line.tr: Wiederum denkt er: "Wer könnte aber, wenn er ein so schönes Mädchen an solchem Ort und zu solcher Zeit gefunden hat, sich zurückhalten? Warum sollte ich nicht aus Liebe (zu) ihr ein Gespräch führen? Oder ob ich zuvor nach ihrer Hand fasse?"

Again he thinks: "But who could restrain himself, after having found such a beautiful girl in such a place at such a time? Why should I not, out of love for her, hold a conversation? Or should I reach for her hand before?"
Or what if I take her by the hand before? (cf 10; 259)

Als dann der Maler voll Liebe nach der Hand des künstlichen Mädchens fasste, zerbrach der Mechanismus sofort, auseinander fielen seine Lappen, Schnüre(?) [und] Holzpflöcke(,), und es war kein (Mädchen).
When the painter then, full of love, reached out for the hand of the artificial girl, the mechanism broke immediately, the rags, strings(?) [and] wooden pegs fell apart, and there was no (girl).
O dear! I have been terribly deceived by the master mechanic! Oh such [is] the power of passion! Oh such [is] the horror of ignorance! If a being loves mere rags so intensely!
Ach die Kraft der Leidenschaft, ach die Macht der Dummheit, wenn ein Mensch schon zu Lappen so heftig Liebe fasst!
Alas, the power of passion, alas the power of foolishness, if man falls in love [lit. seizes love] so deeply with mere rags!
If I examine the body parts one by one, there is nothing called “the self”. (cf 11; 260)

pada.s: Of the master painters the master of painters,my friend(?), came as a guest, pekäntāśśi , käṣṣiśśi ; käṣṣi pekant , ñi naṣu :

line.tr: Darauf zog der Maler sehr schnell [wtl. schnell schnell] Palette(?) [und] Farben hervor und malte noch in derselben Nacht sich selbst als Getöteten an die Wand mit einem Strick (um) den Hals, an einem Haken(?) hängend.

Thereupon the painter quickly, quickly took out [his] palette(?) [and] colours and, in the very same night, onto the wall he painted himself as a killed one with a rope (around) [his] neck, hanging from a hook(?).

... einen Strick um den Hals, an einem Haken(?) hängend als Getöteten, ... [so] sich selbst wie leibhaftig gemalt habend/als er sich wie leibhaftig gemalt hatte, nahm er seine Palette(?) [und] ging hinaus(?).
... a rope around [his] neck, hanging from a hook(?) as one killed, ... having painted himself thus as if real, he took his palette(?) and went out(?).
Als dann morgens der Mechaniker zum Maler kam, sah er das künstliche Mädchen auseinandergefallen und sah [auch] den Maler als [Selbst]-getöteten an einem Haken(?) hängend.
When, in the morning, the mechanic came to the painter, he saw the artificial girl fallen apart and [he also] saw the painter as a killed one, hanging from a hook(?).

Sehet, [ihr] Herren, dieses mein Unglück! Von den Malermeistern der Malermeister, mein Freund, kam als Gast, mein künstliches Mädchen versah ihm den Dienst. Aus Liebe wohl berührte er das Mädchen, der Mechanismus zerbrach, [und] aus Scham darüber [wtl. aus d[ies]er Scham] tötete sich der Maler selbst, er hängt an einem Haken(?), sehet, [ihr] Guten!

See, lords, this my misfortune! The master painter of master painters, my friend, came as a guest, my artificial girl served him. Out of love, it seems, he touched the girl, the mechanism broke, [and] out of this shame the painter killed himself, he is hanging from a hook(?), see, [you] good ones!

Presumably out of love he touched the girl and the mechanism broke down. Out of shame the painter killed himself: he is hanging from the nail—look, o good ones!

line.tr: Es kam ein Maler eines anderen Landes, in meinem Haus war er abgestiegen. Der hat sich jetzt aus Scham selbst getötet.
A painter from another country came [along], in my house he put up. He has now killed himself out of shame.
The lord should know this. (cf 12; 261)
er tötete sich selbst
he killed himself
Deshalb weinten sie alle insgesamt. Darauf sagte der Mechaniker zu den Menschen: "Weinet doch nicht, holet (mir) eine Axt herbei: Nach Zerschneidung des Strickes tragt diesen fort!"
Therefore they were all crying together. Thereupon the mechanic said to the people: "Don't cry, bring me an axe: the string, having been cut, carry away!"
Darauf wollte der Mechaniker mit der Axt den Strick zerschneiden.
Thereupon the mechanic intended to cut the rope with the axe.

Tu's nicht, tu's nicht, sei nicht traurig, o Mechaniker, [zerstöre] nicht deine Wand, zerstöre nicht mein makelloses Gemälde, sieh sorgfältig zu, [o] Freund, beachte zuvor die Regel: [Ein] anderes ist das Gemälde, [ein] anderes der Maler, warum weißt du [das] nicht?

Don't do it, don't do it, don't be sad, oh mechanic, don't [destroy] your wall, don't destroy my faultless painting, watch carefully, [my] friend, mind first the rule: [an]other [thing] is the painting, [an]other [thing is] the painter, why don't you know [this]?

internalComments.comment: The translation strikes me as strange. Also, if it was correct, we would expect an explanation of why inertia is so bad to follow in the discourse. Considering the text is discussing what kind of quality is pruccamo, I believe it would be more sensible to read it as 'Or if (they are) without knowledge, what is power, strength [and] energy, that is all inertia.' i.e. power, strength and energy without knowledge are worthless, thus knowledge is pruccamo. This would fit better with what came before (Ravana was powerful but stupid), and it would especially directly pick up something said in A2: cami ālāsuneyis nu tsraṣṣune pratipakṣ nāṃtsu. It also fits better with what comes after: That knowledge is also better than amok. Thus, my reading would be better also from a literary point of view. We would also have a correlative clause - translated very stiltedly into English - with kus and täm, while the current translation seems to just ignore täm. Also, are there any other attestations of pkänt with the meaning 'opposite'?

Even more the opposite of knowledge, as well as of power, strength [and] energy, is inertia indeed. kupre pat nu knānmuneyäṣ pkänt kuss ats ne nati wä(rṣaltsune)

Skilful ones, too, for lack of wisdom, lose their life just because of their skill, at the wrong time. || amoktse penu knānmuneyäṣ wärcetswātsu(ne)
a(mo)k ṣurmaṣik sne praṣt śol näkseñc

Just like that at another occasion four craftsmen intended to go to some other country. There, when they manifested the skilfulness and merit of their respective skills, one [of them] says: mäṃt ne ālyäkyāṃ praṣtaṃ śtwar amoktse ālakäṃcaṃ (ype)

Through my art this is my ability: ñi amokyo täṣ cämplune

If I find the bones of a deceased, even [if] they have fallen apart, I will put them together again. kupre ne waluntāp ṣñi āyäntu (pkä)
nt pkänt penu kākloñcäs kälpāmār cesäm näṣ wnā kaśal tswāsam
The second says: || wät träṅkäṣ

But I will join the bones completely with the sinews. näṣ nu ce(smä)
k āyäntu pUkāk puskāsyo kaśal malkamäm

line.tr: Die richtige Anweisung seines Bruders nahm er [scil. Rāvaṇa] falsch auf.
His brother's proper instruction he [i.e. Rāvaṇa] took the wrong way.
If I find the bones of a deceased, even [if] they have fallen apart, I will put them together again.
Wenn ich von einem Gestorbenen seine Knochen, auch [wenn sie] auseinandergefallen [sind], finde, werde ich sie wieder zusammensetzen.
If I find the bones of one who has died, even [when they have] fallen apart, I will put them together again.
But I will join the bones completely with the sinews.
Der Zweite sagt: "Ich aber werde euch eben die Knochen sämtlich mit Sehnen zusammenfügen."
The second one says: "Myself, I will join for you the bones with the sinews entirely."
But I will restore the bones with flesh, blood, skin, outer skin, and hair, exactly like before.
Der dritte sagt: "Ich aber werde ihm eben die Knochen mit Fleisch, Blut, Haut, Fell(?) [und] Haar genauso wie zuvor völlig [wieder]herstellen."
The third one says: "I, however, will entirely [re]produce for it, exactly as before, precisely the bones with flesh, blood, skin, fur(?) [and] hair."

(Immediately), one spoke a charm [over] water in the palm of [his] hand [and] only sprinkled [it] onto the bones, [and] instantly, the bones, || (in the) [metre] Ñikci paṇḍurā ... || [that had] fallen far, far apart on the mountain into the rocks, even from the depth they came up – as if they were flying [lit. skipping as it were], they came together. ([over] water) [and] sprinkled [it] over the bones, [and] immediately the bones [were] joined with sinews.

Sofort erhob er sich von [seinem] Lager, mit gähnen die Tatze streckend, [und] hungrig [und] durstig erblickte er die Kunstfertigen, die sich in [seiner] Nähe befanden, [und] eben sie alle vier zusammen(?) mit der Pranke zermalmend, tötete er sie alle und fraß sie auf.

Immediately he rose from [his] lair, stretching [his] paw with a yawn, [and] hungrily [and] thirstily he saw the skilful ones, who were close by, [and] crushing those very four all together(?) with [his] paw, he killed them all and ate them up.

line.tr: Gut war ihre Kunstfertigkeit. Aus den zerbrochenen Knochen ließen sie den Löwen erwachsen/stellten sie sich einen Löwen her, [aber] an die Möglichkeit, dass sie von dem Löwen gefressen werden könnten [wtl. das Gefressenwerdenkönnen] hatten sie nicht gedacht, [und so] wurden sie Nahrung ihres Löwen durch [ihre] Dummheit.

Good was their artistry. From the broken bones the lion they let grow forth, [but] the possibility of being eaten by the lion they had not considered, [and thus] they became the food of their lion because of [their] foolishness.

Sie sammelten die zerbrochenen Knochen des Löwen und stellten ihn mit Kunstfertigkeit [wieder] her. / Die zerbrochenen Knochen des Löwen haben [hatten?] sie gesammelt, mit Kunstfertigkeit hatten sie ihn [wieder]hergestellt, [aber] die eigenen Knochen brachten sie (an die Stelle) der Löwenknochen [und] gingen zugrunde.

They gathered the lion's broken bones and with skill restored it [i.e. the lion]. / The broken bones of the lion they [had?] collected, with artistry they had restored it, but the[ir] own bones they brought (in the place) of the lion's bones [and] perished.

line.tr: Dies ist die alles überragende gute Eigenschaft der verdienstvollen Taten für uns, dass sie da nicht durch Feuer verbrannt werden, nicht durch Wasser fortgespült werden, nicht von Königen weggenommen [und] auch nicht von Dieben gestohlen werden können.
This is the good property, exceeding all [else], of the deeds of merit for us, that they cannot be burned by fire, be swept away by water, be taken away by kings [and] be stolen by thieves either.

Nachdem die fünf Prinzen auf solche Weise je ihre Vorzüge gesagt hatten, sprechen sie dann wieder zueinander: ...
After the five princes each had {sic!} spoken their merits, they again speak/say to each other: ...

line.tr: Wir [sind] hier die von unserem Vater gesammelten Besitztümer genießend und werden durch die Macht des Prinzentums im ganzen Land als Herrschaft gepriesen.
We [are] here enjoying the possessions gathered by our father, und due to the power of princedom we are praised as rulers all over the land.

line.tr: Als Prinz (Vīryavān) in einem fremden großen Wasser einen Sandelbaum [wtl. Sandelholz] im Strombett(?) treiben sah, zog er ihn (durch) seine Kraft (ohne Mühe) heraus. Dadurch erwarb er Geld.
When Prince (Vīryavān) saw, in a great foreign water, sandalwood float in the riverbed(?), he pulled it out (without effort because of) his great strength. Therefrom he gained money.
Auch Śilpavān, durch Lautenmusikmachen die Menschen (erfreuend), erwarb Geld.
Śilpavān, too, (delighting) the people by making lute music, acquired money.
Auch Prajñāvān erlangte Geld, indem er ganz große Reiche [und] Kaufleute (durch) [seine] Klugheit erfreute.
Prajñāvān, too, obtained money, by pleasing very great rich ones [and] merchants (with) [his] sagacity.

Die Minister, Leute des Landes, Kanzler [und] Gelehrte, die insgesamt Prinz Punyavānas Glanz erkannt hatten, lobten [und] priesen [ihn], vollzogen [wtl. machten] Punyavāns Salbung [und] machten ihn sich zum König in dem Lande.

The ministers, the people of the land, chancellors [and] scholars, who had all together realized prince Punyavāna's glory, lauded [and] praised [him), performed [lit. made] the anointing of Punyavāna [and] made him king of the country for themselves.
Sehet die Kraft der Tugendhaftigkeit [wtl. der Verdienste]! Sie führt dahin, wo das Glück [ist].
See the power of merits! It leads to where happiness [is].

Even if the beautiful one, the wise one, the energetic one, the skilled one strove [for it], they [still] did not reach perfection, which virtuousness had reached without effort.

line.tr: (Darauf) kamen (alle) zum König, und angesichts des Königs standen sie an der Pforte des königlichen Palastes.
(Thereupon [they] all) came to the king, and facing the king they stood at the gate of the royal palace.

rsnāl :
he who was Śilpavān is [now] to be known as Aniruddha. kus ne śilpavāṃ ṣeṣ säm aniruddhe kärsnāl :

He who was Prajñavān, is now to be known as Śāriputra. kus ne prajñavāṃ ṣeṣ säm tāpärk śāriputträ kä

He who at that time was Puṇyavān, I was he. kus ne tām praṣṭaṃ puṇyavāṃ ṣeṣ säm näṣ ṣem

Also at that time by the power of virtue I surpassed all other beings, and without effort reached royal dignity. tām praṣt penu näṣ pñiṣiṃ tampeyo puk ālykes (wra)

Even now, by the power of virtue I sit upon the diamond throne, I have [also], without effort, defeated the army of the god Māra [consisting] of 36 times 10 million family members, and the dignity of the king of the world, the unsurpassable, perfect Buddhahood, ruling all dharmas, I have reached. tāpärk penu pñiṣinās tampeyäntuyo waśirṣi(ṃ) (ā)

line.tr: Durch die Kraft der Tugendhaftigkeit lässt die Energie nicht nach.
Through the power of virtuousness, the energy does not weaken.
Durch die Tugendhaftigkeit besiegt die Sonne den Mond im Luftraum, durch die Tugendhaftigkeit übertrifft der Mond die Sterne [und] Planeten.
Through virtue the sun defeats the moon in the airspace, through virtue the moon surpasses the stars [and] planets.
Durch die Tugendhaftigkeit wird man [wtl. ist man fähig] zu dem mit Verehrung behandelten Buddha.
Through virtuousness one can become a Buddha, treated with reverence.
In den sechs Pāramitās [vollkommenen Tugenden] d[ies] er zwei Saṃbhāras aber hat sich der Buddha, der Meister, in drei Asaṃkhyeyas [und] hundert Kalpas geübt.
In the six pāramitās [perfect virtues] of the[se] two saṃbhāras, however, the Buddha, the master, exercised himself in three asaṃkhyeyas [and] a hundred kalpas.

prose.s:
The Arhat, the Buddha [and] master, however, when he was the king named Mahāprabhāsa, had with his determination as hard as diamond sown the seed of Buddhahood without turning back in his sequence of incarnations. āṣānik ptāñkät käṣṣi nu äntā ne mahāprabhā(se)
ñomā wäl ṣeṣ waśirr oki prākräṃ pratimyo sne lotkluneyumänt puttiśparṣiṃ śäktālyi ṣñi sant(ānaṃ)

From there on, collecting the sambhāras of merit, he went into the third Gaṇitasthāna. tmäṣṣ aci pñiṣinās sambhārntu kropnmāṃ okāk tricäṃ gaṇitasthānaṃ yeṣ
From there also, he did not (turn back). tmäṣ penu m·

line.tr: Because when the mahākalpas arrive at the sixtieth gaṇisthāna, at that moment it is [only] one asaṃkhyeya. (cf 22)
If eighty antarakalpas pass, it is one mahākalpa. (cf 22)

If there is one mahākalpa, it is in the first gaṇitasthāna; if there are two, three, until nine mahākalpas, they are just in the first [gaṇitasthāna]; if there are ten mahākalpas, they are in the second gaṇitasthāna; if there are twenty, thirty, until ninety, they are just in the second; if there are a hundred mahākalpas, they are in the third gaṇitasthāna. (cf 22)

Ist es e i n Mahākalpa, [so] befindet er sich im ersten Gaṇitasthāna [Zahlenstelle]; sind es zwei, drei bis neun Ma(hākalpas), [so] befinden sie sich ebenfalls noch im ersten [Gaṇitasthāna]. Sind es zehn Mahākalpas, [so] (befinden sie sich) im zweiten Gaṇitasthāna. Sind es (zwanzig, dreiß)ig bis neunzig, [so] befinden sie sich ebenfalls noch im zweiten. Sind es hundert Mahākalpas, [so] befinden sie sich im (dritten Gaṇitasthā)na.

If it is o n e mahākalpa, it is in the first gaṇitasthāna; if its two, three, up to nine ma(hākalpas), they are also still in the first [gaṇitasthāna]. If there are ten mahākalpas, (they are) in the second gaṇitasthāna. If there are (twenty, thir)ty, up to ninety, they are also still in the second. If there are a hundred mahākalpas, they are in the (third gaṇitasthā)na.

If a being turns back from the Buddha rank from the third gaṇitasthāna, it is called “khaḍgaviṣāṇakalpa” and it goes into nirvāṇa as a pratyekabuddha. If, however, with firm determination and compassionate, it does not turn back from the third sthāna, from then on the Buddhas manifestly and definitely make the prophecy of the Buddha rank. (cf 22)

Der Arhat, der Buddha und Meister, hatte aber, als er der König namens Mahāprabhāsa war, mit [seinem] wie Diamant festen Entschluss den Samen zur umkehrlosen Buddhaschaft in seine Geburtenfolge gesät.

The arhat, the Buddha and master, however, when he was the king named Mahāprabhāsa, with determination as hard as diamond, had sown the seed of irreversible Buddha-hood into the sequence of his incarnations.

line.tr: Der Buddha, der Meister, Śākyamuni, [unser] Schutz [und unsere] Hoffnung, wird von Erkrankung durch Windkrankheit gequält, o Bṛhaddyuti!
The Buddha, the master, [our] protection [and our] hope, Śākyamuni, is tormented by sickness from the wind-disease, oh Bṛhaddyuti!
Einen durch Kalpas hindurch in [meinen] Geburten nicht gehörten Namen hörte ich; deshalb frage ich dich: "Wer [ist] das, was [bedeutet] das: 'Buddha'?"
I heard a name [I have] not heard in [my] births for [long] kalpas; therefore I ask you: "Who [is] this? what [is the meaning of] this: 'Buddha'?"

Den bu(ddhaschaftlichen Körper) des Arhat quält jetzt, wenn er (seines Weges) geht, Erkrankung durch den Wind.
Illness because of the wind now torments the Bu(ddha-like body) of the arhat, when he goes (on his way).
Bringe selbst Öl [und] warmes Wasser, sieh mit eigenen Augen den Meister!
Yourself, bring oil [and] warm water, see the master with [your] own eyes!
Bring oil and warm water yourself, and look at the teacher with your own eyes. Your eyes will be successful [and] your human birth will be successful.
O so wonderful is mere human birth, if it is endowed with such virtue!

line.tr: Darauf verehrte Bṛhaddyuti, der mit über die Maßen großer Freude nahe an den ehrwürdigen Buddha Śākyamuni herangekommen war, (mit) größter Hochachtung [und] Ehrerbietung, mit aneinandergelegten Händen die Füße des Śākyamuni, und dem unersättlich anzusehenden buddhaschaftlichen Körper die Rechte (zukehrend), spricht er zum Buddha: "Wenn, o Arhat, einer wie ich würdig wäre, (deinen) leuchtenden ... (Körper zu berühren), [so] möchte ich die Erlaubnis [dazu] erlangen, mit eigener Hand möchte ich den Buddha baden. Du, der du den [deinen] Wunsch erfüllenden [ihren] Wunsch gewährst, (erlaube es mir(?))."

Thereupon, Bṛhaddyuti, who, with joy beyond measure had come close to the venerable Buddha Śākyamuni, (with) the greatest respect [and] deference, with hands folded, venerated the feet of Śākyamuni, and (turning) [his] right (towards) the Buddha-like body, satelessly to be looked at, and says to the Buddha: “If, oh arhat, one like me was worthy (of touching your) bright ... (body), I would like to gain permission to bathe the Buddha with [my] own hand! You, who grants the wish[es] of those adhering to [your] wishes, (permit me(?) [to do so]).”

line.tr: If [someone] like me, o arhat, were worthy of touching your dignified body, may I obtain the permission that I may wash the Buddha with my own hand! (cf 27)
Tue so, [mein] Sohn, bade du selbst des Buddhas Körper!
Do so, [my] son, bathe you the Buddha's body yourself.

Sofort wich er [wtl. hob er sich] mit Scheu zurück [und] dachte, mit tränenden Augen auf den Körper des Buddha, des Meisters, blickend: "Aller Glanz, Adel, Zartheit [und] (Lieblichkeit) [ist] an dem Körper des Buddha, [aber] trocken, hart, rauh [und] kalt [sind] meine tonbearbeitenden Hände, schwerfällig geworden."

Immediately he recoiled shyly [and] thought, gazing with tear-filled eyes on the body of the Buddha, the Master: "All brilliance, nobility, tenderness [and] (grace) [is] on the body of the Buddha, [but] dry, hard, rough [and] cold are my clay-working hands, having become clumsy."
How could I miserable one touch it? Or don't I touch it? … What am I doing? (cf 29)

Bṛhaddyuti's body began to make reverence towards the right [hand side].
Es erhob sich in ihm der sehr starke Wunsch nach der Buddhaschaft.
There arose in him the very strong desire for Buddhahood.
Durch diesen guten Dienst, durch diese Hingabe möchte mir (dieser) Wunsch (bestimmt) in Erfüllung gehen, (ich möchte ein Lehrer(?) sein) in der Welt.
Through this good service, through this devotion, (this) wish may (certainly) be fulfilled for me, (I want to be a teacher(?)) in the world.

Small fragment of the left side. The string hole space is preserved in lines 3 and 4. Lines a1 and b6 are lost. There are traces of signs in the margin of the recto side.
·ñ(i)s is most likely a gen.sg. (or pl.?).
The phrase mäṃtne klyoṣtä(r) also attested in the small fragment a 2.

Probably, tont is the fem.nom.pl. PPt of 'to put'. For the name dharmarājika- lit. 'belonging to a king of the Law', see and II: 530a; actually, it refers to a monument serving for the relics of the Buddha.
One may restore either (pñintwā)śśi oko or (lyalypäntwā)śśi oko.

The most likely restoration is (ṣtā)ṅkaṃ 'in the palace'. The personal name Badhe does not make sense, because there is no Sanskrit form badha-; it may stand for *Vadhe from Skt. vadha-, which would be a name by itself or a shorten form of a compound name; cf. . In theory, one may think of Skt. bādha- 'oppresser' , but this noun does not make a proper name.

The form ending with ñ cannot modify the next word paräṃ 'dignity'. The most likely restoration is (wrasa)ñ 'beings' or (ñäkta)ñ. alpa belongs to a form borrowed from Sanskrit; it cannot be a tune name since the following text is not metrical.
räṣ may be restored to (wāwleṣu)räṣ 'having accomplished'.

One may restore the form of the adj. saṃsārṣi as an obl.pl.masc.
The derived adjective from the Sanskrit name Kumāralāta has been written here with a hypercorrect retroflex.
The phrase piṭak sutä(rṣi) can be safely restored if one admits the reverse word order here for sutärṣi piṭak matching Skt. sūtra-piṭaka- (cf. b1 and b7).

There is place for restoring vaibhāṣi(k \), which would be the nom.sg. of the loan word from Sanskrit vaibhāṣika- referring to a member of a Buddhist school. But the next sequence of two akṣaras does not lead to a known TA word form. The vowel of the ‹na› can be a, ā, e, ä.
smac can only ba an allative pl. of the demonstrative säm, either the masc. cesmac or the fem. tosmac.

The reading pārlā is certain. A misspelling for pārlyāṅk is out of the question in any case because this is a technical term borrowed from Sanskrit (= TB parlyāṅk) and refers to the crosslegged position in meditation.
näṣ is rather an ablative form of an n-stem than the 1st singular personal pronoun. omäskenäṣ "because of evil" would be a possibilty (cf. line a 6).
On top of the ligatura we cannot see a vowel, so that it cannot be anything else than the present participle of the causative of the root ritwā -.
l is the end of a gerundive constructed with näṣ in a nominal sentence. sa could be the beginning of a 1.sg.act. subjunctive form of sälp- 'to burn'.
mār is the end of a 1.sg. middle verb form. ku is certainly a form of the interrogative pronoun kus or the beginning of the conjunction kuprene 'if'.
The tune has 4x18 syllables (7/7/4).

Both fragments were joined by Siegling in his personal copy, where he further noted on p. 26: "den von den Meer-Wesen gestohlenen Cintāmaṇi erhält der Bodhisattva zurück, da er das Meer auszuschöpfen droht mit seiner Schildkrötenschale." (The Boddhisattva receives back the Cintāmaṇi that has been stolen by the sea creatures after threatening to scoop out the sea with his turtle shell bowl.)

Number 121 is written on the margin of the verso side, but the number 110 (sic!) inside the string hole, the latter by a different hand in careless script. Note that deviating numbering between margin and string hole is also attested for the series to which belongs to the same manuscript. There the difference is likewise between nine and ten numbers, the string-hole number being the lesser one.
About 10 akṣaras are missing between the fragments. Siegling's proposal in his personal copy of pe(nu ca)m is impossible since nu is not an option; fremdzeichen m is possible but uncertain.
About 10 to 12 akṣaras are missing between the fragments. The tune has 4x25 syllables (5/5/8/7).
The dot at the end of the line interrupts a sentence; rather, it is a number one that has been misplaced during copying, since it is missing after pāda 1d.

The reading ṅkatsi is certain; accordingly, the form can only be an infinitive of a verb with present III or IV. Such a verb is as yet unattested in TA, but it could be the first attestation of the TA equivalent of TB präṅk(ā) - 'to restrain' or tsäṅk(ā) - 'to arise', more likely the latter.
The ligatura ‹yma› with a second ‹u› is peculiar; it hardly represents yumā; rather it is a misspelling for yāmlune.

General note: The key word in the technical passage on the recto is the term Gaṇitasthāna, which denotes different levels in high numbers; in Tocharian A, we find a3 kaśaṣi lame 'number place'. It is used to structure the large number of Mahākalpas that makes one Asaṃkhyeya "uncountable" period. The first Gaṇitasthāna contains 1 to 9 Mahākalpas, the second 10 to 99, the third 100 to 999, etc. There are in total sixty Gaṇitasthānas, which correspond to the list of powers of ten in Mvy. (Sakaki) 7988 - 8048. The division of an Asaṃkhyeya into Mahākalpas is discussed in Abhidh-k (: vol. 2, p. 189-190 = ch.3, 93d), where sthāna instead of the more technical Gaṇitasthāna is used (the Chinese has chù 處). Compare also a similar passage in a1-b1.
näṣ: probably an ablative, perhaps (gaṇitasthā)näṣ.
(śtwarā)k: this tentative restoration, one of the very few that are palaeographically possible, would fit the second Gaṇitasthāna. The concept of 40 Mahākalpas is also found in a6.
we: probably we wälts '2,000' (if in the fourth Gaṇitasthāna), less likely we tmāṃ '20,000' (if in the fifth Gaṇitasthāna).
wramnaśśäl: a vowel ä has been erased above mna. After _l\ a piece of paper has been glued upon the fragment, apparently for repair.

Left part of the leaf, the margin is not preserved, but traces of the leaf number 1xx are seen inside the string hole space on the verso side written by a different hand.
Siegling proposed the restoration (sät)k(ār)tsā in his notes p. 27 on the basis of b3.

The original text most likely had omäskenäṃ with the fremdzeichen ‹na›, since this is a rare sign, the scribe miscopied it taking it for ‹śa›; ptāñktā is a metrically reduced form of perl.sg. ptāñäktā. The little piece at the end of the line has been wrongly glued here. The rest of the original sign before this is compatible with the reading ma or pa .

The edition in proposed to read [ṣa]t\ akmalyo, which would be supported by b3, a2 and a5. The phrase ṣät-akmalyo is recorded in . But this reading is impossible in the manuscript, which rather shows [ṇa]. This does not allow for a plausible interpretation. The most likely hypothesis, then, is that it was miscopied from ṣat .
Siegling in his notes restored to (ts)itoräṣ; likewise .
nant is the end of an adjective, fem.nom.pl.

: the last part of line b5 and the whole of line b6 are metrical, the metre probably being 4 x 12 (5 + 7). This is supported by the syntax. The expected punctuation "(:)" can be restored after (pñ)i and before śpālunt.

line.tr: Den königlichen Befehl, das väterliche Wohlwollen verspottest du.

... (Wie sie den von den Caṇḍālas weggeführten Sohn(?)) sah, wurde sie, als sie. "O Mitleidiger!" sagen wollte, ohnmächtig [und] (fiel) zur Erde.

meneklinaṃ: This tune has 4x12 syllables, rhythm 5/7.
Sieg's restoration cämpamo träṅktsi y(n)e(ś naṣt) '[Obwohl] (du) augenscheinlich imstande (bist) zu sprechen' () is not possible: the reading y(n)e is excluded.

(b)odhisatvāp mācar lāts 'the mother of the Bodhisattva, the queen' is probably the subject of the abs. pälkoräṣ 'having seen'. This would mean that wlāññäktes wājärr oki kräntsonāṃ kapśi(ñño) and another ca. 18 syllables all belong to the object of pälkoräṣ, which probably ends with s(e) 'son'. ills in the end of this lacuna as "(Wie sie den von den Caṇḍālas weggeführten Sohn (?)) sah". Indeed, it is likely that the queen sees her son in need, but the precise restoration remains uncertain.
The line originally began with the last 5 syllables of the strophe. The following is again in prose.
vi(śikkonaṃ): This tune has 4x18 syllables, rhythm 7/7/4.
nuk: A writing error for ñuk.
In the preceding lacuna the king has probably refused her request.
(ak)m(a)l: So to be read against , who restores (oñi c)m(o)l 'human birth'; both c and o are excluded.

According to , these lines contain a strophe with a metre of 4x15 syllables. This is impossible because in b4 we have 19 syllables without punctuation (which Sieg expects after kenn ats) and because the caesurae are wrong (both ṣäpnasaṃ menā(k) and śāwaṃ ākālntwā kakmu should rather have been 4 + 3, see ). We should also note that Sieg's metrical analysis does not square with his translation.

... In that way this Bodhisattva [named] Rupyāvata (sic!) as a king during sixty years (held) the kingship,
... ornated by virtues without number, having passed from this earth, (he was reborn in) the world of the Tuṣita gods.

-syo is the end of an instr. pl., probably (yetwe)syo 'with ornaments'.
For the meaning of the adverb/uninflected adjective ṣārce, see b 5.
The meter has most probably 4x15 (7/8) syllables, according to Siegling, pers. copy.

The passage refers to the first and second births of the Bodhisattva: he started as a woman named Rūpāvatī who gave up her life in order to feed a starving woman and renounced her female sex becoming a man afterwards; the Bodhisattva was then reborn as a prince named Rūpāvata. This story culminates in a5 in a prompt to be as generous as these previous beings.

Since the sign ‹ṣä› is on the same level as the following akṣaras of the line and since there is no trace of virāma, we prefer to read ṣäṃ. we- has to belong to a disyllabic form because of the meter, a probable restoration would be we(yeṃ) 'wonderful, amazed'.

line.tr: Die Götter scheinen(?) gleichsam von den himmlischen Palästen herabzufallen.
The gods seem(?), as it were, to fall from the heavenly palaces.
I will have a look on the others too and (I will) with a clear view take (my) measure against deception. (cf 1012)
Aber ich muss auch auf die anderen sehen, [und] (ich muss) mit scharfem blick die Überlegung zu (meiner) Maßgabe (machen).

This line appears to be in verse. However, Sieg's suggestion () that the metre is 4x14 syllables does not fit śäpsaśśäl riwoṣ klyomäṣ, which should have been 4 + 3.

śäpsaśśäl riwoṣ: Without doubt to be corrected into riwoṣ, cf. b3 śäpsaśśäl triwoṣ. The meaning of śäpsaśśäl is not clear. It appears to be a com.pl., possibly of a word śäp, and it may designate a certain type of person.

yärka(nt yāmwā): Restoration after . This lacuna is 15 syllables long (2 syllables of pāda 1a and 13 of 1b).

noṣpeṃ: Very probably a postposition governing the genitive, cf. also a5 temik noṣpeṃ. suggests "zur Herzensäußerung" ( compares Skt. udāna-), but perhaps a spatial function like '(turned) towards' (as in the translation) is more likely.
svarṇapuṣpenaṃ: Name of a tune with 4x18 syllables (7 + 7 + 4).

ṣkitā(nträ): An unclear hapax, which hesitantly translates as "scheinen". Since we also find oki 'as, as if' in the same clause, it might rather be an aspectual verb that expresses progressivity, for instance.
This line seems to start a tune of 4x18 syllables (7 + 7 + 4).

comments.comment: Transcription and translation are based on .

Transcription and references have been transferred from the "Text and Reference Database of the Tocharian A Language" (Gerd Carling Lund University) (funded by the Bank of Sweden Tercentenary Foundation and SCAS).

This manuscript has consistent spelling of double virāma (i.e. with stroke and dot) with the remarkable exception of phrases: camak\ camak\• 'one after the other' (a1). Accordingly, ślak\• śkaṃ 'and in addition' (a5) was not interpreted as a phrase.
Unlike in the edition in , recto and verso side have to be reversed, according to Siegling, pers. copy.
Word separation is uncertain. Note that Siegling, pers. copy took tsaranämak as a single word.

Siegling, pers. copy proposed to resore (omä)sk(e)nāśśi 'evils', but the recorded gen.pl. is omäskenäśśi. In addition, (plya)sk(e)nāśśi 'meditations' seems to fit the context better, since Naivasaṃjñānāsaṃjñāyatana is reached by meditation.
In the verb form is restored as 3.sg. middle present e(ntsäṣtär). Alternatively, Siegling, pers. copy proposed to restore the 3.pl. middle subjunctive e(ntsantär).

The verbal form artär does not belong to ār(ā) - 'to cease' (attested twice in this text) nor to ar- 'to evoke', but is a 3.sg. middle present from ārtā - 'to love', as per ; however, pace Schmidt, it is not due to a misspelling of expected artatär, but rather an analogical form, i.e. with syncope in analogy from the other persons.
The meter has 4x25 (5|5|8|7) syllables.
The hapax waro can be seen as an adjective derived from a noun *war being the match of TB 'hatred, enmity'.

The form before (a)kappi is most likely a sandhi variant of a disyllabic word ending in -i. The remnants of the last akṣara are compatible with 〈ṣya〉. Therefore, one may conceive a form of śoṣi 'world'; it may then be a compound meaning 'the impurity of the world'.
The tune name cannot be restored, the meter has 20+22+10+15 syllables with the rhythm a=5/5/5/5, b=8/7/7, c=5/5, and d=8/7.

(So) hat der Buddha in (seinem) Herzen gedacht: "Wen soll ich zuerst verehren?" [Aber] er fand keinen Verehrungswürdigen, den er hätte verehren können.
Thus the Buddha thought in (his) heart: "Who shall I venerate first?" [But] he did not find any venerable one, whom he could have venerated.
Wem könnte ich [wohl] Verehrung erweisen?
Who could I pay homage to?
Die Söhne der fünf Geburtsklassen erinnerst du, o Buddha, an das Ende [d.h. an den Tod].
The sons of the five incarnations, oh Buddha, you remind of the end [i.e. of death].

Here they (= the possessions of the law) will turn round and go among men and gods; countless pleasures …; he who writes down the law, shows his gratitude to the Buddha; as many akṣaras as there are in a book, so many monasteries will the first make.
Wieviel Akṣaras in einem Buche [sind], so [viele] Klöster wird der eine bauen.
As many akṣaras [as there are] in a book, so [many] monasteries the one will build.
(Wer) das Gesetz [auf]schreibt, der tut [nach] dem Willen des Buddha.
(Who[ever] writes [down] the Law acts [according to] the Buddha's will.
Durch Asaṃkhyeyas [hindurch] hat der Meister in [seinen] Geburten das Gesetz gesammelt.
Through [long] asaṃkhyeyas, the master in [his] incarnations has assembled the law.
Unter Irrlehrern möchten wir nicht [wieder]geboren werden, nicht möchten wir einen [beliebigen] Spruch(?) für die rechte Lehre(?) halten.
Among teachers of false doctrines may we not be [re]born, may we not [mis]take a random saying(?) for the right teaching(?).

The fragment is currently missing. On the photo in the plates volume (; photos 8a and 8b), a small fragment is not included. This fragment must have contained a1 ssaṅkṣiṃ wi and b6 ṣimäs ca.

yä(rk)s(ā)t: This restoration of makes sense in the context, but this stem of the verb yärk- is not attested otherwise (cf. e.g. ). The reading is in fact not very likely to be correct: the last consonantal element of the second akṣara is certainly s, but it cannot have been only k, since it is too low and too far to the right. It is more likely to be the third consonantal element of a heavier ligature.
restores puk täm was ṣru(maṣ yāmtsāt klopant kropa)t saṃsāraṃ "Alles das hat er unseretwegen getan. Leiden hat er gesammelt im Saṃsāra.". If correct, ṣru(maṣ) would violate the metre.
– – klo(pant): restores (ālu) klo(pant), which does not seem possible. Parts of the large akṣara lu should still have been visible.
try esaṃkhesaṃ: For try asaṃkhesaṃ.

/// ñc ptāñkät: restores (tämne ṣñi āri)ñc ptāñkät pälskāt "(So) hat der Buddha in (seinem) Herzen gedacht". If correct, (ṣñi āri)ñc would violate the metre. The metre would be all right if the original text had e.g. (tämne ṣñ= āri)ñc pättāñkät.
märkampa(l): Possibly märkampa(lṣās niṣpalntu), cf. b1.
päñ-cmolwāṣnis: For päñ-cmolwāṣinäs. See a comparable inversion of the vowels of the last two syllables in b4 mṣapantnis and b5 mṣapantniṣ.

lipäṣ: The restoration of this word and the rest of the lacuna follows . The present stem of läyp-
s-tr. is so far unattested (cf. ; ).
sas: Literally 'one', but here probably 'the first', cf. b4-6 sas 'one', wät 'second', trit 'third'.
mṣapantnis: For mṣapantinäs. See a comparable inversion of the vowels of the last two syllables in a6 päñ-cmolwāṣnis and b5 mṣapantniṣ.
ānt ratkaṃ: Apparently a compound 'front army'.

The beginning of the line is restored as pekäntāśśi 'of the writers' by . Indeed, it is likely that the expression mṣapantnis ānt ratkaṃ is part of a metaphor, but Thomas' restoration violates the metre.
mṣapantniṣ: For mṣapantinäṣ. See a comparable inversion of the vowels of the last two syllables in a6 päñ-cmolwāṣnis and b4 mṣapantnis.
ṣukṣeñi āpṣātrikāñ: The metre rather requires 4 + 3 syllables here.
: For the reading and the restoration, cf. . Nevertheless, the metre is not regular: the first segment of mar wi(c) wrāṣimäs cam sīddhāṃ is 5 instead of the required 4 syllables.

märkampal(ṣ)ā(s) – – ntwaṃ: A restoration märkampal(ṣ)ā(s niṣpal)ntwaṃ, a frequent expression in this text, is excluded because the top of the akṣara ntwaṃ is preserved. Also a (metrically incorrect) spelling of the same as märkampal(ṣ)ā(s niṣpalä)ntwaṃ is impossible, because it would have taken more space. Theoretically, (cmolä)ntwaṃ would be possible.

In such a way precisely at the very time of the anointment of this glorious being [= Rūpyāvata] the great glory [of the city Utpalāvatī] became visible like (in the divine city of the god) Kubera. tanne wkänyo cami parnontāp wrases abhiṣekṣināṃ praṣtanäk ñäkciyāṃ kube(r)

(voi)ce, he [kept] instructing all beings with equal thought [and] with respect for every [being]. tmäṣ säm rupyāvate wäl bodhisatveṃ tsopatsäṃ kāruṇaśśäl triwont āṣträṃ knānmuneyo wlyepäṃ

line.tr: Die Blütenbäume schmückten sich immerfort mit Blüten, [und] ohne Melken gaben die Kühe Milch.

comments.comment: Transcription and translation are based on .

Transcription and references have been transferred from the "Text and Reference Database of the Tocharian A Language" (Gerd Carling Lund University) (funded by the Bank of Sweden Tercentenary Foundation and SCAS).
The meter has 4x14 syllables.

mänt in the phrase mänt wäknā 'in such a way, thus' is written with double virāma, even though in this manuscript such phrases or compounds are devoid double virāma after the first member. Note also the word-internal (!) double virāma spelling in mā_l\•kluneyo. There are other examples of such word-internal spellings in clusters, esp. in late TB texts.

The meter has 4x25 syllables with the usual rhythm (5|5|8|7). However, in pāda 1a we have an alternative colon division 5|5|7|8. Note that the tune name literary means "the royal one of the Ārśis", which fits with the content of the narrative about a royal celebration.

restores a Pt II w(a)wiwār for w(a)wipār from the causative of the root wipā - 'to moisten', followed by . However, the direct object is lost, and, what is more, it is more likely in this passage that the form refers to the act of waiving the aformentioned fans (and maybe chowries). The act of perfuming has already been mentioned in line a3.
Four to five akṣaras are missing.
The meter has 4x12 syllables, rhythm (5/7).
Formally, the 3.pl. Pt II śaśmānt 'they had been growing' does not comply with the remants of the akṣara in front of the lacuna. A better alternative is pyāṣtṣānt 'they became strong'.

ṣārce is otherwise only attested in A 57 a 2 in the phrase ṣārce spānte wätkāltsune 'firmness reliable [and] confident'. In the present context the adverb/uninflected adjective refers to fruits that are always edible and never raw or rotten.

... (The first one who), by himself intentionally breaks the good way [and] manner taken from the self;

«Very briefly put, (the cutting off of the) life of the beings [is] of two kinds: waltsurākk ats wrasaśśi wäṣt wäknā śo
(lis) (kärṣtālune)
by dying (in a natural way) [and] dying by effort. (ṣäññāk) wlaluneyo • skāyluneyo wlalune śkaṃ •
Dying in a natural way, however, is of a three-fold kind. ṣäññāk wlalune penu tri wäknā mäskatär •

The first dies (by the cessation of merits, the second) [dies] by the cessation of (possession), the third [dies] by the cessation of both, because: sas ṣñi
(ntwis) (ārluneyo) (wät) (niṣpa)lis ārluneyo • trit āmpine ārluneyo wälläṣtär kUyalte •

line.tr: Diese dreifachen Wesen [sind] durch (den Mangel) an [sittlicher] Haltung noch lebend als Tote zu erkennen; denn sieh, o Herr: Im Metrum Ṣāckācke || (Das Bewahren) der guten Dinge [ist] den Menschen (zugleich) Samen [und] Frucht gebend. Wer den Samen der Bewahrung in sich gesät hat, der [ist] von Menschenart. Wer aber seine (gute Art [und] Weise selbst) absichtlich unterbricht als Unverständiger, der [ist] auch lebend tot, von der guten Weise abgefallen [und] nicht von Menschenart.

These threefold beings, through (lack) of [moral] conduct, [are] to be recognized as dead ones even when still alive; for, see, lord: in the Ṣāckācke metre || (Maintaining) the good things [is] giving (, at the same time,) fruit and sees to the humans. Who[ever] has sown the seed of preservation in himself, he [is] of human kind. But who[ever] intentionally interrupts his (good way [and] manner himself) as an ignorant one, [he] is dead also while living, [has] fallen from the good manner [and is] not of human kind.
Mitleidslos [ist] der Tatengott, ungerecht(?) [sind] die Götter, die dessen sieben Juwelen, tausend Söhne, (tausend Töchter) [und] tausend Minister nicht zur Erscheinung bringen.
Without compassion [is] the god of deeds, unjust(?) [are] the gods, who do not reveal his seven jewels, thousand sons, (thousand daughters) [and] thousand ministers.

line.tr: Even though possessions are the fruit of merits, they do not [re-]establish life when it has perished.

line.tr: If both [scil. the merit, which causes life, and the possessions, which retain life] cease, that is the third cause for the beings in the world to die in a natural way.
Der eine stirbt durch die Bemühungen des eigenen Selbstes, der zweite durch die Bemühungen der anderen, der dritte (indessen) stirbt durch die Bemühungen (beider).
The one dies through the effort of [his] own self, the second through the efforts of others, the third, (however,) dies through the efforts (of both).

[Du] guter Vater, du darfst den gemeinen Tod nicht anderen bringen. Sieh, o Herr: Im [Metrum] Devadatta || (Un)besiegbar ([ist] der Tod), ... schwer fernzuhalten [und] jedem das Leben raubend [ist] der Tod; alle Wünsche zunichte machend, wie eine drohende Krankheit das Leben nehmend, wie der Ozean (unersättlich), ...(spottend(?) der Kraft des Heilmittels [und] des Zauberspruchs, bodenlos wie die Unterwelt. Wie könnte den wohl ein Mitleidiger anderen bringen?

Good father, you must not bring base death to others. See, lord: in the Devadatta [metre] || (In)vincible ([is] death), ... death is difficult to keep away [and] robbing everybody's life, taking life away like a threatening sickness, (edacious) like the ocean, ... (mocking(?)) the power of cure [and] charm, bottomless like the underworld. How could a compassionate one ever bring this onto others?

line.tr: ... (makellos) bist du. [Aber] aus diesem Grunde eben [ist] mir hier Besorgnis gekommen. Sieh, [meine] Tochter: || Im Metrum Śāntavantaka(?) || Der Vorzug [deiner] Schönheit ... deine Lieblichkeit [ist] in allen Gegenden Verbreitet. Aus den großen benachbarten Ländern [sind] die Weiber der Könige gekommen. Das eigene Leben ... um die (Gatten)perle bitten sie. Wenn ich dich einem König gebe, werden die anderen meine Feinde werden. Sie werden mit ihrem vierfachen Heere kommen ...

... you are (without blemish). [But] for this very reason apprehension has come [over] me. See, [my] daughter: In the Śāntavantaka(?) metre || The excellence of [your] beauty ... your grace [has] spread into all lands. From the great neighbouring countries the wives of the kings [have] come. The own life ... for the pearl of spouses they ask. If I give you to one king, the others will become my enemies. They will come with their fourfold army ...

line.tr: If I give you to one king, the others will be enemies to me, they will come with [their] fourfold army.
Sie werden mit [ihrem] vierfachen Heere kommen.
They will come with [their] fourfold army.
Bedenke, [meine] Tochter, wie (soll ich) [es] machen?
Consider, [my] daughter, how (shall I) do [it]?
O Herr, aus diesem Grunde sei du nicht bekümmert, denn Veranlassung hierzu [ist] überhaupt nicht.
Oh lord, for this reason do not be aggrieved, for there [is] no cause for it.
Therefore I too will choose a husband for myself in the svayaṃvara, free and according to my own will! (cf 9)
Dir soll nicht Not kommen.
Penury shall not come onto thee.
Darum werde auch ich in den Svayaṃvara eintreten und nach eigenem Ermessen mir den Gatten wählen [wtl. machen].
Therefore, I, too, will enter the Svayaṃvara and choose [lit. make] a husband for me after my own will.
Make [yourself, pl.] ready and come to the place that day, so that your [pl.] cherished wish will be fulfilled [and] you [pl.] will enjoy yourself with the pearl of women.
Rüstet euch [und] kommt an dem Tag zu dem Platz! Es wird euch in Erfüllung gehen der gehegte Wunsch. Ihr werdet euch an der Frauenperle erfreuen.
Equip yourselves and come to the place on this day! The wish you had will be fulfilled for you. You will take delight in the pearl of women.

muk is known otherwise as the translation of Skt. yuga- 'yoke', but this meaning does not fit this context because nati and tampe are abstract notions of positive qualities. suggests that here it transposes Skt. yoga-, with the meaning “harnessed team, unit”; however, that is not a likely translation either. Possibly, muk here rather transposes Skt. yoga- in the abstract sense of 'dispostion, fitness, zeal'.

When you have attained the Buddha-rank, may you remember me as well.

The meter has 4x12 syllables (5/7).
According to , note 5 and 9, the number 12 was written below the tune name consisting of 12 syllables and the number 14 below the tune consisting of 14 syllables by a different hand.
At the end of the line the manuscript allows the reading ñcaṃ as well as ñaṃ. In the former case one may consider the loc.sg. of a feminine noun with suffix -āñc.
The meter has 4x14 syllables (7/7).

Pace , one has to read tsuneśśi, being the gen.pl. of a noun ending in -tsune; since these are usually abstracts with a plural in -uyentu, the form may belong to an (animate) compound. The hands probably refer to the other women of the palace holding the child.
The meter has 4x14 syllables (7/7).
The sequence at·āśik is probably the name of the son; it may contain Skt. śikhā 'top knot, crest, tuft of hair' as second element.

... you will not think of [your] (royal) dignity [and] status. 1. When you see the ever changing seasons (?), rains [and] heat (?)
... the ... which cause longing, (when you) ... in the rivulets of water dug by nature

line.tr: Not in any way will I care about the hardship in the wilds if I follow you.

If you see the two ornamented with flower strings … you cannot remember kinghood; (if you see) the two childish ones (playing) in the salty bushes … you cannot think about the royal rank and worth. (If you) … the [appropriate] season …, the good and the bad season … if you see the … that cause joys; the courses (?) of the water dug by nature … as if sitting among … you will certainly enjoy yourself. (cf 135a)

translation.line: ... Thereupon he [i.e. the king] speaks: Say, [you] good ones, how shall I do? || In the Ś.-tune: || I [am] the ruler over the Jambudvīpa, the king, father by name (only)
... I make through my son. A word from him I ask, bowing with my body [and] with hands folded. But my wish is not fulfilled. Say [you],
([you] noble ones, how shall I do? 1. Thereupon) the ministers say: There is a remedy for this. Pleased the king says: Of what kind is it? Thereupon
... (the ministers) say without ... to the king: Oh lord, there is no other thing here as much beloved as one's life. Therefore
... (the prince) will (only) be able ... to hide as (long) as he does not come into danger to [his] life. When he had heard that, the king Brahmadatta, without looking at his own son, (agreed).
... even called, in the presence (of a great crowd of people), the Caṇḍālas, who kill the ones to be killed, [and] says: Ho, deathsmen (?)! || In the S.-tune: || All over the world my

(command (?) is obeyed with reverence) [and] good will. Deliberately, however, this my son mocks the royal command [and] does not comply to say a single word, although [he is] able [to speak]. Seize him
... If he does not say a word at all, take his life with the sword. 1. When he had heard that, the prince [began to] fear kingship even more.

... ([and] he thinks to himself: Oh, what) an awesomeness/cruelty that comes from the aberration of dominion of the kings! || In the W.-tune: || Because of masterly pride (the rulers) do (terrible things).
(But if) death becomes their master, then they go to the deep hells. The command to kill an impeccable son like myself [is]
(foolishness) ... [there?] is no longing for a royal sovereign/royal dominion. 1. When thereupon the Caṇḍālas knew the Bodhisattva [to be] surrendered by [his] father, the king,

... the naturally (cruel ones (?)), having tied the Bodhisattva’s flawless, tender arms to the back, as it were [= as if they were] without suffering, having placed the oleander wreath around his neck

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6

line.tr: Ein Wort von ihm erbitte ich, mich mit dem Körper beugend [und] mit zusammengelegten Händen. Aber er erfüllt meinen Wunsch nicht.
One word I ask of him, bending my body [and] with hands folded. But he does not fulfil my wish.
There is no other thing as dear as one's own life.
Will he be able to hide himself as long as he does not come into danger of life? (cf 18)
Mit Absicht indessen verspottet dieser mein Sohn den königlichen Befehl [und] fügt sich nicht, ein Wort zu sagen, obwohl [er dazu] imstande [ist].
Deliberately this my son mocks a royal command [and] does not acquiesce to say a word, although [he is] able [to speak].
If he does not say a word at all, take the life out of him with the sword! (cf 18)

translation.line: ... to the ministers daughters were born, [and] to the kings. Certainly vessels full of pearls
... ministers. The daughters of the kings are ready for a union, all other kings in Jambudvīpa
... The Bodhisattva sat silent, without paying attention. Thereupon the ministers, [with regard to] the one being loveless, say
... to the king: Oh lord, if the prince should not succeed in leaving the house
... give him [your] permission! He shall leave the house. If he obtains pleasure in the forest, [then it is] good. Judicious ones
... who gave up kingship [and] went to the forest. But if
... Also (for) the living there is (nothing) ... but father [and] mother.
... (Thereupon the king) says (heatedly) to the ministers: I have truly come to be deeply worried (?), because: || In the D.-
(-tune: || ... if) I separate from [my] dear son. He was living in happiness, wrapped in a beggar’s garment
... (If) I do (not) give him permission, he will starve himself. As if [caught] in a pair of tongs [I am] because of this suffering, (depressed in the heart) [and] in the belly.
(1. ... Give him permission!). Thereupon the king speaks to the ministers: So it shall be, [oh] skilful ones, if you
... permission the prince shall have. May he leave the house. The ministers thought: in that way the prince

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6

line.tr: If he obtains pleasure in the forest, it [is] good.
... gib ihm die Erlaubnis! Er soll aus dem Hause gehen. Wenn er am Wald Gefallen findet, [dann ist es] gut.
... give him permission! He shall go out of the house. If he takes delight in the wood, [it is] well.
... welche die Königswürde aufgaben [und] zum Walde gingen.
... who [pl.] gave up royal dignity [and] went to the forest.
... (wenn) ich mich von [meinem] lieben Sohn trenne.
... (when) I part from [my] dear son.
If I do not let him go, he will starve himself out.
[Wenn] ich ihm (nicht) die Erlaubnis gebe, wird er von selbst verhungern [wtl. das Selbst verhungern lassen].
[If] I (do not) give him permission, he will starve himself [lit. will let [his] self starve].
So it will be. (cf 23)
… the prince will have permission: he may leave the house. (cf 23)

translation.line: ... should fade completely like fire extinguished by water. 1. The mountain gods, who took note of this, speak in wonder:
(Oh on) the power (of compassion). || In the D.-tune: || See his compassion towards the murdering hunter, [his] enemy, splitting his heart with a sharp arrow.

... he [i.e., the hunter] increased as it were the pressure in [his] veins, but this one did (not) harbour any evil disposition towards him. (Because of) trust (the arrow) penetrated [his] body. Because of (?) the Bodhisattva-like ...
... his spirit should be cheerful. 1. (Thereupon) Subhadrā (again) says to the Bodhisattva: You have spoken well. The Kāṣāya-
(robe is praised as the best by all good ones). || In the M.-tune: || By the friendly, the merciful, and by all of the good ones the monk’s robe has of old (?) been praised as the best.
... (of such a robe (?), no) fear there is, [just] (like) the (moon)god (brings forth) only coolness (?), not burning. 1. See (, however, oh venerable one), has not from the monk’s robe
(arisen distress for you?) The Bodhisattva says: Do not plague my spirit [and my] heart again, for in no way [has] distress arisen (for me) from the monk’s robe.
... for me. See, oh skilled one, of all evil things passion, wrath [and] ign(orance) are (the source). Certainly this one’s

(venomous arrow [is] caused by this). There is (no passion), wrath or ignorance in his heart (with regard to) this matter [pertaining to] myself. (And) therefore he [is] without guilt. He [is] in the power of the three Kleśas.
(Miserable [is]) this (world). || In the N.-tune: || Caused by (the three Kleśas) and by the assistance of the bow the venomous arrow went (into) my
(breast) ... Or whatever the hunter’s guilt, the hapless one [is] in the power of the Kleśas. See the guilt of the Kleśas, not the guilt of the man,
(not the guilt of the robe. Thereupon) Subhadrā, exceedingly irritated, says to [her] husband: I am not able (to bear) your death because of this talk.

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6

line.tr: Sehet sein Mitleid gegen den mordenden Jäger, [seinen] Feind, [der] mit scharfem Pfeil [sein] Herz durchbohrt. ... [seine] Adern bedrohte förmlich der (Jäger), aber dieser hegte (nicht) böse Gesinnung gegen Ihn.

Behold his compassion towards the murdering hunter, [his] enemy, [who] with a sharp arrow pierces [his] heart. ... [his] veins the (hunter) virtually threatened, but this one did (not) harbour a bad disposition towards him.

translation.line: ... || In the V.-tune: || Should he (enjoy) a poisonous dish as good (food) ... who loves [his] life, why
... or why should one be fond of (?) a stained ... (how should) someone who wants to live, (yearn for [the smell of] a nice-smelling blue) lotus containing a snake
... How should I love kingship, oppressing me with the royal ... 1. And also, father, how could someone who [is] knowledgeable in it,
... or desirous be? See, oh lord: || In the P.-tune: || Hostilities [and] ... ... [are] also royal obligations
... of the kings [for] many years. (And) evil [is] the obligation, to the one [who is] ... (by) hate confused, at the (time) of [his] death.
... When he had heard this, (the king says) in bewilderment: ... (Oh lord,) my son! [For] years you (have (?))
... This you have not actually seen ... ... with regard to being a ruler (?) as a teacher
... (This) you have (not really) seen. This you do (not) know. ... ... kingship is (not) of such kind. Excitedly
(the prince says to the king:) Oh lord, in the doing of the kings (I do not see) the true knowledge of it [i.e. kingship]. ... The king says: Speak, speak, [my] son! (In) what
(way) do you really know the doing (of kings)? The prince says: Listen, father! Just like a human clearly seeing (one’s) ... shoulders without a callus
... (just so,) having the memory of the births, I remember [my] (previous) births. || In the Y.- tune: || (In) earlier births I have
... resorted (to cruelty) in order to preserve the realms. A man (made) a mistake, ... certainly the (command (?)) to kill

line.tr: Wie sollte ich die Königswürde lieben, die mich bedrückt durch die königlichen ... ?
How should I love the rank of king, which oppresses me with royal ... ?
... (genau so) erinnere ich mich, da ich die Erinnerung an die Geburten habe, der (früheren) Geburten.
... (just so), since I have memory of the incarnations, I remember [my?] (previous) births.

translation.line: ... Thereupon the hunter [told] how he (went) to the forest, (how) he there hit the elephant, how immediately the elephant, to keep him alive,
(hid him, how then he himself) pulled out the tusks, or how, because of this, the earthquake, the raining of divine flowers [and]
the praising of the Bodhisattva (by) gods, (humans), ... happened, or how even Indra sat on his knees before the Bodhisattva. That, too, (he told (?)) to the queen
... Thereupon, presenting the tusks to the queen, he says: And these tusks (he commanded me) to give to you. Shedding tears
(the queen speaks: What said (?)) the compassionate being? The hunter speaks: ... || In the S.-tune: || Not well (you did, when you sent the hunter)
to kill (me(?)). Repent! Drop the hate from [your] thoughts in all births and do not (let) the hate (?) ...
... the tusks I sent to you; take them, oh noble one, [and] forgive!. 1. When (Bhadrā) had heard this, ...
... threatened (all) her (veins), she fainted [and] (fell) to the ground. Immediately king Brahmadatta let Śītābhāsa-pearls (be brought (?))

(Thereupon) queen Bhadrā (, having come round again,) speaks, remembering [her] previous births, turning towards the mountainous region of the Himavant (and) thinking (?) (of her birth) as an elephant:
... reproaching herself: || In the H.-tune: || Oh! Ignorant and mean, because of hostility, jealousy and hatred,
not considering his (virtue), I have ordered to kill him. The one compassionate and in spirit [and] mind pure, like a wise man
... the followers with love. 1. Separated from him, they have (now) become unprotected [and] they will break asunder. I wonder where they will be going? Long

line.tr: Darauf [berichtete] der Jäger, wie (er) zum Walde (ging, wie) er dort den Elefanten traf, wie der Elefant (ihn) sofort, (um) ihn am Leben zu erhalten, (Verbarg, wie er dann selbst(?)) [sich] die Stoßzähne ausriss, ...

Thereupon the hunter [told of] how (he went) to the forest, (how) he hit the elephant there, how the elephant, (in order to) keep him alive, immediately (hid him, how he then) pulled out [his] (own(?)) tusks, ...

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6

line.tr: Bereue, entlass den Hass aus [deinem] Denken in allen Geburten ...
... repent, discard hate from [your] thoughts in all incarnations ...
Als [Bhadrā] das gehört hatte, ... lähmte (alle) ihre (Adern), sie wurde ohnmächtig [und] fiel zur Erde.
When [Bhadrā] had heard this, ... paralysed (all) her (veins), she fainted [and] fell to the ground.
Having been separated from him, they have now become miserable and will fall apart. Where will they go? (cf 16)
