translation.line: ... she says: Oh lord, do not speak thus! One ... thing is just not seen in dreams. There is no thing ...
... (If) they should be, still (on earth) they will be seen [only] once; together, however, these things are [to be found] all in the ocean. (If) ... come (?) ...
... the vision, oh great king. [He who] has educated himself in this matter in an earlier time, [he] (will ...) such a unique vision ...
... the third vision, too, of which there will certainly be fear. [To?] him, who has seen the fourth vision, belongs ...
... remembers. You know my dream, with it ... you have been called by me ...
... (When he had heard this, the king) like a ruler with all friendliness says to the queen: Thus shall it be, oh noble one. I will send out (hunters) ...
... After (the king) had gathered (the hunters), he says: Go then, skilled ones! The elephant, who has been seen by the queen in a dream, (does he exist or does he not (?)) ...
... When they had heard this, the old hunters say (to the king): Oh lord, these (locks (?)) of our hair ...
... ([but] never) we had heard: There is such an elephant. And how should we have seen [it]? ...
... (If) you bring the tusks of the (ele)phant, [it is] well. If (, however,) you do not bring [them], I will arrange for the (killing) [of you] all to the seventh lineage ...
... The queen thought: Never will there be (a hunter) who (finds (?)) the elephant without instruction ...
... After the queen thereupon had called the old hunters (together, she speaks to the one), who among them (was versed (?) in) the fivefold art of archery ...

line.tr: Ein ... Ding wird eben in Träumen nicht gesehen.
A ... thing is just not seen in dreams.

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6

line.tr: … the third image, for which there will certainly be fear. (cf 10)
So it will be, o noble one. I will send (hunters). (cf 11)
How should we have seen [it]? (cf 11)
(If) you bring me the tusks of the elephant, [it is] good. (But) if you do not bring [them], I will cause [your] (death) [and that of your] relatives up to the seventh [degree]. (cf 11)
... (wenn) ihr die Stoßzähne des Elefanten bringt, [ist es] gut. Wenn ihr [sie] (aber) nicht bringt, werde ich bis zum siebenten Geschlecht insgesamt [eure] (Tötung) veranlassen.
... (if) you bring the elephant's tusks, [it is] well. (But) if you do not bring [them], I will arrange for [your] (killing) entirely until the seventh generation.

translation.line: ... When [the Bodhisattva] saw this, he thought: Those shall not bring distress to the unlucky one. Immediately (he says), like an old father to [his] son, (to) the man:
... Distress is never [to be] for you from me. Rather, son, come straight to my heart. Kneel(?)/bow down(?)/huddle down(?) before my feet.
... the elephants should not bring you distress. Thereupon the Bodhisattva, having sheltered his heart-splitting, even murdering enemy (with) much (compassion)
(close to his body) – the elephants are gone, since he has sent them, with a trumpet blast (?), one by one to the other elephants [that were] very far away –
says to the man: take what you want to have. When he had heard this, the hunter, having been made glad by the sweet word of the Bodhisattva, began (to think to himself):
... (I) who am, compared to this good creature of animal-kind itself, in virtue (surpassed (?) ...
(He began to cry and) being asked by the Bodhisattva without resentment: "O son, why art thou weeping?", the man says: "O lord, I am struck." ...
(The Bodhisattva says:) Did I bring you distress by giving [you] protection? Or say, [was it] Subhadrā, not enduring my death, [that] has caused you to weep?
(having heard this,) with his eyes overfilled by tears [and] a halting voice, the hunter says: || In the Ṣ.-tune: || Oh lord of elephants,
(with the poisonous arrow) I have hit (you) in the middle of [your] breast. But by [your] arrow of virtue I, the unlucky one, have been hit in the middle of [my] heart by you. Well [again] becomes
... a wound in the body. But a wound which has been made out of the virtue of the ignorant ones spreads in the three bad conditions. 1. Even towards [your] enemy
(you did show) compassion. [Oh] ocean of virtue. Who is able to tell all your merits? In brief, however, I will say this:

line.tr: They must not bring distress onto the miserable one! (cf 13)
Nicht sollen diese [scil. die Elefanten] dem Unglücklichen Not bringen.
These [i.e. the elephants] shall not bring distress to the miserable one.

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6

line.tr: The elephants will bring you no distress.
(Er begann zu weinen, und vom Bodhisattva befra)gt: Warum weinst du, [mein] Sohn, ohne Veranlassung(?)?" spricht der Mann: "Oh Herr, ich bin erschlagen."
(He began to cry, and ask)ed (by the Bodhisattva): Why do you cry, [my] son, without reason?" the man says: "Oh Lord, I am slain."
Have I perhaps brought [you] harm in offering [you] protection? (cf 13)
Habe ich [dir] etwa Leid gebracht, indem ich [dir] Schutz gewährte?
Did I bring [you] suffering by granting [you] protection?
Aber eine Wunde, die durch Tugendhaftigkeit Unverständigen in den drei Geburtsklassen gemacht ist, bleibt bestehen [wtl. breitet sich aus].
But a wound, that was inflicted by virtue onto ignorant ones in the three incarnations, remains [lit. spreads].

translation.line: ... In a short time certainly (he will (?) ...) together with our sons ...
... (Thereupon) the 500 sons of the ministers (were ready (?) to go into the forest (?) together with) the Bodhisattva ...
... having come to the prince, he says: You shall have permission, oh prince. Leave (the house!) ...
... This you will certainly achieve. I did (not) have (the possibility), the distinctiveness, to see ...
... When you, led to death by the Caṇḍālas, went into the city, first of all you spoke the word[s] ...
... for (what) reason have you spoken this talk, which all beings here have heard? ...
... through the ... (?) of the world. 1. When he had heard this, the Bodhisattva (, surrounded with rays) a fathom [broad] (, says:) ...
... with the energy of a Bodhisattva, with a cheerful mind, with hands folded, to the king:
... when you gave me into the hands of the executioners [and] ordered them to kill, (I saw (?) the people of the city) ...
... of/to the king. The land is under the protection of the king. The land under the protection ...
... was there no one in this town, who asked: [Is] my death justified? 1. See, (oh lord) ...
... thereby I have found myself tied and (delivered) to the executioners ...

line.tr: Warum wohl behandeln sie die im Saṃvara Stehenden nicht mit Verehrung?
Why then do they not venerate the ones standing in the saṃvara?
Auf solche Weise ruft Indra zu der einen Zeit bei sich das Verlangen nach dem Mönchtum hervor.
In such a way, Indra, at one time, evokes in himself the desire for monkhood.

line.tr: … he will no longer fill [satisfy] me with love and praise.
... und an der Frau wird er hängen.
... and to the woman he will be attached.
Die Śākya-Prinzen gaben mit [ihrem] Harem alle [ihre] Geliebten auf.
With [their] harem, the Śākya princes gave up all [their] lovers.

line.tr: ... die zwei Frauen sind ... [herbei]zuführen.
... the two women are ... to be brought [here].
Daher stellten die (Minister) einen Wunsch frei.
Therefore the (ministers) granted a wish.
Sobald (die Sonne im) Schosse des Sumeru aufgeht, erleuchtet sie mit tausend Strahlen Jambudvīpa ...
As soon as (the sun) rises (in) the depth of Sumeru, with a thousand rays it illuminates Jambudvīpa ...

The fire of digestion, however, expires completely in this body.

when it [i.e. the food] is in the āmāśaya, moistened [and] blown on by water [and] wind ...

translation.line: ... I see who may not have died, or will not die. Therefore Nanda ... from death ...

line.tr: Er hob das Diadem auf [und] setzte [es] dem[seinem] ältesten Sohn aufs Haupt.
He picked up the diadem [and] set [it] upon the eldest son's head.
(4)000 Jahre hielt er im Walde am Sittengesetz fest.
[For] (4)000 years he adhered to the moral law in the forest.
Sie wurden alle des Sterbens überdrüssig, schoren [sich] den Kopf [und] (gingen) aus dem Hause [d.h. wurden Mönche].
They all grew weary of death, shaved [their] head[s] [and] (went) out of the house [i.e. became monks].
Warum zeigst du, Nanda, keine Furcht?
Why do you, Nanda, show no fear?
… I see who may not have died, or will not die. Therefore Nanda … from death …

translation.line: ... over fifty miles it [i.e., the Pārijāta-tree] smells lovely ...
... in order to evoke ...
... the heart is gladdened by happiness and joy ...
/// Near the city Sudarśana there is a great pond filled with divine water. Out from there grows [lit. has left] this tree. Therefore (it is called Pārijāta.)

line.tr: ... fünfzig Meilen [weit] riecht er [scil. der Pārijāta-Baum] lieblich.
... [over] fifty miles it [i.e. the pārijāta-tree] smells lovely.
Auf solche Weise schmückt er sich, um Göttern [und] Göttinnen immer neue Glücksgefühle hervorzurufen, innerhalb von vier Monaten (in) sieben (Zeitperioden).
In such a way it [i.e. the pārijāta-tree] adorns itself, [in order] to call forth ever new feelings of bliss in the gods [and] goddesses, within four months (in) seven (periods of time).
In der zweiten Zeit[periode] aber treibt er [scil. der Pārijāta-Baum] Blätter [und] Blüten.
In the second [period of] time, however, it [i.e. the Pārijāta tree] sprouts leaves and blossoms.
[Wenn] der [bzw. die]Blüten- ... entsteht, zu der Zeit wird das Herz (der) Gö(tter [und] Göttinnen) durch Glück [und] Freude erfreut.
[When] the blossom- ... emerges, at that time the heart (of the) go(ds [and] goddesses) is delighted with bliss [and] happiness.
In der fünften Zeit[periode] aber schmückt er sich mit Knospen(?).
In the fifth [period of] time, however, it adorns itself with buds.
... vierfach nennt man [wtl. nennen sie] seinen Namen, nämlich ...
fourfold they call his name, to wit ...

line.tr: In der 21. (Woche) entsteht im Körper das Blut. In der 22. Woche entsteht ihm [scil. dem Embryo] in den Knochen das Mark. In der 23. Woche entstehen ihm die Sehnen. In der 24. Woche entsteht ihm das Fleisch am Körper.

In the 21st (week), the blood develops in the body. In the 22nd week, the marrow develops in the bones for him [i.e. the embryo]. In the 23rd week, the sinews develop for him. In the 24th week, the flesh on [his] body develops for him.
... wird übelgesinnt [wtl. ruft sich üble Gesinnung hervor] [und] ist bedrückt.
.. becomes ill-minded [lit. calls forth an ill disposition in himself] [and] becomes gloomy.
who acts in an evil manner, he goes into the hells when he is [re]born …

translation.line: ... As at another time [when] there was a famine. The vultures ...
... Thereupon the water animals were pulled out [and] they gave them to the vultures as food.
Thereupon the turtles were tortured by hunger. They said to the vultures: «...»
... fearing falling ...

line.tr: Darauf wurden Wassertiere heraufgezogen, [und] sie gaben den śukrāṅga[-Vögeln] zu essen.
Thereupon water animals were pulled up, [and] they gave food to the śukrāṅga[-birds].
Darauf wurden die Schildkröten von Hunger gequält.
Thereupon the turtles were tormented by hunger.
... ständig vor dem Fallen sich fürchtend ...
... being always afraid of falling ...

line.tr: Auf solche Weise schmückt er sich, um Göttern [und] Göttinnen immer neue Glücksgefühle hervorzurufen, innerhalb von vier Monaten (in) sieben (Zeitperioden).
In such a way it [i.e. the pārijāta-tree] adorns itself, [in order] to call forth ever new feelings of bliss in the gods [and] goddesses, within four months (in) seven (periods of time).
[Wenn] der [bzw. die]Blüten- ... entsteht, zu der Zeit wird das Herz (der) Gö(tter [und] Göttinnen) durch Glück [und] Freude erfreut.
[When] the blossom- ... emerges, at that time the heart (of the) go(ds [and] goddesses) is delighted with bliss [and] happiness.

translation.line: whosever intention it is to put an end to the master
the separation from each other ...
Brahmā-god, giver of the life of knowledge
the separation of himself ... struck by old age
... || In the M.-tune: || I [am] decrepit by old age and no more able to walk in order to see the good teacher
... to whatever extent pupils can be brought to awareness by a teacher, (that) I have made you aware of ...
If you [pl.] (now leave me alone and) go to the Buddha, the teacher, in order to leave the house, with many indeed the question will arise: ...
When you [pl.] come close (to the Buddha, the teacher, sitting surrounded by a large crowd), then you [pl.] (must try to see) the thirty-(two marks) on his body.
flat all around like the front of a mirror
his heels slender. 4. Soft like silk ...

line.tr: Whosoever intends to put an end to the saṃsāra, the master. (cf 79)

line.tr: Wie vom Lehrer die Schüler zu unterrichten [sind], so habe ich euch unterrichtet.
Like the students [are] to be taught by the teacher, so I have taught you.
If you [pl.] now leave me alone and go to the Buddha, the teacher, in order to leave the house, with many indeed the question will arise: … (cf 83)
When you [pl.] come close to the Buddha, the teacher, sitting surrounded by a large crowd, then you [pl.] must try to see the thirty-(two marks) on his body. (cf 83)

translation.line: like those of the Aiṇeya king-of-wild animals (his) calves. 8. ...
(like a) banyan tree, of equal proportions, with his height equal (to its width)
each single lock of hair grown [and] turned toward the right
... 19. His shoulders are well formed. 20. ...
23. Very white his teeth. 24 ...
... 29. ‘[His] eye-lashes like [those] of a bull. 30. on his head an uṣṇīṣa. 31. a white bunch of hair [is] between his eyebrows.
... how old is he? How many Śāstras does he teach to the Brahmin youths? ...
... [if] he will decide firmly and without (leaving) an alternative ...
... each according to their respective training ...

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 a7 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6 b7

line.tr: If all these thirty-two signs are complete in their entirety on his body, then, standing in front of him, without a hint, and in your minds only, you [pl.] must ask him question[s] as follows: … (cf 91)
Wieviel Brahmanenknaben lehrt er die Śāstras?
To how many Brahmin youths does he teach the Śāstras?
If he also understands your [pl.] questioning immediately and without hesitation, then you [pl.] are indeed to recognise him surely as the (Tat)hāgata and the all-knowing Buddha. (cf 91)
He will know in his mind all that has been thought and will answer firmly without ambiguity (…). (cf 91)

When [lit. who] some of you [pl.] have asked the questions mentioned, then some [others] on their part, each according to his educational training, in connection with skills as …95, must ask him, one after the other, deep and difficult questions, quietly kept in your minds only. (cf 91, 93)

translation.line: nights have passed. (Not) one (single) night (did) I (sleep) so (well) ...
... (with) a pure ray
o Bādhari, you should know that!
... Where then is at this moment this venerable one? Bādhari (says),
«He is on Mount Pāṣāṇaka (in the lands of Magadha)». || ...
Māgharāja says: «O teacher, is it to believed that in such a Kaliyuga era, in a short (lifetime a Buddha will appear in the world?)»
... as I have heard it from the clever wise men of the past ...
because of his love for the miserable world ...
... far and near ...
(by day and) night, in the sky, (proceeding from the garments) of the gods, the Asuras, the Nāgas, and the Yakṣas, of the Kinnaras (and the Gandharvas)

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 a7 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6 b7

line.tr: The Buddha-god the teacher has appeared in the world, o Bādhari, you should know that!
Bādhari says, «He is on Mount Pāṣāṇaka in the lands of Magadha». (cf 69)
O teacher, is it to believed that in such a Kaliyuga era, in a short (lifetime a Buddha) will appear in the world? (69)
... aus Liebe zu der (elenden) Welt strebt er zum Ort der Buddhaschaft/wird der Ort der Buddhaschaft erstrebt..
... out of love for the (miserable) world, he aspires towards the place (of) Buddhahood/the place of Buddhahood is aspired to.
... vollständig ist der Sternenkreis sichtbar.
The circle of stars is entirely visible.

translation.line: for twelve years I gave alms, all my possessions have come to an end
... I do not have even a single gold piece ...
... I will make your great wishes come true ...
... On the seventh day, with sorrow and pain, I will split your head into seven parts. Pay attention, you shameless old man! ...
... Purṇabhadre says: (having seen) that the noble Metrak will leave his home in order to go to the Buddha-god the teacher

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 a7 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6 b7

line.tr: [I] do not [even] have five copper coins—how could I now give you five hundred gold pieces? (cf 45)
If you do not give me (the money), the rich man will surely have me shut up in prison again! (cf 45)
I do not have a single gold piece—how am I going to have five hundred?
If, however, you do not give it to me, …
If you give me (the money), then [it is] good [and] I will fulfil your great wishes! (cf 283; see also 45)
Wenn du [sie] mir gibst, [ist es] gut, [und] ich werde dir [deine] großen Wünsche erfüllen; wenn du [sie] mir aber nicht gibst, [dann] ...
If you give [them] to me [it is] good, [and] I will fulfil your great wishes; but if you do not give [them] to me, [then] ...
Within one week … of your mind … I will cause [lit. bring] your heart to break. On the seventh day, with sorrow and pain, I will split your head into seven parts. (cf 45, 47)

Make effort so that Bādhari the Brahmin of Dakṣiṇāpatha will fully understand the rising of the Buddha, the teacher, and that he [Bādhari] indeed in this (way) … (so that) the (noble) Maitreya will immediately come to the Buddha, the teacher. (cf 51)

translation.line: ... The Buddha has consented to teach the good Law to the world ...
... He [i.e., the Buddha] has consented
to teach the good Law [and] within a short time he will promote immortality for gods and humans. 8. ... to whom do I first teach the fine
deep, good, Law? ... the compassionate one saw Ārāḍa, dead for seven days, having passed over [and] taken birth elsewhere ...
... he left from Urubilvā, headed for Benares ...
... his head is rounded like a parasol, his hair is thick and blue ... with the wheel of the face ...
with thick eye-lashes ... his teeth are of equal size like a string of pearls
a wheel in [each of] his palms and webs between all his fingers ... he walks high above in the air space ...
... no other wandering monk like you ... Udumbara tree
... pure is the appearance of the face ... to whom have gone, leaving the house? Whose law do you approve?
... by knowing for myself, whom should I refer to (as my teacher) ...

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 a7 a8 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6 b7 b8

line.tr: Höret, [ihr] Wesen! Rufet alle Sehnsucht hervor, (denn) der Alleswissende [ist] als Sonne in dem herrlichen [wtl. glänzenden] Magadha-Lande aufgegangen.
Hear, [ye] beings! Call forth longing, all [of you], (for) the Omniscient [has] arisen as a sun in the splendid Magadha-country.
He [the Buddha] has agreed to teach the good law. Before long he will grant gods and men the immortality [medicine of the law].
Er [scil. der Buddha] hat eingewilligt, das gute Gesetz zu lehren, in nicht langer Zeit wird er Göttern [und] Menschen die Unsterblichkeit wachsen lassen.
He [i.e. the Buddha] has consented to teach the good law, in not [so] long a time he will let immortality grow [for/in] gods [and] humans.
The omniscient thought, «Whom do I first teach the fine, deep [and] good law?»
«To them I will teach the good law!», [and] he set out from Urubilvā towards Benares.
... geht er [scil. der Buddha] hoch in den Luftraum, denn es schmückt seine [Fuß]spur den Scheitel der Erde (?).
... he [i.e. the Buddha] goes high up into the airspace, for his [foot]prints adorn the crown of the earth's head (?).
Zu wem bist du aus dem Hause gegangen? Wessen Lehre [wtl. Gesetz] erkennst du an?
To whom did you go out of the house? Whose law do you accept?

translation.line: ... he uttered the sixth stanza, the merciful: I am going to Benares and I will beat the drum of immortality;
(I will turn the wheel of the law) that has (not) been turned (in the world before).
I will now state the sense of the strophes as far as my memory goes.
... including the animals, including the unborn ones ...
If a breath comes from my mouth, up to the gods, they give up their negligence ...
There is no movement, no word or thought of mine, [not] even within the measure of the smallest moment, which would not be for the happiness of others.
... in my own palm ...

line.n: a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 a7 a8 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6 b7 b8

line.tr: I am going to Benares and I will beat the drum of immortality; (I will turn the wheel of the law) that has (not) been turned (in the world before).
I will now state the sense of the strophes as far as my memory goes. (cf 172)
In drei Asaṃkhyeyas [und] hundert Kalpas habe ich [in Gestalt von] Gabe[n], Sittlichkeit, Kräften [und] Kenntnissen endlose Verdienst(e) gesammelt.
In three asaṃkhyeyas [and] a hundred kalpas I have gathered, [in the form of] gift[s], moral, powers [and] knowledge, endless merit(s).
If a breath comes from my mouth, up to the gods, they give up their negligence … (cf 172–173)
There is no movement, no word or thought of mine, [not] even within the measure of the smallest moment, which would not be for the happiness of others.
In allen drei Weltregionen und von allen Lebewesen alles, Geburt, Sinne [und] Schönheiten, sehe ich wie einen Gegenstand in meiner Handfläche.
In all three regions of the earth and of all living beings, I see all, birth, senses, beauties, like in object in the palm of my hand.

translation.line: ... the ignorance has covered my eyes ...
... by the root of virtue. 69. ...
... by smearing of the blood of the belly ...
... through blood and sperma of the belly ...
... The fourfold truths they will know through the teaching; thus they will leave the house for the law of the noble Buddha Maitreya.
... there is, at this moment, a second, large group of disciples. 77

line.tr: Beabsichtigtest du nicht, die Welt leidlos werden zu lassen?
Did you not intend to make the world become free of suffering?
The fourfold truths they will know through the teaching; thus they will leave the house for the law of the noble Buddha Maitreya. (cf 491)
Welche Wesen auf den Pratyekabuddha Aṅgada ... Samen streuten [und] sich aus dem Grunde Verdienste erwarben ...
Which[ever] beings strewed the seed onto the Pratyekabuddha Aṅgada .... [and] obtained merits for this reason ...

Having killed his father and having behaved perversely toward the Buddha, he made a confession... (säm) (kākoräṣ) , (ṣñi) (pācä)r ; kenpar spārttu , pät(t)āṃñktaṃ :

line.tr: Und nicht wurden ihnen die Baumfrüchte zur [rechten] Zeit reif [und] kamen nicht zustande.
And the fruit of the trees did not ripen [for] them at the [right] time and did not come into being.
Zahllos machte der Buddha Anstrengung, die[se] Wesen zur Entsagung zu bringen, in langer Zeit (in) [jedem] einzelnen (Augenblick). [Aber] sie entsagten eben (nicht).
The Buddha made attempts without number to bring the beings to renouncement, in a long time (in) [every] single (moment). [But] they did (not) renounce.
Mit großer Mühe [und] Anstrengung zog ihn der Buddha aus dem Hause. [Da] er [sein] Denken an eine Frau gehängt [hatte], duldete er [es nämlich] nicht, zu entsagen.
With great effort [and] exertion the Buddha pulled him out of the house. [Since] he [had] attached [his] thinking to a woman, he [could] not bear [it] to renounce [her].
Alsdann führte er [scil. der Buddha] (ihn zu den Göttern). [Aber erst] als er ihn von da in die Hölle führte, entsagte er.
Thereupon he [i.e. the Buddha] led (him to the gods). [But it was only] when he led him from thence into hell [that] he abjured.
Dem Pfahle vergleichbar hielt er zwölf Jahre [lang] (am Sittengesetz) fest.
Akin to a stake he adhered (to the moral law) [for] twelve years.
Er [scil. Devadatta] ging vom Gesetzeswandel ab und bemühte sich, den Buddha zu töten. Er beging (die [fünf] Todsünden), [und] er (fiel) in die Avīci-Hölle.
He [i.e. Devadatta] left the conduct of the law and strove to kill the Buddha. He committed (the [five] deadly sins), [and] he (fell) into the Avīci-hell.

Er [scil. Gokālika] (legte) Tadel [und] üble Nachrede zugleich auf Śāriputra als auch auf Maudgalyāyana. Gott Brahman selbst hielt ihn zurück. Auch der Meister, der Buddha, (hielt ihn) noch dreimal zurück. [Aber] er duldete [es] (nicht), davon abzulassen, [und] fiel in die Mahāpadma[-Hölle].

He [i.e. Gokālika] (put) censure [and] slander at the same time on Śāriputra and also on Maudgalyāyana. The god Brahman himself held him back. The master, the Buddha, also (held him) back three times more. [But] he [could] (not) tolerate to forbear [and] fell into the Mahāpadma [hell].
Er [scil. Sunakṣatra] beabsichtigte nun, seine Mutter zu töten ... Er beabsichtigte nun, den Buddha zu töten.
He [i.e. Sunakṣatra] now intended to kill his mother ... He now intended to kill the Buddha.

line.tr: Welche Menschen da die Wälder verbrennen ...
Whichever humans are burning the forests...
In der Raurava-Hölle werden die wesen sicherlich [wieder-]geboren werden, wenn sie nicht von dort umkehren.
The beings will certainly be [re-]born in the Raurava-hell, if they do not turn back from there.
He will not drive off the causes if he does not protect himself against evil. (cf 306)
... wenn er sich nicht vor dem Bösen hütet.
... if he does not beware of evil.
Die Ursachen wird er nicht beseitigen, wenn er sich von dem Bösen nicht hütet.
The causes he will not eliminate, if he does not beware of evil.
they will have obtained pleasure …, and they will have driven off the seed of greed from their mind[s], ashamed and abashed they … the evil ones …
And what if they do evil according to the [spirit of] the times (cf 342)
[Wenn] sie ... aber Böses (tun), [so] tun sie [es] mit Furcht, empfinden Reue [und] bekunden sie auch.
[If] they ... to evil, however, they do [so] with fear, feel remorse [and] express it as well.
(Wenn sich) die Buddhas in der Welt (erheben), kommen sie [scil. die Wesen] sicherlich mit ihnen zusammen [und] werden alsdann erlöst.
(When) the Buddhas arise in the world, they [i.e. the beings] will certainly meet with them [and] will then be redeemed.

translation.line: Very difficult was such a kāvya composition...
... when he does not keep the tune, the meaning … If he does not say kind [things], the listeners do not approve.
... I have tried to keep the sense
In this, may there not be destruction of the good law by me.
... you should make that poem ...
I, oh great king, have again put together the Kāvya, as far as my competence went, in accordance with the meter and tune
Where I may not have gotten the sense, ... ... patience may be for me, like a mother has patience with her little son ...
having taught the Law /// ...
... power will be gained; the evil power of the Kleśas will go down. 63.

line.tr: If he does not say kind [things], the listeners do not approve. (cf 134)
[Wenn] er ... das Metrum nicht bewahrt, die Bedeutung(en) ... bzw. [Wenn] ... das Metrum nicht bewahrt wird, die Bedeutung(en) ...
[If] he ... does not keep [up] the metre, the meaning ... OR [If] ... the metre is not kept [up], the meaning ...
Ich habe mich bemüht, den Sinn zu bewahren, aber die Worte haben sich mir vielfach vertauscht/sind von mir vielfach vertauscht ]d.h. nicht richtig getroffen] worden.
I have strived to retain the meaning, but the words have frequently changed on me/have been frequently changed by me [i.e. I got stuck for the right word].
In this, may there not be destruction of the good law by me. (cf 134)
Ich machte demzufolge, aber (die Zuversicht) schwand mir, ich konnte nicht.
I did accordingly, but (confidence) failed me, I could not.
Where I may not have gotten the sense, …

translation.line: ... and for them at harvest time the tree did not ripen or yield / and for them the canes did not ripen at the [right] time
(after)wards (he) l(e)d ...
... the god Brahman himself kept him away ...

line.tr: Und nicht wurden ihnen die Baumfrüchte zur [rechten] Zeit reif [und] kamen nicht zustande.
And the fruit of the trees did not ripen [for] them at the [right] time and did not come into being.
Zahllos machte der Buddha Anstrengung, die[se] Wesen zur Entsagung zu bringen, in langer Zeit (in) [jedem] einzelnen (Augenblick). [Aber] sie entsagten eben (nicht).
The Buddha made attempts without number to bring the beings to renouncement, in a long time (in) [every] single (moment). [But] they did (not) renounce.
Mit großer Mühe [und] Anstrengung zog ihn der Buddha aus dem Hause. [Da] er [sein] Denken an eine Frau gehängt [hatte], duldete er [es nämlich] nicht, zu entsagen.
With great effort [and] exertion the Buddha pulled him out of the house. [Since] he [had] attached [his] thinking to a woman, he [could] not bear [it] to renounce [her].
Alsdann führte er [scil. der Buddha] (ihn zu den Göttern). [Aber erst] als er ihn von da in die Hölle führte, entsagte er.
Thereupon he [i.e. the Buddha] led (him to the gods). [But it was only] when he led him from thence into hell [that] he abjured.

translation.line: ... I honor you leading the caravan unsurpassed ...
/// (18) your soul is pervaded by emptiness; you have rejected every merit and sin ...
the somnifacient for the brahmins, named [wrong] imagination, has been cut off ...

line.tr: (Abgeschnitten worden) [ist] das Schlafmittel der (Bra)hmanen namens [falsche] Vorstellung. Eben dadurch [ist] von dir zerspalten worden (jegliche) Hinderung des Verstandes. ... in allem [bzw. in allen ... ] wirst du nicht gehemmt.

The sleeping draught of the (bra)hmins called [false] notion [has] (been cut off). Exactly therefore, (any) hindrance of the mind [has] been cloven apart by you ... in all [or: in all ...] you are not hindered.

prose.s:
Having heard that, the cakravartin-king Śaṅkha with his seven jewels and with all the kings of Jambudvīpa takes the venerable Maitreya as teacher. täm kaklyuṣuräṣ śaṅkh(e) cakkravartti wäl ṣpät ñemintwaśśäl puk śkaṃ jambudvipṣinäs lāñcsa
(śśäl) āṣānikāṃ metrakaṃ käṣṣiṃ eṃtsäṣtär
From then on he comes to see the venerable Maitreya every day; tmäṣṣ aci koṃ koṃ āṣānikāṃ metrakäṃ lkātsi kumnäṣ

he listens to his Law with all heart and soul. cami märkampal puk āñmaṣ käryāṣ klyo
(snäṣ)
And he behaves according to it. tmā särki śkaṃ spārtwlune yatär
Therefore, there is an increase of all virtues for him along with the kingdom. || täm ṣurmaṣ śla ypeyis puk kāswonentwāśśi tsmālune mäskatr-äṃ ||
All have left. || lcär poñś ||

In the Maitreyasamiti-nāṭaka, the eleventh act with the name (Guru)darśana ["Appearance of the Teacher"] has come to an end. || maitreyasamiti nā
(ṭkaṃ) (guru)darśaṃ ñomā śäkṣapint nipātt ār ||

|| Thereupon, at another time, the bodhisattva Maitreya, having descended from his jewel palace together with a large entourage, like the divine king [descends] from his sky palace, with vehicles adorned with jewels, adorning, as it were, the whole world with his splendor, he leaves the city of Ketumatī on the golden road, through the eastern gate. || tmäṣ ālyäkyāṃ praṣtaṃ metrak bodhisattu ñäkci wäl täpräṃ wimānäṣṣ oki tsoptsāṃ wartsyaśśäl ñemi

line.tr: Even if all beings in the world were Brahmā gods, all these are worthy to bow with the crown of their head at his feet.
Als er das gehört hatte, nimmt sich der Cakravartin-König Śaṅkha mit den sieben Kleinodien und (mit) allen Königen von Jambudvīpa den würdigen Maitreya zum Lehrer.
When he had heard this, the Cakravartin king Śaṅkha, with the seven jewels and (with) all kings of Jambudvīpa, takes the worthy Maitreya as a teacher for him[self].

Von da an kommt er [scil. der Cakravarti-König Śaṅkha] Tag für Tag, den würdigen Maitreya zu sehen, (er) hört von ihm das Gesetz aus ganzer Seele [und] mit [gutem] Willen und richtet dementsprechend seinen Wandel ein.

From that on, he [i.e. the Cakravartin king Śaṅkha] comes day by day to see the worthy Maitreya, (he) hears the law from him with all his soul [and] with [a good] will and orientates the change [in him] accordingly.
Sieh, Bruder, diese Besonderheit [seines] Glanzes!
See, brother, this peculiarity of [his] splendour!
Der Cintāmaṇi-Sonnenschirm dreht sich über seinem Kopfe.
The cintāmaṇi sunshade turns above his head.
Edle Rosse ziehen seinen [scil. Maitreyas] goldenen Wagen, der gleichsam zu schweben scheint.
Noble steeds pull his [i.e. Maitreya's] golden chariot, which seems to float [in the air], as it were.
In den Palästen und Triśālas [Häuser mit drei Hallen], hoch [oben] in den Fenstern, fallen die geschmückten Frauen gleichsam nach unten.
In the palaces and triśālas [houses with three halls], high [up] in the windows, the adorned women fell down, as it were.
Alle Tugenden haben sich [sind] in dir vollständig versammelt.
All virtues have entirely gathered in you.

Einige preisen [ihn mit den Worten]: "Alle Tugenden sind in dir vollständig versammelt, alle guten Dinge sind gerade bei dir [wtl. von dir her] offenbar". Einige preisen die Gattin des Bodhisattva [mit den Worten]: "Du hast fürwahr {?eifrig} gutes verdienstvolles Werk getan, das dir d[oes]en Geliebten gegeben hat."

"Some praise [him, saying]: "All virtues are entirely gathered in you; especially in you [lit. from you], all good things are manifest". Some praise the spouse of the Bodhisattva [saying]: "You have certainly done good work, full of merit, which has given you [this] lover."
Die Straße bebt unter der Menge der Wesen.
The road shakes with the number of beings.

MaitrSiŋgim, Taf. 38

This fragment contains the end of the eleventh and the beginning of the twelfth act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; the colophon of act XI is to be found in lines a5-6, the twelfth act begins in line a6. An Uy. parallel is MaitrSiŋgim, Taf. 38 (), where Taf. 38 r. 26f = line a1 here, and Taf. 38 v. 22-29 contains the colophon (= lines a5-6 here) . See also .
Fragment of a manuscript which includes A 251 - A 294 (cf. ).
There are roughly 25 akṣaras missing (cf. ). Inside the lacuna one can make out the lower part of two ligatures, the second one containing <k>.

The oblique form (as opposed to the nominative ) is unexpected, especially since the containing relative clause is coordinated with another relative clause containing . However, the reading is certain.

The segmentation cem mā =ṣāṃ makes better sense in this context. This was misunderstood by the Uyghur translator, who did not recognize the negation and read cemm āṣāṃ. (cf. ). The Turkic form used as the equivalent of [[āṣāṃ]], i.e. tägim (38 v 9), is a hapax. The expected form is tägimlig.

to me releasing a voice. (In the) Hells ...
/// (nā)ntsuṣ nṣac wak tärnāmāṃ : ñar(eyäṃtwaṃ) ///
... to let the beings, that are attached (to the Kleśas), feel [world-]weariness, (a mirage). (ta)träṅkuñcäs wrasas mroskäṣlis mos(aṃ)
(This was) the city Ketumatī, houses, streets, beings and the achievements of the beings. (tāk) k(e)tuma(ti) r(i) waṣtu ṣontañ wrasañ wrasaśśi yātluneyntu •

So as (here there are cities, houses, streets, beings and) the achievements (of the beings), just so the venerable Maitreya, the Buddha-god, (by his supernatural power let appear) other cities, houses, streets, beings and achievements of the beings. mä(nt) (ne) (tṣaṃ) (riñ) (waṣtu)
(ṣontañ) (wrasañ) (wrasaśśi) yātluneyntu mäskanträ • tämnek ālkontäk āṣānik metrak ptāñkät ris waṣtu ṣontas wrasas wrasaśśi yātluneyntu rä(ddhiyo) (pā)
(kär) (yāmäs) (•)

Having seen this, the beings of Maitreya, these other exchanged beings in all their achievements resembling themselves one by one, are amazed by this manifestation, (and) they say: (täm) (pälkoräṣ) (me)trakṣiñi wrasañ cesäm ālykes-äk mamäskuñcäs wrasas puk yātlunentuyo ṣñi ṣñi āñmaśśäl tāskmāṃ pā(kär) (yāmlu)
(neyo) (añumāski) (nāntsu)ṣ träṅkiñc
|| In the Kutsmāt-tune: || || kutsmātaṃ ||

pada.s: Oh what happiness! ote täpreṃ suk ;
Oh what dignity! ote täpreṃ , kärparäṃ :
With [their] capability [having increased], even the[se] people grow. tspont yātluneyo ; śamantarr ats , napeñi :

(These very beings are to us) doubly venerable persons. wäṣt ā(ṣā)
(nikāñ) ; (ceṣ-äk) (wrasañ) , (wasäṃ) (neñc) (:)
Hey, you good ones, enjoy without concern the delights of mortal beings! (yśe) kraṃś sne kärye ; purpāc skuntu , napeṃṣās :

prose.s:
Then, these beings of Maitreya, with increased pleasure, with increased achievement (by enjoying) increased delights having become joyful beyond measure, men and women, big and small, went (together) with the powerful, highly capable, fashioned beings in the[ir] fashioned cities, houses, streets (in countless numbers). tmäṣ cem metrakṣiñi wrasañ tsmont kāckeyo tsmont yātluneyo tsmont skuntu (wä)
(rpāluneyo) (nermi)tṣinās risaṃ waṣtwaṃ ṣontsaṃ yātälwātses tsopats-tampes nermitṣinäs wrassaśśäl ātli kUlewāñ tsopats mkälto lyutār memaṣ kātkmāṃ (nā)
(ntsuṣ) (sne) (kaś) (ṣiyak) (kalka)r«†ä»
|| In the Phulleṃ-tune: || || pullenaṃ ||

pada.s: By nature the Maitreya people are feeble companions. ṣäññā ylāre , olariñ ; metrakṣiñi , mäskanträ :
They make friends with them [i.e. the fashioned beings], ypanträ cesmaṃ , ortune ;
[they are] very happy [and] rejoice. ṣokyo skassuṣ , plantanträ :

(They receive) homages for the festivity ... yärkant opṣl(y)a(c) ,
(wärpnāntär) ; /// (:)
These call those hither ceṣ kenanträ , cesäm ṣu ;
and those call these hither. cem nu cesäs , kenanträ :

prose.s: Then suddenly fires appear from the fashioned cities. tmäṣ ātukek nirmitṣinās risäṣ poräṃ pākär mäskanträ

The jewel-cities, the jewel-(houses the jewel-streets), with [all] possessions and achievements shrouded in flames, burn one and all as in the Raurava-hell. || ñemiṣināñ riñ ñemiṣin(āñ)
(waṣtu) (ñemiṣiñi) (ṣontañ) śla niṣpal yātluneyaśśäl raurāp ñareyaṃ oki slamasyo wäntoṣ pUkāk sälpiñc ||

Having seen this the Maitreya people (have become woeful) beyond all measure; pointing out [the inhabitants] being in the jewel-cities, in the jewel-balconies, palaces, and towers, they say: täm pälkoräṣ metrakṣiñi wrasañ lyutār me
(maṣ) (klopasuṣ) (nāntsuṣ) (tosäm) ñemiṣinās risaṃ ñemiṣinäs skāksaṃ ṣtāṅksaṃ kuccatāksaṃ kälymāṃ nirmitṣinās ris ṣärpäsmāṃ träṅkiñc

Fie on the malicious (threefold Saṃsāra)! hīśt tākiṣ omäsken(ā)
(p) (traidhātuk) (saṃsāris)
|| In the Ṣeraśi Niṣkramānt tune: || (||) ṣeraśi-niṣkramāntaṃ ||

pada.s: Just like the eight hells together with [their] beings, shrouded by flame, glowed [and] burned, just so these miserable beings, (father and mother, son and daughter) are burned, okät ñareyntu ; mät ne śla wrasas ; slamyo wäntoṣ , sälypār tskäṃṣānt ; tämne tāloṣ , ceṣ wrasañ (:)
(pācar) (mācar) (se) ; (ckācar) tskäṃsanträ ;
lovers clinging together, couple after couple, are burned surrounded by flames; kāpñeñ kāpñeñ , yäksoṣ kaśal ; slamyo wäntoṣ ; tskäṃsanträ :
Abandon, you good ones, the delights, ptärkäs kraṃś skuntu ;
give you up all births, prisāc puk cmolu ;
leave from home, pälcäs waṣtäṣ ,
withdraw from this whole three-fold world, from the Saṃsāra! pälycäs poñcäṃ ; traidhātuk caṣ , saṃsāräṣ :

prose.s:
Then the venerable Maitreya, (the Buddha-god,) proclaims (to these beings) the Law of Emptiness [śūnyatā], whereby these (beings), that have become overly world-weary, having left from home by [the] hundreds, thousands, ten thousands, myriads, towards Maitreya, the Buddha-god, ... [they] obtain the (Srotāpanna) dignity. || tmäṣ āṣā(n)ik me(trak)
(ptāñkät) (cesäs) (wrasaśśi) (śū)nyātṣi märkampal āksiṣ kucyo ne cem ly(u)tār mām(r)oskuṣ käntantuyo wältsantuyo tmānantuyo korisyo waṣtäṣ lanturä(ṣ) (metrakäṃ) (ptāñäktac)
(srotāpattune) (paräṃ) kälpnānträ • ||
Then the king Siṃha, ... having become woeful beyond all measure, (thinks) to himself: tmäṣ siṃhe wä(l) /// l(yutā)r (m)emaṣ (kl)opas(u) nāṃtsu āñmaślä(kk) (ats) (pältsäṅkāṣ)

(Oh what) (ote) (tä)
(preṃ)

line.tr: (He,) [ihr] Guten! Genießet ohne Sorge die irdischen Glücksgüter!
([You] good ones! Enjoy the earthly blessings without worry!
Sie schließen mit ihnen [wtl. zu ihnen] Freundschaft, [sind] sehr glücklich [und] freuen sich.
They make friends with [lit. to] them, [are] very happy [and] are pleased.
Diese rufen jene herbei, jene aber rufen diese.
These call for those, but those call these.

Wie [da eben] die acht Höllen mit [ihren] Wesen, von der Flamme eingehüllt, glühten [und] brannten, so verbrennen [bzw. werden verbrannt] diese unglücklichen Wesen ... verbrennen [bzw. werden verbrannt], von der Flamme eingehüllt, alle Lieben, sich zusammen umklammernd. Im ganzen Saṃsāra wird nicht [mehr?] Geburt verlangt, nicht ...

Just like the eight hells with [their] beings, wrapped in flame, glowed [and] burned, so burn [are being burned] these unhappy beings ... burn [are being burnt], wrapped in flame, all dear ones, clutching at teach other together. In the whole Saṃsāra, birth is not desired [any longer?], not ...

The heart of many beings will break apart because of the separation from me, māk wrasaśśi nṣäṣ śraluneyā āriñc wākaṣ
hot blood will go to their throat. omäl ysār ṣuṅkac kalkaṣ

Why should I not, for three months, teach the Law that sees [the causes of the world], after having rejected the efforts pertaining to [long] life? kUyal mā näṣ tre mañsā
(śolṣinäs) (skeyas) (tärkoräṣ) pälkont märkampal ākṣiññim ||

Thereupon, The Buddha-god, Maitreya, after having rejected the efforts pertaining to [long] life, with resolve, he held on to living for three months. || (tmäṣ) (metrak) (ptāñkät) (śo)l(ṣ)inä(s) skeyas tärkoräṣ tre mañsā śolune adhiṣtitā etsäṣtär

(dattenaṃ) (||)
(At this moment, the earth trembles,) (tām) (praṣtaṃ) (tkaṃ) (meṣ) ;
the directions are burning, kälymeṃ tskäṃsanträ ;
(the shooting stars) are raining [down], swiñc
the terrifying drums (are roaring), (nuseñc) (ku)m(c)i , śurām(ṣ)iñi ;
the drum of the spirits is heard, kāl(ta)ṅk klyoṣtär , bhutāśśi ;

the ... of the Yakṣas ... murkcnā ya
(kṣāśśi) ,

line.tr: Als die Lebens[dauer] der wesen 30 000 Jahre war, war der (Buddha) namens Kanakamuni. Auch er, der Alleswissende, hat 8000jährig die Buddhaschaft erlangt.
When the life of the beings was [= lasted for] 30.000 years, there was a Buddha named Kanakamuni. He, too, the Omniscient, obtained the rank of Buddha at [the age of] 8000 years.

Als die Lebensdauer der Wesen 120 Jahre war (wtl. bei einem Leben der Wesen 120 Jahre [lang]), war der Buddha namens Śākyamuni. Auch er, der Mitleidige, hat 35jährig (die Buddhaschaft) erlangt. 45 Jahre hat er die Buddhaschaft ausgeübt [und] ist, 40 Jahre Leben übriggelassen habend, ins Nirvāṇa eingegangen.

When the lifespan of the beings was 120 years (lit. with a life of the beings 120 years [long]), [there] was a Buddha named Śākyamuni. He, too, the compassionate one, attained (Buddhahood) at the age of 35. For 45 years he practiced the Buddhahood [and] having left [over/behind] 40 years of life, he went into the nirvāṇa.

(1) (Wenn) ich (heute) ins Nirvāṇa eingehe, von wem wird [dann meine] Rückkehr erlangt [d.h. von niemandem wird dann meine Rückkehr erlangt]? Vielen Wesen wird durch die Trennung von mir das Herz brechen [und] heißes Blut zum Munde strömen [wtl. zur Mundhöhle gehen]. ODER (2) (Wenn) ich (heute) ins Nirvāṇa eingehe - für wen gibt es [da] eine Wiederkehr [d.h. für niemanden gibt es [da] eine Wiederkehr]? -, wird vielen Wesen durch die Trennung von mir das Herz brechen [und] heißes Blut zum Munde strömen.

(1) (If) I go to the nirvāṇa (today), by whom then will my return be effected? [i.e. nobody will effect my return]? The heart of many beings will break because of [their] separation from me [and] hot blood will flow [lit. go] to the mouth. OR (2) (If) I go to the nirvāṇa (today) - for whom is [there] a return [i.e. [there] is a return for nobody]? -, the heart of many beings will break because of the separation from ne [and] hot blood will flow to the mouth.

Thereupon this king Siṃha, son of the Cakravartin king Śaṅkha, anoints [his] eldest son Udrāyaṇa as king. tmäṣ säm śaṅkhe cakkravarttis lānt se siṃhe wä(l) (udrā)

Thereupon the king Siṃha, together with 84,000 excellent beings, like the heavenly king, (receiving) ovations [and] blessings from countless creatures, moves out from the city (Ketumatī). tmäṣ säm siṃhe wäl okät-tmāṃ śtwar-wälts śpāluñcäs wrassaśśäl ñäkci wäll oki sne yärm wrassäṣ yärkant maṅkalänt(u) w(ärpnāmāṃ) (ketuma)

Where the Samantapuṣpa-monastery is, there he goes. äntanne ne samantapuṣp saṅkrām tämne yäṣ

Having arrived in the monastery, he sees the venerable Buddha Maitreya, adorned with [his] ornaments and Lakṣaṇas (on his splendid body). Being amazed he says: saṅkrāmaṃ kakmuräṣ āṣānikāṃ metrakäṃ ptāñkät yetwes lakṣaṇäsyo kaknunt (parnontsāṃ) (kapśiññā) (pä)

pada.s: It [i.e. the Buddha's body] lets it rain loveliness, swāsäṣ ciñcrone ;
it produces brightness in thought. tämnäṣ pälskaṃ , parnore :
It makes joy and delight grow, tsmäṣ kācke plānto ;
drives away suffering and sorrow from the mind. wikäṣ pältskäṣ , klop śurām :

adorns [and] embellishes the own (self), ytäṣtär wamträ , ṣñi (āñcäm) (:)

line.tr: Die durch [Erb]folge [auf dich] gekommene Erde nimm entgegen, um [sie] zu beherrschen, [mein] Sohn! Die von den Ahnen [und] Vätern aufgestellte Regel, die überschreite nicht! Bewahre die Sittenvorschrift, gib Gabe[n und] vollziehe Opfer! Bezeuge den Guten Verehrung [und] strafe die Pflichtvergessenen!

Accept the earth [that has] come to you by heritage to rule [it], [my] son! The rule, established by [your] sires [and] fathers, do not transgress it! Keep the moral rule, give gift[s and] perform sacrifices! Express [your] reverence towards the good ones [and] punish the undutiful ones!
Don't break the rule established by ancestors and fathers!

Just as if thousand suns, as if thousand moons provided (with) … had arisen in one row, as if a mass of millions of lightnings were standing in one row on the earth, as if there were an upper apartment of fully glowing jewels, as if there were a … Pārijāta tree, as if there were a mountain of Jāmbūnada gold, adorned with cintāmaṇi jewels, also adorned with glowing rays, [and] with pleasure and dignity— so [is] the (Buddha rank) body of the (Buddha) Maitreya. (cf 53, 56)

Er [scil. der buddhaschaftliche Körper] lässt Schönheit regnen, er erzeugt im Geiste Glanz, er lässt Sehnsucht [und] Freude wachsen, er vertreibt Schmerz [und] Kummer aus dem Gemüt, er vernichtet die Glanzlosigkeit, er schmückt [und] ziert (das) eigene (Selbst) [= einen].

It [i.e. the body in Buddhahood] lets beauty rain [down], it creates splendour in the mind, it lets grow joy [and] longing, it expels pain [and] grief from the spirit, it destroys dullness, it adorns and decorates (the) own (self) [= oneself].
Auf der Gesichtsscheibe dieses Buddha Maitreya werden auch die früher aufgestandenen Buddhas, mit den 32 L(akṣaṇas geschmückt [und]) geziert, deutlich gesehen.
On the disc of the face of this Buddha Maitreya, also the Buddhas that have arisen before, (decorated [and]) adorned with the 32 L(akṣaṇas), are clearly seen.

This almost complete leaf belongs to the same manuscript as , which it immediately follows. The manuscript as a whole includes A 251 - A 294 (cf. ).
There is a gap of about 25 syllables in the middle of this line (); the tune Citraśoka has a strophe 4x17 syllables, rhythm 6/6/5 ().
The tune Hariṇapluta has a strophe of 4x12 syllables, rhythm 5/7 ().
The tune Kutsmāt has a strophe of 4x12 syllables, rhythm 5/7 ().
The Buddha-name, probably consisting of 2-3 akṣara, at the end of this line is destroyed ().
For the identification of the names of the Buddhas, cf. . See also the discussion in .

The Old Turkic parallel is edited in (text) and 352-355 (translation).
The meter is most probably 4x17 (6/6/5).

The restitution of the absolutive form ṣikoräṣ is admittedly uncertain. The phrase ṣikās ṣikoräṣ would match the figura etymologica [[ṣikonta]] attested in TB (e.g. in b6). A preterite stem of class I would complement the subjunctive V attested in TB (cf. ). The restoration proposed in Siegling's personal copy of p. 133
does not complete the colon.
The expression [[wraṣi]] is a calque of the Sanskrit compound udakakṛtya, which occurs in the parallel episode in the Mahāvadānasūtra (Vorgang 5e).
The form preceding [[pyāpyās|pyā(py)ā(s)]] is most probably a verb form with a 3sg suffixed pronoun. One possibility would be to correct and restore swāsästr-äṃ "s/he lets rain".

read . However, the nominative singular is incompatible with the Old Turkic parallel, in which the Purohita Brahmāyu lays his head at the feet of the Bodhisattva (bodiswt adaqınga 12a 6-7, cf. the translation in ). The Old Turkic version uses an uninflected form (bodiswt), rather than a genitive, which may indicate the use of a possessive adjective in the Tocharian original.

MaitrSiŋgim, Taf. 185, 88; MaitrHami 27, 1r

This fragment contains the end of the twenty-sixth and the beginning of the twenty-seventh act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; the colophon of act 26 is in line b3. Uy. parallels are MaitrSiŋgim, Leaf 13 = Taf. 88v (for A 258r), and Taf. 185r f. () for the end of act XXVI (= MaitrHami 26, Blatt 13v), as well as MaitrHami 27, Blatt 8, 1r for the beginning of act 27. See and .

The Udānavarga verses (Uv IV.37-38) in lines a4-5 are also to be found in b5-6, and are parallel to MaitrSiŋgim Taf. 88 v.1-17. King Simha's future Buddha-hood is prophesied in line 8a here, as in MaitrSiŋgim Blatt 14.

In the TA text here, there is a gap of 4+12 syllables at the beginning of line 8a, containing the end of pāda a, and pāda b of this strophe; there is another gap in b5, which must contain the name of a tune, most likely a strophe of 4x12 syllables, rhythm 5/7. The tune Chandakavartana in line a7 has the same length and rhythm (cf. , 181).

In the colophon a man named Kulmäs Orś is mentioned as the donor or patron of the manuscript. The same name is mentioned in b6. assume that the family of this dignitary were natives of Agni (Yanqi) (see also ).

Fragment of a manuscript which includes A 251 - A 294 (cf. ). The fragment is badly damaged, only the left half of the leaf remains. The original leaf must have been remarkably long, with about 50 syllables in line 8a. Lines a1-2 and b7-8 are lost.
The fragment contains the end of act 26 with the colophon and the beginning of act 27.
The translation and commentary for this fragment can be found in .
The tune name has been lost. The meter is 4x12 (5/7).

MaitrHami 1, 1b 14-3a 22; MaitrSiŋgim

These fragments contain part of the first act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka. An Uy. parallel is MaitrHami 1, 1b14 - ca. 3a12; lines a6-7 here correlate with MaitrHami 1, 2a19-24 and MaitrSiŋgim, Taf. 116 v.4-11 (). See also .
presents the two sides of this leaf in the wrong order, as the authors already point out in the appendix (p. 256).
Fragment of a manuscript which includes A 251 - A 294 (cf. ). Lines a1 and b8 are lost.
For a complete translation and commentary cf. .
The narrative of this passage corresponds to a sequence of episodes told in the Catuṣpariṣatsūtra, end of Vorgang 20 to the beginning of Vorgang 22. (cf. , vol. II: 212-217).

The only possible way to interpret the sequence wiki u pñi is as wiki ñu pi, which is confirmed by various parallels. As a scribal error, this kind of mistake would be unparalleled. do not comment on this sequence but Siegling corrects it in his personal copy.

transcription.prose:
Thereupon, the bodhisattva Maitreya, although still young and small in years (with his hands) adorned with webbings, glorious, (he took a gold-colored leaf) ...
/// (tmäṣ) (metrak) (bodhisat)tu w(ir) mkälto puklākaṃ tmäk teṣ sopisyo yetuñcäs parnoñcä
(s) (tsarnā) (wsā-yokāṃ) (patrak) (eṃtsāt)
... by the putting down (a line) he writes thousand akṣaras. /// āñc tāluneyo wälts akṣaräs pikäṣ
Thereupon, having given this leaf to his father, he says: ... tmäṣ cam patrak pā
(cri) (wawuräṣ) (träṅkäṣ) ///
These akṣara writings in this kind of configuration, these are the characters fashioned by the sages. (akṣar-pekeyntu) (tämne-wäknā) (retweyo) (:) (cemäk) (akṣari) (ri)ṣakäśśi raritwuṣ :
But for our sake, who are illuminating the speech appropriate for the nirvāṇa, these characters do not count as the (proper) script. mā nu nervānac ritwont rake tkäl(ṣa)ntā
(s) (:) (wasäṃ) (mosann) (ats) (akṣris) (kaśaṃ) (yäñc) (||)
Being astonished and amazed, Brahmāyu says: (añumāski) (weyeṃ) (nāṃtsu) (brahmāyu) (trä)ṅkäṣ
"Which script then counts as the [proper] script?" || äsaṃ nu akṣar akṣris kaśaṃ yäṣ ||
Thereupon, the bodhisattva ... tmäṣ bodhisattu
///
This script is definitely appropriate to make known all the Laws. (sä)s akṣar puk märkampalntu śärsässi āyāto nāṃtsu
Therefore this script counts as the proper script. tämyo
(säs) (akṣar) (akṣris) (kaśaṃ) (yäṣ) ///
These characters are comparable by the configuration (akṣari) (menāk) retweyo
but it does not exist here in the world. mā nu täṣ ārkiśoṣṣaṃ naṣ
Then the god Brahmā stands in the sky ... (tmäṣ) (bramñkät) (e)preraṃ kä
(lytär) ///
Among all characters, these characters are the glorious ones, (which were written by the Buddhas) as numerous as the grains of sand of the Gaṅgā-river. (puk) (akṣarsaṃ) (ceṣ) (akṣari) (pa)rnoṣ näṃ gaṅgavāl(uk) ///
///
///
///
... Having heard that(, the purohita Brahmāyu says:) ... täm ka(k)l(y)u(ṣuräṣ) ///
... (this) script stands. ||
/// akṣar kälytär ||
Then the purohita says to the bodhisattva: tmäṣ purohi(t) (bodhisatvānac) (träṅkä)ṣ
"O lord, ..." k(ātäk) ///
... (the bodhisattva say)s:
/// (träṅkä)ṣ
Hear, o father! päklyoṣ pācar
|| In the tune Niṣkramānta: || || niṣkramāntaṃ ||

pada.s:
From Ratnaśikhin onwards until Śākyamuni many Buddha-gods, teachers, (to many gods and mortals by the ten thousands, by the thousands,) by the hundreds, the ones who have attained the realm of script, these ones were the teachers of the (proper) script, ratna(śi)kh(i)näṣ ṣu ; śākya
(muni) (ṣolar) (māk) (ptāñktañ) (käṣṣiñ)
(ñäktas) (napenäśśi) ; (tmānäntu) (wältsantu) ; (kä)ntantuyo māk :

akṣar lame yomuṣ ; akṣar āksiṣa
(ntāñ) ; (cemäk) (nāṃtsuṣ) (ṣeñc)
from them I have learned to write this script and writing named Brāhmī. (cesmäṣ) (cam) (brāhmī) (ñom) ; (akṣar) (peke) (piktsi) ; (āklye) (yāmwe) (näṣ)
... in the script and writing there is no other one equal to you. (a)k(ṣa)r pekeyaṃ ; mā naṣ cwaśśäl , samm ālak :

prose.s:
(I entrust you with) [my] 84,000 (disciples.) okät tmāṃ śtwar wä
(lts) (tñy) (ākläṣlyes) (senik) (kälpsaṃ)

translation.line: ... sit down, you noble [men]!
... the Purohita Brahmāyu, having raised both hands towards the sky ...
... the sun is rising. || ...
... (No matter how many gods) ... from (all) directions revere (Brahmāvatī) with añjali-hands, you [pl.] too by day [and] (by night) ... him ...

line.tr: Aufgegangen sind die ausgezeichneten Kennzeichen: Es bebte die Erde, es regneten Perlen zusammen mit lieblichen Blumen [bzw. liebliche Perlen zusammen mit Blumen]
The excellent signs have arisen: the earth has trembled, pearls have rained [down] together with lovely flowers [or: lovely pearls have rained [down] together with flowers]
... das Wort "... m buddha" wird von(?) den Göttern ... gehört.
... the word "... m buddha" is heard by(?) the gods ...
(No matter how many gods) … from (all) directions revere (Brahmāvatī) with añjali-hands, you [pl.] too by day [and] (by night) … him …

line.tr: Welche in des Buddha (Śākyamu)ni Lehre Si(ttlichkeit bewahren), Gaben geben, mit Freude (das Wissen) lernen, den Sinn verstehen, ... auf den Wegen den Boden fegen, ...
Who[ever], in the teaching of the Buddha (Śākyamu)ni, keep the moral conduct, give gifts, learn (the knowledge) with joy, understand the meaning, ... sweep the ground on the paths, ...
Wie ihr es für euch gut befindet, so tuet auch ihr!
As you find it acceptable for yourselves, so do you[rselves] also!

line.tr: Welche da jetzt ... in des Buddha Gesetz Freude finden ...
Who[ever] now ... take delight in the Law of the Buddha ...
Who[ever] now ... take delight in the Law of the Buddha ...
Welche da jetzt ... in des Buddha Gesetz Freude finden ...
Who[ever] now ... take delight in the Law of the Buddha ...
Who[ever] now ... take delight in the Law of the Buddha ...
... welche da jetzt ... an die Tugenden binden ...
however now attaches ... to the virtues ...

Welche da jetzt ... (entlassen) habend, in des Buddha Gesetz Freude empfinden, Gaben (ge)ben, sittliche Haltung bewahren, das Wissen l(ernen), der Juwelendreiheit Dienste tun, Höhle, Zelle, Kloster [oder] Aufenthaltsort der Gemeinde bauen, elende Wesen (lieb)en, den Kranken Dienst tun, an ... Gefallen haben, ... Wissen lehren/lernen, vom (Bö)sen fernhalten [und] an die Tugend binden, ebendiese (werden) zu (der Zei)t mit dem Bu(ddha, dem Lehrer), zusammenkommen.

Those who now ... having (released), find pleasure in the law of the Buddha, (gi)ve donations, keep the moral conduct, l(earn) the knowledge, do service to the jewel-trinity, build a cave, a cell, a monastery [or] a habitation for the community, (lo)ve miserable beings, do service to the sick, find pleasure in ..., teach/learn the knowledge, keep away from (ev)il [and] attach to the virtues, these very [people] (will), at (that tim)e, meet with the Bu(ddha, the teacher).

prose.s: All exit. || lcär p(o)ñś ||

In the Maitreyasamiti-Nāṭ(aka, the 25th act, with the name “The Showing of the (Great) Hells” [Nirayanidarśana]) has come to an end. || maitreyasamit(i)nāṭk(aṃ) (niraya)
(nidarśaṃ) (ñomā) (wikipäñpint) (ni)pāt ār ||
(Now this dialog) [is] to be understood [as taking place] at the (northern) side (of the Kukkuṭapāda-mountain). (sās) (nu) (tāpärk) (plāc) (kukkuṭapāt) (ṣulis) (uttar) kälymeyaṃ kärsnālyi •

Thereupon, the venerable Buddha-god Maitreya reflects (in the sixth hour of the day on the heart [and] mind [and] deeds) of the beings (to be freed): tmäṣ āṣānik metrak ptāñkät ko(naṃ)
(ṣkäśśāṃ) (praṣtaṃ) (tsälpäṣlyinäs) (wra)saśśi ā(riñc) (pältsäk) (lyalypäntu) (pältsäṅkāṣ)

“The many beings [and] the people, who in their existences (together with me) according to my teaching had striven for (the wish) for redemption, (these were redeemed by me.) (k)us n(e) nṣ(aśśäl) (ṣiyak) (māk) wrasañ śoṣi cmoläṃtwaṃ ñi śāsnaṃ tsälpāluneṣi
(ākāl) (rināntāñ) (ṣeñc) (cem) (ñi) (tsälpo)ṣ ṣeñc

(And furthermore, [the beings], which were [beings] having a (good) mind, these not only by my turning the wheel of the Law [but also] by seeing my magic power, (with which the wall of the Kukkuṭapāda-mountain was broken) (by ten millions and countless numbers have acquired the benefits [of salvation]. kus pat nu (wrasañ) (kāswa-)pälskāñ ṣeñc cem ñi märkampalṣi wärkänt spārtwäṣluneyo okāk ku(kkuṭa)
(pāt) (ṣulis) (cwaṅke) (wākäṣluneyis) (pratiha)ri pälkāluneyo ko(risyo) (asaṃkhyes)y(o) wrasañ kās(w)o(ne)yntu yomär

Those beings, however, with a small [and] dry mind, these (by my bringing forth of exceedingly great) magic power, (having acquired the benefits [of salvation],) were redeemed. kus ne nu tsru-āsar-pälskāñ wrasañ ṣeñc ce(m) (ñi) (ṣo)
(kyo) (tsopatsäṃ) (pratihari) (yāmluneyo) (korisyo) (a)saṃkhyesyo kās(w)o(neyntu) (yomu)räṣ tsalpar •

And now these beings, by whom really and truly (the wish) to acquire the benefits [of salvation] according to my teaching (has been striven for), [they] are not [yet] (released from the sufferings of the Saṃsāra). tāpärk nu cem wrasañ ke ne ṣakk atsek ñi śāsnaṃ kāswone(yntu) (yo)
(nmāluneṣi) (ākāl) (rito) (naṣ-äm) (saṃsārṣinās) (klopäntwäṣ) mā (tsälpoṣ)
Therefore, I must bring forth openly some really and truly great magic power openly. (tämyo) (ñi) (ṣa)kk atsek tsopatsäṃ pratihari pākkraśi yal
And thus: ślak śkaṃ

prose.s: (After him having reflected in that way) in the three-thousand-fold world the earth is moving in a six-fold way: (tanne) (wkänyo) (pälskoräṣ) (tri) (wältseṃ) (ār)k(i)śoṣṣaṃ tkaṃ ṣä(k) w(äknā) (wāsä)ṅkātär

pada.s: It [scil. the earth] goes towards the sunrise, yäṣ koṃ-pärkāntac ;
it goes back towards the sunset, yäṣ ṣkārā koṃ-wmānt ;
[and] it goes towards the North yäṣ ṣul(iñcäṃ) ,

[it goes] (back towards the South,)
(ṣkārā) (mäcriṃ) ;
([it goes] to the centre,) (ywārckā)
([it goes] back to the ends.) (ṣkārā) , (ākantwac) (:)
The water (wells up) in the ocean; (ysäṣ) (s)āmudraṃ wär ;
(the divine palaces) tremble, meyeñc (wimāntu) ;
divine voices are raised; (kātä)ṅkānträ , ñäkcyāñ w(akañ) ;
divine instruments are sounding. nuseñc ñäkcyāñ , rapeyu :
It is raining divine flowers, swiñc ñäkcyāñ pyāppyā(ñ) ;

(Kuśeśaya- [and] Mandāraka-flowers are floating in [the] air) filled with sandal-wood [and] jewelry. (plu)
(señc) (kuśeśaiy) ; (mandārakāñ) , candaṃṣinäṃ ; katuṣ(inäṃ) , (epreraṃ) (:)
The earth [lit. earth god] is sprinkled with a fragrant rain, pärsäṣtär tkaṃ ñkät ; snumṣiṃ swaseyo ;

MaitrHami 26, 1; MaitrSiŋgim 26, 1

The attribution of this fragment to act 26 and the connection to A 287 is expounded in (pace , who originally places it in act 20/21). The colophon of act 25 thus is to be found in line a2; lines a3 through b7 already are part of act 26. Line b7 runs parallel to MaitrHami 26, 1a26; a3ff. run parallel to MaitrSiŋgim 26, 1a (Taf. 181, r.1-3) ().
The transcription and translation here include the text from fragment A 287 (unlinked passages)!

Two fragments of a manuscript which includes A 251 - A 294 (cf. ). A 287 contains part of the left side of this leaf, while A 259 contains the right half, containing the ends of several lines. The latter fragment is considered to be lost.
Sides have been swapped here as against the original publication in and as already suggested in (Nachträge): 256, , and II, 65II, 81I, 125II and 163II.
Sides have been swapped here (as against the original publication) following the fragment A 259; see , and I, 98I, 125II and 163II.
There is a gap of about 12 syllables at the beginning of this line; prefer to read [n.] instead of [t.] (as in ).
The tune Yuk 'horse' matches a tune Yakwe in TB, which also helps in determining the metre: 4x12 syllables, rhythm 5/7 ().
pākraśi yalyi: this pāda is one syllable too long; , suggest to read pākär 'apparent' instead of pākraśi.
The tune bahudantāka also appears in TB; it has 4x25 syllables, rhythm 5/5/4/4/4/3. This strophe ends in line b5.
The syllable ri of risaṃ is still readable on fragment A 287 ().

All this is seen without fault on the body of the Buddha Maitreya.

line.tr: ...setzt er den glühenden Dreizack, in den Körper stach [und] stieß(?) er...
he sets the glowing trident, into the body he stabbed and thrust(?)...
Wiederum denkt er: "Pfui (sei) über (mein böses) Tun! Wer mir Gutes getan hat, eben dem habe ich Böses zugedacht."
Again he thinks: "Fie on (my evil) doing! Who has done good to me, to just the one I have intended evil."
Why shouldn't I, having given up life, go into nirvāṇa?
Darauf kommen die Karman-Wesen mit Schwertern in der Hand [und] schneiden sich in der Annahme, [es sei] Gold, Fleisch von seinem Körper.
Thereupon the karma-beings come with swords in [their] hand[s] and, thinking [it to be] Gold, cut [the] flesh from his body.
By hundreds the years will pass, [but] cutting off flesh from his body [will] not stop. (cf 99)
Zu Hunderten werden die Jahre vergehen, [aber] man hört nicht auf, Fleisch von seinem Körper zu schneiden [wtl. das Fleisch hört nicht auf, von dessen Körper zu schneiden (= geschnitten zu werden)].
In [their] hundreds the years will pass, [but] the flesh will not stop to [be] cut from his body.

This fragment may contain part of the fift act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka. There are no obvious Uy. parallels, and the tocharian parallels and are not clearly identified as to which act they belong in either. This fragment's connection to act V is established by the existence of a folio number (67) on the verso side, which can be calculated to go into this act. But see .
Lines a1 and b8 are lost.
The restoration kälk(i)m is thanks to Sergey Malyshev (p.c. 6 January 2017).
The reading aṣaṃ in was corrected to arṣa in . The segmentation arṣäl k· is thanks to a suggestion by Sergey Malyshev (p.c., 14 June 2016).
For the combination of ime with an adjective in -ṣi, cf. and .
For the translation, cf. Dictionary and Thesaurus of Tocharian A s.v. ywārckinäṃ-ywārckiṃ-pältsäk*.

MaitrSiŋgim, Taf. 146-148

This fragment contains the end of the fourteenth and the beginning of the fifteenth act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; the colophon of act 14 is contained in line a8, line b1-8 already cover the beginning of act 15. An Uy. parallel is MaitrSiŋgim, Taf. 146 v.6-147 r.28 (act 14, ) to Taf. 148 (act 15, ), where the colophon is in Taf. 147 r.21-28 (). See also .
The restoration (ś)l(a) (ri)s is based on Siegling's personal copy of 157 . The collocation ris waṣtu also occurs in a3 (as pointed out by Anna Kuritsyna via Ilya Itkin, 18 November 2015).
The restoration (kumbhā)ṇḍāśśi (cf. ) is based on the Uy. parallel of the sentence.

This fragment contains the end of the twenty-first and the beginning of the twenty-second act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka. line.tr: (Welche) ... Kloster, Aufenthaltsort der Gemeinde, Höhle [oder] Zelle herrichten, die (drei) Juwelen mit Verehrung behandeln, schließlich Zuflucht zu den drei Stätten der Zuflucht [wtl. die drei Zufluchtnahmen] nehmen [und] den Wunsch (hegen), mit dem Buddha Maitreya zusammenzukommen, ...

(Who[ever]) ... prepare a monastery, a habitation for the community, a cave [or] a cell, treat the (three) jewels with reverence, last but not least, take refuge in the three places of refuge [lit. the three refuge-takings] [and] (cherish) the desire to meet with the Buddha Maitreya, ...
Freue dich [wtl. rufe Freude hervor], Edler! (Eine) wunderbar(e Sache habe ich in meinen Träumen gesehen).
Rejoice [lit. evoke joy], noble one! (A) wonderfu(l thing I have seen in my dreams).

MaitrHami 10, 7-8; MaitrHami 11, 1-2

This fragment contains the end of the tenth and the beginning of the eleventh act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka, with the colophon of act X contained in lines a7-8. For lines a1-8 the Uy. parallel is MaitrHami X, 7b22-8a25. Act XI begins in lines a8-b8 here, the Uy. parallel probably being MaitrHami XI, 1 and 2, which, however, is missing. See also .

line.tr: (Da(?) euer Verhalten(?)) ... in der Lehre des Śakyamuni nachlässig [war], ihr Nonnen, wurdet ihr in 16 Städten Zerstörerinnen genannt.
((Since(?) your behaviour(?)) ... [was] negligent in the teaching of Śakyamuni, you nuns, in 16 cities you were called the she-destroyers.
Ziehet [eure] Zunge aus dem Munde!
Pull [your] tongue from [your] mouth!
Eigenhändig ziehen wir die eigene Zunge aus dem Munde [und] (schneiden sie mit) glühenden Me(ssern ab).
With [our] own hand we pull [our] own tongue out of [our] mouth [and] (cut it off with) red-hot kn(ives).
... wir tadelten die in der Zucht Stehenden.
... we scolded those under the discipline.
Wir bekennen unsere Schuld [und] beseitigen unser Vergehen: Möge uns Verzeihung sein ...
We confess our guilt [and] eliminate our offence: may forgiveness be ours ...

; MaitrHami 4, 16-17; MaitrSiŋgim

This fragment contains part of the fourth act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka. Uy. parallels are MaitrHami 4, 16b-[17], and MaitrSiŋgim, Taf. 27 (): line a3 here = Taf. 27 r.2, lines a-6 here = Taf. 27 r.18-19, and lines b6-8 here (= Taf. 24 v.7-10) contain the colophon of act 4. A tocharian parallel is (with a1 here = b7, and a2 here = b8 = MaitrHami 4, 16b8f.). See also .
Reconstructed tentatively after b1.

MaitrHami 13, 9-10
This fragment contains part of the thirteenth act of the Maitreyasamitināṭaka; an Uy. parallel is MaitrHami XIII, 9a19-10a15f. See also .

Ilya Itkin (p.c., 20 July 2016) suggests restoring (sä)rk, which is supported by the fact that the expression "sickness, old age and death" is also attested in a6, albeit with the word for "sickness" instead of . On the other hand, the restoration (sä)rk conflicts with the Uyghur translation, which only mentions old age and death: qarïmaq ölmäkn(i)ng (MaitrHami XIII, 10a13, cf. ).

The king Siṃha, [having seen] on the body of the teacher, the Buddha, the falling of the gods, the desire of the human beings, [the ignorance] of the animals, the shame and the slaughtering of the infernal beings, and [having considered] also the efforts of the Bodhisattvas on behalf of the entire world in the hells, in the special hells, among the animals, among the ghosts, on the four continents, in the divine abodes of the six-fold Kāmadhātu a compassion beyond belief for the beings born in the 50 former places arises in him, siṃhe wäl ptāñkät käṣṣiyāp kapśiññaṃ ñäktaśśi litālune • napenäśśi ritālune • lwāśśi ā

line.tr: Darum haben wir desgleichen mit Freude geschrieben [in dem Wunsche]: "Möchten wir [doch] gewiss zu der Zeit zu Maitreya, dem Buddha, (in die Stadt) Ketuma(tī) kommen!"
Therefore we wrote likewise with joy [wishing]: "May we certainly come at that time to Maitreya, the Buddha, (into the city) Ketuma(tī)!"
... dürfte Klöster errichten, [eine] Meile groß [und] ganz aus Juwel[en] errichtet.
... may build monasteries, [a] mile large [and] made entirely from jewel[s].
Durch Gläubigsein dürfte sich ein Wesen viele Verdienste erzeugen.
Through believing, a being may create for himself many merits.
Whether he will question why they have called the merit of the law so great? (cf 239; 343)
Ob er Zweifel hegen wird?
[I wonder,] will he have doubts?
Ihre Zuflucht zum guten Gesetz genommen habend, werden alle die[se] Buddhas erlöst.
Having taken their refuge with the good law, all [these] three Buddhas will be released.

Then anytime the Buddha, the master, as if he were a ... mountain, (decorated) [and] adorned with the 32 marks [and] the 80 delightful ornaments, took a step, just as many times roared and sounded as it were this earth with happiness, tmäṣ ptāñkät käṣṣi mäṃt ne y· ṣul tāṣ tmaśśäl tāskmāṃ taryāk we pi lakṣaṇä(syo) o(ktuk)

[and] so often rays spread from the crown of his head and throat and blinded as it were gods and humans in all 10 regions of the world. täpreṃ täprenäk mrācäṣ ṣuṅkä«ṣ» swāñcenāñ ñä(ktas) (na)

Therefore, the great kings, starting with Prasenajit, and the lay kings, starting with Bimbisāra, area by area from [their] lands, surrounded by 10 million ministers [and] noblemen, at (the marvel) of the god of gods, the Buddha, they gathered, even going far from [their] countries, hurriedly [and] without effort. tmäṣ prasenajinäṣṣ aci śāwe lāṃś bimba(sārä)
ṣṣ aci wāskāñ lāś kälyme kälyme ypeyätwäṣ ṣñi ṣñi korisyo āmāśās ypeṣinäs wrasasyo worpuṣ ñäktaśśi pättāññäktes (prātihāri)
yā lok penu ypeyätwäṣ ymār sne ske kropant

Thus also went Anāthapiṇḍika, Ugra, Luhasudatta, to start with, who already had obtained a rank, the lay brother, house(holders,) Koṭīśvaras, rich ones, caravan leaders, the queens, surrounded by goddesslike women, Kṣemā, Mālikā, etc., the lay sisters, Viśākhā, Sujātā, etc. tämne pat nu anātha«pi»ṇḍikāṃ ugreṃ luhasudattenäṣṣ aci paräṃ kälpoṣ wāskāñ waṣt (lmo)

ñ yeñc

[Furthermore] the six Tīrtha-teachers went, Puraṇa, Maskari, etc., surrounded by [their] Kāpālikas, Ulūkas, Tāpasas, Nirgranthas [and] Parivrājakas (wandering monks) respectively, (and other countless) people of the land. puraṇeṃ mäskarinäṣṣ aci ṣñi ṣñi kāpālikās ulukes tāpases nigranthās parivrājkāsyo worpuṣ ṣäk tirtheñi käṣṣi(ñ) (ālyek) (śkaṃ) (sne) (kaś)
ypeṣiñi wrasañ yeñc • ||

Likewise the Rūpadhātu-gods went, starting from the five Śuddhāvasās; Śubhakṛtsna, Ābhāsvara, Brahmaloka, etc., to see the marvel of the god of gods, the Buddha. tämne pat nu päñ śuddhavāsätwäṣ śubhakṛts ābhāswar brahmalokäṣṣ aci rupadhatuṣiñi (ñäktañ) (yeñc) (ñäkta)
śśi pättāññäktes añumāskiṣiṃ wram lkātsi •

The four kings of the Kāmadhātu [world] (went), Indra (with) Suyāma, Saṃtuṣita, Su(nirmāṇarati), each surrounded by [their] own divine crowd, letting rain divine flowers, clothes, jewels [and] heavenly golden jewelry; kāmadhātuṣiñi penu śtwar lāṃś wlāñkät suyāmeṃ saṃtuṣiteṃ su(nirmāṇaratiṃśäl) (yeñc) (ṣñi) (ṣñi) (ñä)

[Furthermore], the Gandharvas went by the hundreds, Citra, Citrāṅgata, Timburu etc. good ... beating musical instruments. citreṃ citrāṅganeṃ timburenäṣṣ aci käntantuyo g(andharviñ)
kāswe rapeyäntu kärnäsmāṃ yeñc

Finally, by the surface of the air space in [their] ten millions heavenly Apsaras stood, Śacī, Rambhā, etc., who [their] with beautiful gestures confuse (all) passionate beings, to see the god of gods, the Buddha. śaci rāmbhānäṣṣ aci penu korisyo ñäkcyāṃñ aptsaräntu kräntsonās pikārāsyo trikäsm(āṃ) (puk) (eṅkä)

line.tr: Wie oft alsdann der Buddha, der Meister, ... einen Schritt setzte, ebenso oft brüllte diese Erde/Erdgöttin.
As often then as the Buddha, the Master, made a step, equally as often the earth(goddess) roared.

Anytime the Buddha, the teacher, (decorated) and adorned with the 32 marks [of the great man] and the 80 gentle jewels, took a step, as if he were a … mountain, just as many times the earth roared and resounded as if out of joy, and just as many times rays spread from the crown of his head and from his mouth towards all ten cardinal points, [which] blinded gods and men, as it were.

line.tr: Infolgedessen versammelten sich fern von [ihren] Ländern, eiligst [und] ohne [irgendwelche] Bemühung die großen Könige, Prasenajit usw., [und] die Laienkönige, Bimbisara usw., Gegend für Gegend aus [ihren] Ländern, je von ihren zehn Millionen von Ministern [und] Leuten des Landes umgeben.

Consequently, there gathered, hurriedly [and] without [much] effort, far from [their] countries, the great kings, Prasenajit etc. [and] the lay kings, Bimbisara etc., area by area from [their] countries, each surrounded by their ten millions of ministers [and] people of the country.
Götter [und] Menschen sehen sich gegenseitig.
Gods [and] humans saw each other.
Erregt holte er [scil. der Gott Māra] damals seinen Blumenbogen im Vertrauen auf den Pfeil der Leidenschaft.
Excited, he [i.e. the god Māra], at that time, fetched his bow of flowers, trusting in the arrow of passion.
(Die Erde) war (ringsum(?)) mit Blumen bedeckt, sie war lieblich wie die himmlische [Erde].
(The earth) was covered with flowers (all around(?)), it was lovely like the heavenly [earth].
Er [scil. Māra] ging (zu) eben der (Stelle, [aber] verwirrt) geworden, erkannte er für sich nicht die Richtung, wodurch (er) den Pfeil (nicht fand).
He [i.e. Māra] went (to) the very same (place, [but]) having become (confused), he did not recognize the direction for himself, wherefore (he did not find) the arrow.

line.tr: Unmittelbar darauf kehrten (die Strahlen), gleichsam mit Geist [versehen], um [und] nahmen wieder in dem Körper des Göttergottes Buddha Platz.
Immediately afterwards (the rays), [provided] with a mind, as it were, turned around [and] took their place again in the body of the god of gods, the Buddha.
Aus der Kontemplation sich erhebend, rief (alsdann aus) Mitleid (der Buddha, der Meister), mit schallender, tönender, lieblicher Brahmasvara-Stimme den Ānanda [und] sprach zu ihm:
Rising from contemplation, then, (the Buddha, the Master), (out of) pity, called Ānanda with [his] resounding, sonorous, lovely Brahmasvara voice [and] spoke to him:
Was muss das für ein gedanken(loses, böses) Wesen sein, das nicht ständig den Wunsch nach der Buddhaschaft hegte!
What a thought(less, evil) being this must be, who does not cherish the wish for Buddhaship at all times!
... sich gleichsam schämend vor den Wesen der fünf Geburtsklassen ...
... being ashamed, as it were, before the beings of the five incarnations ...

If I had known before, brother, that the Buddha rank is so excellent, and that for each moment, for as many moments as there are in three asaṃkhyeyas, I would have had to work three asaṃkhyeyas and one hundred kalpas in the Avīci [hell] with glowing body, then I would never have returned from my wish for the Buddha rank. (cf 33)
