Sieg/Siegling in already assumed that A 318 and A 319 belong to the same leaf. The calculation below is based on the size of the original leaf (based on the almost complete leaf ) and on the metrical analysis.
Lines a8 and b1 are lost on the right fragment (= A 319).

According to the context, kärsä must be derived from a root kärs- 'to shoot an arrow' being the equivalent of TB , also attested in TA ‘(distance of an) arrow shot’; the precise grammatical form, however, is uncertain, but a Prs VIII m-participle would make some sense, morphologically and syntactically.
About 18 akṣaras are missing in this line in total and approx. 8-9 syllables in the lacuna between the two fragments.

About nine syllables are missing in the lacuna between the two fragments and about four akṣaras at the end; this conforms to the number of 15 missing akṣaras in total. The restoration (śomi)nāśśi is proposed by Siegling in his personal copy.

Eight syllables are missing in the lacuna to judge from the lacuna in line b6; at the end, 7 syllables are missing for metrical reasons, both in a3 and on the verso side b6. Since this calculation matches both metres perfectly, one has to conclude that this line had no string hole space; even though most leaves of this series have string hole space in lines a3 and b6, a counter example is provided by , where line a3 had no string hole space either (and, accordingly, about 48 akṣaras in the line). We are then left with 14 missing syllables and approx. 15-16 missing akṣaras in both lines a3 and b6.

tläśtont has to be separated to tläś tont based on the co-occurrence of tläś with the verb knā- "disperse tläś" in b2. The form tläś is the oblique of an abstract noun in -ś (cf. ) is surely derived from the root 'to lift up, carry, bear'. In this passage it is used as an adverb.

For metrical reasons, me(m) 'measure' seems the only possible restoration, maybe an obliquus of manner. Even though the reading of the preceding word nim or tim cannot be checked, the dual pronoun tim is the only syntactically possible solution.
The colon division of pāda 1d after the lacuna is unclear; note that this would still be true without accepting the joint.

In total 14 syllables are missing and approx. 16 akṣaras. Restoration to (kä)l(ns)eñc is proposed by Siegling in his personal copy with two question marks, restoration to ṣom(aṃ) at the end of the line is proposed without question mark.
The colon division is unclear; in total, 19 syllables and approx. 21 akṣaras are missing. The hapax prusaṃ can be a locative sg. or pl. of a noun pru or prus.
-ṣ should belong to a 3.sg. form. The complete pāda 3c is missing and the first colon of pāda 3d, i.e. 25 syllables; approx. 31 akṣaras are missing in total.

25 syllables are missing and approx. 29 akṣaras in total. Since himavant is exclusively attested with ṣul 'mountain' or the adjective ṣulyiṃ, I propose to restore to (ṣul)y(iṃ) himavant; and since the remaining wär yā can hardly mean 'water traveled', I further suggest to read (or restore?) the instrumental wäryo. In any case, there is no possible alternative restoration for yā – ·y· (a form of the gerundive yātal 'capable' is excluded because it would mean that himavant had feminine gender). Note that the following 3.sg. kälnaṣ for kälnäṣ is certainly a misspelling (thus ) – it is quite certain that the original manuscript indeed had the reading kälnaṣ, because Siegling, who still ought to have access to the original, marked the form with a question mark in his personal copy.

Ten syllables are missing in the lacuna, eleven at the end, and approx. 24 akṣaras in total. As for the restoration of the second colon of 4c, nkä(ñci) 'silver' is the only known possible form, while restoration to mātär is suggested by mātrā in the following line – most likely not a variant of [[mātār]] 'sea monster', but rather derived from the Sanskrit water plant mātar- "Asian Watermoss" [Salvinia cucullata Roxb.].

The line contains prose text; about 15 akṣaras are missing in total. The restoration to (smi)mā(ṃ) is proposed by Siegling in his personal copy; restoration (himava)nt suggests itself by line b1 and is in accordance with the lacuna of about 3-4 missing akṣaras; we have here an ablativus comparationis.

Only two syllables are missing in the lacuna between the fragments and approx. 15 at the end of the line, so that in total 18 syllables are missing and approx. 22 akṣaras. The restoration wā(wluṣ) is suggested by Siegling in his personal copy, with reference to a 5.

Approx. eight syllables are missing in the lacuna, and seven at the end of the line; approx. 18 akṣaras are missing in total. lāñci-waṣtantu 'royal houses, palaces' has to be a compound; cf. a 1. The following form may be restored to an obl.sg. krañcäṃ ‘good' or poñcäṃ ‘all'.

The reduced form of the copula, which surfaces with pronominal suffixes in näṃ and näm, is indifferent to number, as was shown by and . Therefore, the agreement between näṃ and the plural participle worpunt is unproblematic. We thank Ilya Itkin (p.c) for pointing this issue out to us.

Eight syllables are missing in the lacuna and seven at the end of the line; the latter lacuna fits perfectly with the respective recto line a3. Restoration to (jimutake)tu is already proposed by Siegling in his personal copy.

Approx. four akṣaras are missing at the end of the line; together with the nine missing syllables in the lacuna, this conforms to the total number of approx. 15 missing akṣaras. One may restore the beginning of pāda 1d to p(ñ)i(ntuyo) 'with merits'.

Restoration to (pälska-pā)ṣe is suggested by the following; what is more, only this kind of verbal governing compounds can end in °ṣe. proposed to join the two fragments completely and to restore to lā(ntsa)c, but according to the calculation, there is a lacuna of at least 8-9 syllables between them. Siegling in his personal copy proposes to restore to lā(laṃṣkā). In total, about 20 akṣaras are missing in this line.

translation.line: ... Some, as enemies, withheld, as it were, friendship from each other [and] said: Don’t do [it, my] son! The others (?) ...
... 1. (Like) the extinguished [has tried to] go to the extinction, just so everyone should try ...
... penetrated [and] (surrounded) on the right side by the ray. 2. (In) such a way ...
... (Into the hot hells cold) rays they released; into the cold hells they released hot rays ...
... [inhabitants of] hell, animals [and] pretas were beaten by thirst and hunger. With them ...
... (|| In the N.-)tune: || But this Saṃsāra is very faulty, although exceedingly lustrous ...
... the earth with mountains [and] trees ... as it were. On the earth and in the air space ...
... the hells. They were ... as the abode [of gods] ...
... surrounded (by) the ray ...
... like the heavenly earth ... (musical instruments) roared, they made resound as it were ...
... in the hells the hell-guardians stood first, black like mountains ...
... with hands put together the hell-guardians despondently looked at the Buddhas. Hate [and] discord ...
... ([inhabitants of] hell), animals and pretas, all forgot their sufferings. Gods [and] humans, too, set (?) ...
... the earth-god shook, ... (heavenly) flowers (were raining down and) lovely (wreaths. 5.) ...
... created the marvel. (There)fore excessive [and] countless beings ...
... For redemption they sowed the healing roots. Having seen this matter ...

translation.line: ... my wish should be fulfilled by you ...
... having become the ones who fulfill the wish of the Lord Buddha, the teacher ...
... to revere the wise monk
... and at the beginning they are not under the control of the well-behaving ones ...
... oh Kāśyapa ...
... beings arise with an evil desire because of bad action ...

line.tr: ... macht ihn verächtlich.
... treats him with contempt.
Nicht wird dieses Gesetz des Buddha, o Kāśyapa, durch das Geschlecht der Erde vernichtet.
This law of the Buddha, o Kāśyapa, is not destroyed by the generation[s] of the earth.

... again [and] again he called [his] followers [and], at the same time, Ānanda.

line.tr: In dem Wunsche nach Essen wurden sie [scil. die Pretas] schnell begierig.
Wishing for food, they [i.e. the pretas] soon became greedy.
Ich [bin] selbst hungrig; von euch erbitte ich dieses.
I [am] hungry myself; of you I [would] ask this.
If out of compassion with us water is raining from the cloud, …
… the [clear] sky comes back again.
Er [scil. Koṭikarṇa] fand kein Wasser, er riss sich die Blätter des Baumes ab. Das aß er.
He [i.e. Koṭikarṇa] found no water, he tore the leaves off the tree. That he ate.
... genossen Glücksgüter nach himmlischer Art.
... enjoyed blessings of the heavenly kind.
Die Nacht wurde hell; zugleich mit dem Ruhebett verschwand die Frau.
The night was getting bright; together with the bed the woman disappeared.
Koṭikarṇa sah das [und] ekelte sich.
Koṭikarṇa saw this [and] was disgusted.
Bei Nacht ergötzest du dich wie ein Gott, bei Tage siehst du h(öllische) Leiden.
In the night you regale yourself like a god, in the day[time] you see h(ellish) suffering.
Aus Mitleid sprach Kātyāyana (zu mir: "Vom Schafetöten) kehre um, [mein] Lieber!" Ich aber fügte mich nicht. Ich sagte: ("Das ist mein Gewerbe, ich lebe davon."
Out of compassion, Kātyāyana spoke (to me: "From killing sheep) turn away, [my] dear!" But I did not obey. I said: ("This is my craft. I live on this.")
Keep the moral by night, so that you will not perish by that same thing!
Bei Nacht bewahre die Moralvorschrift!
At night, keep the moral rule!

translation.line: (By day I enjoy) the heavenly fruit of moral behaviour, by night the hellish fruit (of adultery. Koṭikarṇa continued on his way. He came to a lake next to which there was a palace, which he entered. 88. Therein)

was a woman, [beautiful] as an apsaras. To the top of her seat a preta (was) tied with ropes (and another to the foot of her seat. Koṭikarṇa was greeted in a friendly way by the woman and she inquired about the state he was in. He answered: Hungry)

I am beyond all measure. Give me, oh noble one, something to eat! 89. The woman said to him: "I will give you [something] (but you must not give anything to the two there. She gave him food and went out. Immediately the two came and said)

to Koṭikarṇa: Compassionate lord, long we have been hungry! (Koṭikarṇa gave them food out of compassion. But as soon as the two put the food into their mouths, it turned into blood and puss, and they spat it out again.)
They filled the palace with an evil smell. The woman came (and saw what had happened and rebuked Koṭikarṇa for his compassion. In the meantime there came)

another (woman). She said to the first woman: Hungry I am, oh noble one, [my] food (allocate to me! 91. This one answered: eat the food that has been allocated to you. Immediately a pot appeared, filled with boiling water.)

The wind of deeds threw her head first into the pot [and] quickly boiled her body [in it]. (By) her deeds ... (A fresh wind made her alive again, and she then devoured her own boiled flesh. Thereupon a second woman came and)

said: I am hungry. Allocate my food to me! In the same way she spoke to this one. Immediately, she became a she-goat [and] began to eat fodder. (Koṭikarṇa mused: I have not died. How have I ended up in the realm of the pretas? He then turned to the woman and asked her: What)
deeds have you done? The noble one told [him]: 93. This one, bound to the top [of the seat], (was my husband, the one at the foot of the seat was my son. The worthy Kātyāyana received)

food [and] drink from me. They scolded: (You do not) eat the food yourself; you also give it to others. You have shattered (our possessions (?) ... as a punishment you shall eat blood and puss. Now in retribution all they eat turns into blood and puss. The woman who eats her own)
flesh, this one was my son’s wife. What I would give her as food and drink to stock up, that (she ate herself or gave to others. When I rebuked her for this, she said: I did not do so! If I did,)

I will eat [my own] flesh. She did [do so and] now enjoys the fruit of it. 95. The one who eats the fodder, this one (was my servant) before. (When I told her to grind corn, she ate it herself or gave it to others. I took her to task, but she insisted: If I have done so, may I become a goat and eat fodder! In retribution)

she [now] is a goat that eats fodder. Myself, too, I had an evil disposition towards these. Among the gods (I will be reborn, after a brief sojourn amongst the pretas. And she added: Can you do me a favour? When Koṭikarṇa asked her what this was about, she said:)

Oh Koṭikarṇa, in Vāsavagrāma, the village of the humans, (there is) our (daughter, who has not learned to do good. Tell her about our suffering here among the pretas, and that her mother advises her to desist from her evil deeds. When Koṭikarṇa asked to be brought to Vāsavagrāma,)

she immediately took [his] arm [and] the preta-woman brought him with [his] animals (to Vāsavagrāma within a moment (?). In the meantime the other merchants had returned to Vāsavagrāma and had told there that they had lost Koṭikarṇa. Koṭikarṇa heard the people lament, and on his asking about the reason, they say):

These many people said that Koṭikarṇa, the caravan leader has lost [his] dear life on the way. (In order not to create fresh excitement, Koṭikarṇa kept secret his arrival, first attended to the preta-woman’s errand, and then went to Kātyāyana and sat down by the feet)

of the good one. This one taught him the law [and] as fruit [of this] he obtained the Srotāpatti rank. (He now wished to become a monk, but Kātyāyana made it clear to him that he would need his parents’ consent for this. When he now called on them and brought forward his request,)
father [and] mother said to him: Consider us first of all, oh good one! 99. Twelve (years he remained with his parents)

line.tr: «Give me, o noble one, something to eat!» The woman said to him: «I will give you [something], …»
Der Tatenwind warf sie kopfüber in den Topf, [und] schnell kochte ihr Körper darin.
The wind of [her] deeds threw her headfirst into the pot, [and] quickly her body boiled in it.
(Welche) Taten habt ihr getan?
What deeds did you do?
Sie schalten: "Du (issest) das Essen (nicht) selbst, du gibst auch anderen."
They scolded: "You (do not eat) the food yourself, you also give [it] to others."
What I would give her as food and drink to stock up, that …
Auch ich hegte böse Gesinnung gegen diese.
Myself, too, harboured an evil disposition towards these.
Diese vielen Leute sagten, Koṭikarṇa, der Karawanenführer, hat auf dem Wege [sein] liebes Leben verloren.
These many people said Koṭikarṇa, the caravan leader, has lost [his] dear life on the way.

line.tr: Darauf die (Minister), mit drohenden(?) Schwertern an der Tür der Dānaśālā stehend, ...
Thereupon the (ministers), standing with threatening(?) swords at Dānaśālā's door, ...
Durch die gute Art [deines] Königtums hast du unser Herz ergriffen.
Through the good nature of [your] kingship you have seized our heart.
This rākṣasa of human birth must quickly go away from this country. (cf 36; 305)
Die Minister sprechen: "Ob der Herr diesen Brahmanen oder uns behält, wir aber (sind) nicht imstande, mit einem derartigen Feind des Herrn (in diesem Lande zu bleiben(?))."
The ministers say: "Whether [our] lord keeps this Brahmin or us - but we (are) not able (to remain in this country(?)) with such an enemy of [our] lord."

This text contains a conversation and argument between the king and Purohita [Brahmin], who does not share the king’s generosity towards supplicants. In the argument between the king and the vidūṣaka [Brahmin] immediately follows the dialogue of the king and the queen, where the king emphasises the fact that he would even give his own life to a supplicant. Thus it makes sense that should follow .

In the story as related in this text and the continuing fragment , there is a gap of unknown length, which may comprise perhaps less than a leaf’s length, but no more than two or three leaves: King Araṇemi drives the Brahmin Rudramukha out of the country before the eyes of his followers – which amounts to a serious insult. Rudramukha betakes himself to a different country where he opens a Brahmin school. All his thoughts and desire are bent on taking revenge on king Araṇemi.
The translation follows , and .
This fragment must be placed after and, according to , before . places A 342 first.

Translation as above . , and have more or less “Or why do you not regard my order [and] get excited [about] giving gifts at all?”. Instead of 'you get excited', Couvreur (op. cit.) suggests as alternative 'you continue'.
This line seems to contain a verse of 4x18 syllables, rhythm 7/7/4.

This fragment must be placed before and . However, it is unclear how many leaves are missing between these three fragments. This fragment, i.e. A 344, contains the beginning of the Araṇemijātaka. Lines a1–3 apparently mention donors and end with a pious wish. Lines a3–4 may mention briefly the general topic, and perhaps the title of the jātaka or the name of the protagonist, Araṇemi. Line a5 calls on to the reader, perhaps in the original setting the listener or spectator, to listen carefully. Lines b1–5 contain a frame story, a kind of Prolog im Himmel, to the actual jātaka. In this frame story, the gods Jñānaprabha and Karuṇaprabha comment on the world below. One of them speaks the strophe starting in line b3, which is of general content. Probably they will subsequently more specifically introduce the story of Araṇemi. The Tocharian B fragment covers roughly the same passage, but a close parallel is found only between A 344 a5 and 4–5.

tākmäs: If for tākamäs, this is a preterite. Possibly, it is for the optative tākimäs 'may we be', since often wishes of this type are found in colophons and introductory passages. Note, in any case, that the spelling is not correct: it is written tākmäs with regular k and m instead of tāk_m_as or tā_k_m_as.
skey· y·āṃ: The restoration is uncertain. One would expect the obl.pl. skeyas (not found here) followed by a verb.

cāt(a)kṣ(i masäk): This term refers to the identification of persons in the jātaka with persons from the present, i.e. the Buddha and persons from his life. Normally, this identification is found at the end of a jātaka, not at the beginning, so that this restoration (already by ) must remain uncertain.
: The two Tuṣita-gods, who are called Jñānaprabha and Karuṇaprabha here, are called Jñānasthita and Guṇasaṃpada in the Tocharian B version.
/// räṣ: Certainly an absolutive, for instance (täm kaklyuṣu)räṣ 'having heard this' or (täm pälko)räṣ 'having seen this'.
(śmāśānaśrä)ṅkāraṃ: This is the only tune name ending in ṅkāraṃ; the metre is 4 x 7/7/4.
(s)_uku(n)tw(äṣ): interprets "fallen (von) [ihren] Glücks[-Himmeln] herab".
: suggests ñareṣi(ñi klopantyo) 'the hell [beings] (suffer from sorrows)'.

/// nträ kaṣt yokeyo: The context clearly requires 'suffer from hunger and thirst', but the restoration of the verb is uncertain. Palaeographically excluded is (kärntsa)nträ 'are struck', as in a5 kaṣt yok(e)yo kakärnuṣ ṣeñc 'were struck by thirst and hunger'. yokeyo is the end of pada 1b.

prose.s: The Ārṣagrantha has come to an end. || ārṣkrānt ār ||

line.tr: Es muss eben auch dieses berücksichtigt werden: Es [ist] kein einziger Mensch in diesem ganzen Saṃsāra übriggeblieben, der nicht mein Angehöriger gewesen [wäre] oder dessen [Angehöriger] ich nicht gewesen wäre: [Aber] wir sind alle voneinander getrennt worden. Was für Tränen ich geweint habe, [wenn] das einer gesammelt hätte,[so] wäre es in einem Kalpa mehr gewesen als die Wasser in den 4 Ozeanen.

This, indeed has to be taken into account as well: There [is] not a single human left in this whole Saṃsāra, who has not been my relative or whose [relative] I have not been: [But] we have all been separated from each other. The tears I have wept, [if] one had gathered that, it would have been more in a single kalpa than the waters of the 4 oceans.

Just like a seeing person [avoids] uneven paths, [just so] shall the wise one ... avoid evils.
… taking the juice [away], just so the wise should go [away] from the village. (cf 75, 78)

(good) [is] self-control (in talking),

s.tr: He who in the discipline of the law will not be careless, who has taken away the cycle of birth, he will go to the end of sorrow.

line.tr: In der Meditation möge er nicht nachlässig sein.
He shall not be negligent in meditation.

[Even if] scolded [himself], may he [in turn] never scold.
Auf! [wtl. fangt an!] Geht hinaus [und] schließt euch der Lehre des Buddha an!
Come on! [lit. begin!] Go out [and] join the teaching of the Buddha!

line.tr: Verständige Menschen bewahren die Regel der Selbstzucht.
Conscious beings keep the rule of self-discipline.
Die verständigen Wesen nehmen anderen nicht [ihr] Eigentum [fort].
Prudent beings do not take [away] the property of others.
Die verständigen Wesen nehmen anderen nicht das Leben [und] verletzen nicht die Grenze des Samvara.
Prudent beings do not take the life of others [and] do not violate the constraints of the samvara.
Verständige Wesen wahren die Regel des Saṃvara [und] überschreiten [sie] nicht aus Leidenschaft.
Prudent beings keep the rule of the saṃvara [and] do not transgress [it] out of passion.
Die bedachtsamen Wesen nehmen anderen nicht das Leben [und] verletzen nicht die Grenze des Saṃvara.
The thoughtful beings do not take the life of others [and] do not violate the boundaries of the saṃvara.

Wer mit ... Ehrerbietung die Füße des Buddha verehrt, den Samen des Nirvāṇas in [seine] Geburtenfolge gesät habend, der wird(?) [in dem Gedanken]: "Du bist mein Verwandter" [als] Verwandter begehrt. Wer...

Who[ever] reveres with ... reverence the feet of the Buddha, having sown the seed of the nirvāṇa in the sequence of [his] incarnations, he will be desired as a relative [with the thought]: "You are my relative." Who ...

translation.line: ... create an island [i.e. a refuge]
for yourself! ...
fire burns it and it is lost ...
celui qui prend refuge en la conduite morale
the beating of a cymbal [i.e. name of a sacrifice] and brahmanical sacrifice
... a man, friendly to goodness ...
with something having the name Truth ...
the increase (?) of pride is not good ...

line.tr: Suche schnell Zuflucht für dich ... [wtl. Stütze dich schnell auf eine Stütze für dich]
Look for a refuge for yourself quickly ... [lit. Support yourself quickly with a support for you]

(Du bist) in die Nähe (des Todesgottes gekommen), Brahmane; es gibt [wtl. ist] weder eine Zwischenexistenz [zwischen Tod und Wiedergeburt] für dich, noch gibt es [wtl. wird gefunden] unterwegs Wegzehrung für dich.
(You have come) close to (the god of death), Brahmin; there is no intermediate state of existence [between death and rebirth] for you, and on the way, no provisions are [to be] found for you, either.
Mache du eine Insel [d.h. eine Zuflucht] für dich selbst!
Make you an island [i.e. a refuge] for yourself!
Nimm Zuflucht zur Energie, liebe die Weisen!
Take refuge with energy, love the wise ones!
Der König nimmt [es fort] (oder die Diebe).
The king takes [it away], (or the thieves [do]).
Wer zur sittlichen Haltung Zuflucht nimmt ...
Who[ever] takes refuge with moral demeanour ...

translation.line: /// as a worn-out horse, unfed ...
... it [i.e. the stick] keeps away a cow that has been driven mad

line.tr: Derentwegen der Reichtum erworben [wtl. gesammelt] worden ist, (die) ... haben mich aus meinem eigenen Hau(se) verstoßen [wtl. herausgezogen].
Those for whose sake the wealth had been gathered, (they) ... have banned [lit. drawn] me from my own house.
Um derentwillen der Reichtum erworben [wtl. gesammelt] worden ist, (die) ... haben mich (aus) meinem eigenen Hau(se) verstoßen [wtl. herausgezogen].
Those for whose sake the wealth had been gathered, (they) ... have banned [lit. drawn] me from my own house.
Dieser Stock [ist] für mich besser als [wtl. nicht aber] die (ungeratenen) Söhne. Er hält eine wildgewordene Kuh fern und einen (bösartigen(?)) Hund.
This stick [is] better for me than [lit. for me, but not] (undutiful) sons. It keeps away a cow gone wild and a (vicious(?)) dog.
Bettelmönch ist man nicht insofern, als man andere anbettelt.
One is not a begging monk (mendicant) insofar as one begs of others.

translation.line: Prête attention à cela!
... should I have committed offences connected to the fifteen (?) ślokas, to the seven saptatikaras, connected to the hidden [objects], with the truths, with the vipravāsas; ... intentionally ...
... should I have uttered a lie, harsh speech, [or] senseless talk; should I have committed offences through inertia, want of trust, [or] deception, ...
... should I have uttered ..., duṣthūla words; to [my] teachers, upādhyāyas [and] ācāryas, to my excellent father and mother, to those being good and faithful ...
... should I intentionally have uttered reproach, ... seen [or] heard, to others; these offences of the tongue ...
... I remove (my sin) and confess. If there is confession for me, I will thereafter attain ...

line.tr: … should I have committed offences connected to the fifteen (?) ślokas, to the seven saptatikaras, connected to the hidden [objects], with the truths, with the vipravāsas; … intentionally … (cf 252a)
… should I have uttered a lie, harsh speech, [or] senseless talk; should I have committed offences through inertia, want of trust, [or] deception, … (cf 252a)
… should I have uttered …, duṣthūla words; to [my] teachers, upādhyāyas [and] ācāryas, to my excellent father and mother, to those being good and faithful …
… should I intentionally have uttered reproach, … seen [or] heard, to others; these offences of the tongue …
… I remove (my sin) and confess. If there is confession for me, I will thereafter attain … (cf 412)
... ich beseitige (mein Vergehen) [und] lege Beichte ab.
... I remove (my offence) [and] make confession.

wsāṣy-ople〈ṃ〉 tsākkiñ: Sieg and Siegling read oplen sākkiñ^ä\ (), but compare this form in their grammar to b1 tsākkiñ (). Here tsākkiñ is read, but it should be noted that the anusvāra that this reading requires has to be added against the manuscript. (ople(ṃ) sākkiñ in is a typographical error.) As for the meaning, the context in my view suggests that it should be a part of a lotus, for instance "petals". I.e. the hair of the Buddha is as beautiful as lotus flowers hanging down on both sides.
kusraṃ: as pointed out by , this form can only be a loc.sg., not a nom.du. (pace –158). For the meaning, he suggests 'toison', i.e. 'mop' instead of Carling's 'braid'.

(aśnäṣ ¦ swāñcenāñ): aśnäṣ 'from the eyes' as the fourth term is suggested by e.g. VAV10.1–20, which describe the eyes, the lips and the teeth of the Buddha (cf. ; the next strophes there concern body hair rather than hair of the head). swāñcenāñ 'rays' is suggested by the colours mentioned before. With these restorations, the metre fits.

translation.line: ... having as innate disposition the mind's
coarseness, through the capacity of Vitarka the five Vijñānas will become gross. The five [Skandhas], Rūpa etc., will be conceived as gross spheres. For the mind's coarse-
ness Vitarka is the reason.

line.tr: Wie das Denken die [materielle] Erscheinung auf acht Arten erkennt [und] unterscheidet, so erkennt [und] unterscheidet es auch in den acht [geistigen] Kategorien jeden einzelnen Daseinsfaktor auf acht Arten kraft der prajña.

Just as the thought recognizes [and] distinguishes the [material] appearance in eight ways, just so it also recognizes [and] distinguishes within the eight [mental] categories each individual factor of existence in eight ways, thanks to the prajña.
Die fünf [Skandhas], Rūpa usw., werden als grobe Sphäre aufgefasst/verstanden.
The five [Skandhas], Rūpa etc., are conceived/understood as gross spheres.

Das Merkmal der Tätigkeit in den fünf Denkbereichen, [das] überall im Bereich der fünf Sinnesobjekte grob [ist], wird bei der Verbindung mit dem eigenen [speziellen] Merkmal saṃkalpa [Willensbestimmung] genannt.

The feature of activity in the five areas of thought, [which] is rough everywhere in the area of the five objects of sense, in combination with [one's] own [special] feature, it is called saṃkalpa [determination of the will].
Die saṃjñā [Erkenntnis] wird als [Denk]bereich verstanden, in eben dem Bereich denkt er den Denkprozess [durch].
The saṃjñā [perception, insight] is understood as an area [of thought], in just this area the thinks [through] the thinking process.

translation.line: ... as long as the mind uses the good laws as support ...
... the dharmas of the mind ...
... If negligence is manifest in the mind, by its power
the mind carries out two actions: virtues that have been created it cannot make manifest [and] of virtues that have not been created it cannot create the attainment.

line.tr: An der Feinheit des Geistes ist vicāra die Ursache, insofern als der Geist sich die feinen Eigenschaften zur Stütze macht. Das einzelne Atom, die über die fünf materiellen Sinnesorgane hinausreichenden Sinnesobjekte, die avijñapti und welches die feinen geistigen Eigenschaften sind, sie alle insgesamt macht sich die Geisteserkenntnis vermöge des vicāra zur Stütze.

Of the subtlety of the mind vicāra is the cause, insofar as the mind makes the fine qualities its support. The individual atom, the sensual objects that outreach the five material sensual organs, the avijñapti and what[ever] the fine mental qualities are, all these as a whole the mental perception makes its support by means of the vicāra.

If negligence is manifest in the mind, by its power the mind carries out two actions: virtues that have been created it cannot make manifest [and] of virtues that have not been created it cannot create the attainment. (cf 722)

[Wenn] Nachlässigkeit im Geiste vorhanden ist, [so] übt der Geist kraft d[ies]er zwei Tätigkeiten aus: [bereits] hervorgerufene Tugenden kann er nicht zum Vorschein bringen, die prāpti [Erreichung] [noch] nicht hervorgerufener Tugenden kann er nicht hervorrufen.

[If] there is negligence in the mind, [then] the mind performs, because of th[is], two actions: virtues [already] generated it cannot make manifest, the prāpti [attainment] of virtues not [yet] generated it cannot generate.
Der Geist wird des Saṃsāras überdrüssig.
The spirit grows weary of the saṃsāra.
Die[se] mit dem Geist verbundene geistige Eigenschaft wird nirvid [Überdruss] genannt.
Th[is] spiritual feature, connected with the spirit, is called nirvid [weariness].

translation.line: ‘[the mind] is disposed to gather virtues by the power of prasrabdhi [serenity] for the good morals. As kalyāṇa gold
is disposed to be worked if it is soft, so prasrabdhi [serenity] is to be understood.’

line.tr: ... und auf Grund der Verbindung mit welchem [scil. dem Geist] der Überdruss "geistige Konzentration" genannt wird.
... and because of the connection to which [i.e. the spirit], weariness is called "spiritual concentration".
Dies wird prāmodya genannt: Was dem, der den achtfachen Weg verwirklicht, daraus [wtl. deswegen] zu der Zeit [als] freudige Erregung [und] Sehnsucht entsteht, das wird prāmodya "Freude" genannt.
This is called prāmodya: [that] which develops in one who accomplishes the eightfold way therefore at that time [as] joyful excitement [and] longing, this is called prāmodya, "joy".
Die für den Geist zum Sammeln der Tugenden die Grundlage bildende(?) Ursache an [seinem] Geschmeidigsein, die wird prasrabdhi "[innere] Ruhe" [wtl. das Entlassen [jeglicher Störung]] genannt.
The reason for his being lissom, forming(?) the basis for the mind in the gathering of virtues, this is called prasrabdhi “[inner] calm” [lit. the release [of any disturbance]].
As kalyāṇa gold is disposed to be worked if it is soft, so prasrabdhi [serenity] is to be understood.
avihiṃsā "Nichtverletzung". Das wird Nicht-verletzen genannt, vermöge dessen man andere nicht verletzt.
avihiṃsā "Non-injury". That is called non-injury, due to which one does not injure others.

Transcription and translation are based on .
Striking is s for ts in a5 oktasi and b1 kāse.
In this text, the Tocharian A translations seem to follow after each complete Sanskrit strophe (instead of each half pāda, as is often the case).

The reading of the leaf number is very uncertain. The first akṣara (there was probably no other one on top of this one) seems to be ‹60›, the second may be ‹7›, ‹8›, or ‹9›. If the reading of at least the ‹60› is correct, the manuscript will have contained another text preceding the Varṇārhavarṇastotra: with approximately 7 strophes per leaf, the beginning of the latter text may have to be placed about 35 leaves before this one.

śkaṃ tom kleśāñ tñi: parts of the translation of 7.11c-d na ceme granthayo 'nyatra cchidyante tvanmatād ṛte 'Diese Fesseln werden aber nirgends als in deiner Lehre zerschnitten.' (). The syntax of the Tocharian A translation is different. plausibly suggests to restore ā /// to ā(kṣiñluneyäṣ pkänt), which would give us something like '(Apart from) your teaching, these kleśas are (not cut off)'.
cf. 7.12d tvayi sāphalyam āgataḥ.

oko lyockäṣt: renders 7.12d tvayi sāphalyam āgataḥ (see line a3; pace ) 'hat in dir ihre Erfüllung gefunden' (). However, literally the Tocharian A seems to mean 'you have turned [it] into fruit' (taking a little more freedom, translates 'liet de vrucht ontstaan', i.e. '[you] let the fruit arise'). täm(y)o 'therefore' seems to begin a next clause that has no precise Sanskrit parallel.

oktasi ytār nervāṃ 'the eightfold path, the nirvāṇa' may perhaps somehow, but certainly not literally, correspond to 7.13a pratipad brāhmī 'den Brahma zugehörigen Weg' (). The literal correspondence of pratipad brāhmī is found in line b4.

cf. 7.14a-b na tvayā saṃskṛtaḥ kaś cid bhavati brāhmaṇo 'śuciḥ 'Nicht wird irgendein durch dich (rituell) gereinigter Brahmane (wieder rituell) unrein' (). The variant reading (sa)dṛśa{ḥ} attested here is certain.
[mā]: can be read pace .

mā śkaṃ kāse klo: translates 7.14c na copanīto 'und nicht fällt ein (von dir) eingeführter' (). kāse klo (for kātse klo) literally means 'led close' and is without doubt a calque (Skt. upa = TA kātse, Skt. nī- = TA kälā-.
(śpā)lmeṃ tre: last part of the translation 7.15d brāhmaṇapravarās trayaḥ 'die drei brahmanischen Ahnherren' ().
na (h)i: beginning of Skt. 7.16a.

mā brāmaṇi ytār kl(awanträ): renders 7.16b na brāhmī pratipat kva cit 'nirgendwo den brahmanischen Weg' (). restores to kl(yant naṣ) 'bevindt zich [niet]', i.e. 'is [not] there', but the relevant akṣara can only be kla or klā. With the restoration kl(awanträ), a literal translation of the Tocharian A text becomes: 'they do [not] call the Brahmanic path'.
The end of 7.17.a, and 7.17b.

(e)he kāsu kälko yruñci: renders the beginning of 7.17c (sugatāve)ṇikaivaiṣā 'gerade nur [dem Wohlgegangenen] eigentümlich ist' (. There is no place for the equivalent of TA ehe 'oh' in the restored Skt. text. On yruñci, the equivalent of Skt. āveṇika 'independent; characteristic', see .

line.tr: ... den bettelnden Wesen (gab er) mit eigener Hand {G}aben. Speisen wurden gekocht, [und] er gab den Vögeln [wtl. das hüpfende Tier] [und] Wassertieren Gaben.
... to the begging beings (he gave) gifts with [his] own hand. Food was cooked, [and] he gave gifts to the birds [lit. the hopping animal] [and] to the water animals.
Wenn er in den Palast [wtl. das königliche Haus] ging, sah er [seinen] Vater, den König, bald nach dem Gesetz, bald nicht nach dem Gesetz Befehl gebend.
When[ever] he went into the palace [lit. the royal house], he saw [his] father, the king, giving orders, sometimes according to the law, sometimes not according to the law.
Er bat um Erlaubnis, aus dem Hause zu gehen [d.h. Mönch zu werden], [aber] er erhielt nicht die Erlaubnis, aus dem Hause zu gehen.
He asked for permission to go out of the house, [but] he did not get permission to go out of the house.

Da er den starken Entschluss, aus dem Hause zu gehen, gefasst hatte, aß er am ersten Tage [und] auch am zweiten Tage keine Speise. [Auch] am dritten Tage [und] am vierten Tage (aß er) nicht, [und] am fünften Tage aß er keine Speise. Vielmehr gab er sich selbst hin zu verhungern.

Since he had made the strong decision to go out of the house, on the first [and] on the second day he ate no food. On the third day [and] on the fourth day, [also,] (he) did not (eat), [and] on the fifth day, he ate no food [either]. Rather, he gave himself up to starvation.
Als darauf [sein] Vater Mahendradeva ... den Prinzen als einen, der sechs Tage ohne Speise geblieben war, erkannt hatte, gab er ihm [von sich aus] die Erlaubnis, aus dem Hause zu gehen.
When thereupon [his] father Mahendradeva ... had recognized the prince as one who had remained without food for six days, he [, of his own accord,] gave him permission to go out of the house.

line.tr: So sprach der Haushalter zu seiner Frau: "Edle! Sei nicht so traurig wegen deines lieben Sohnes Priyadatta! Nicht treffen [wtl. sind] alle Dinge dem Traum entsprechend ein!"
Thus the householder spoke to his wife: "Noble one! Do not be so sad because of your dear son Priyadatta! Not all things are according to a dream!"
Gewiss schützen ihn die Götter, [und] er wird nicht in Not kommen.
Certainly, the gods protect him [and] he will not get into troubles.
Als die Eltern Priyadattas das gehört hatten, verloren sie über d[ies]em Schmerz die Besinnung. Ohnmächtig geworden, ... erlangten sie die Besinnung durchaus (nicht so bald) wieder.
When the parents of Priydatta had heard this, through [this] pain they lost consciousness. Having fainted, they did (not so soon) [re]gain [their] consciousness.

… (so) arguing they entered the Kosala forest. Then they could by no means go any further and thought, «Will we enter the town Śrāvasti? Certainly … danger will fall on us!». Therefore they did not cross the Kosala forest any further.
Sicherlich wird uns (dieser Weg(?)) ... Gefahr bringen.
Certainly, (this path(?)) will bring us ... danger.
Als der Zauberkreis den nimittakundigen Brahmanen vor der Stadt Śrāvastī hervortrat(?), führten sie sogleich ... den Brahmanenknaben an den Zauberkreis heran.
When the magic circle appeared(?) to the Brahmins, well versed in the nimitta, immediately they led ... the Brahmin youth towards the magic circle.

comments.comment: Transcription and translation are based on .

Transcription and references have been transferred from the "Text and Reference Database of the Tocharian A Language" (Gerd Carling Lund University) (funded by the Bank of Sweden Tercentenary Foundation and SCAS).
(spa)rcwatr-äṃ: the following character may be the punctuation mark ":". If so, four more akṣaras may be lost in the lacuna; that is, if the restoration (trä)ṅkäṣ is correct, still another three.
(ā)kṣ(i)ñam-ci: the restoration is certain. More frequent are the variants ākṣiññam (excluded here, pace ) and ākṣñam (see also ).

taruṇadivāk(araṃ): tune name certainly corresponding to TB taruṇadivākarne, which has the metre 19 / 19 / 10 / 19 (= 7 ¦ 7 ¦ 5 / 7 ¦ 7 ¦ 5 / 5 ¦ 5 / 7 ¦ 7 ¦ 5). However, this metre is so far not attested in Tocharian A and this fragmentary passage does not allow a detailed metrical analysis.
tseṃ-o(ppalṣi): cf. a1 tseṃ-oppa(lṣiñi).

These lines contain hapax legomena of unknown meaning: /// ṣāmikāñ and trāṅk. Also tkani is unclear, since the plural of tkaṃ 'earth' is regularly tkañi, while also a derived adjective would be expected to be tkañi.

paṇḍurāṅkaṃ: the long ā is left-bound, apparently as an ornamental feature at the end of the chapter. This tune name with unknown metre is also attested in a6; in Tocharian B, the corresponding tune paṇḍurāṅkäññene has the metre 4 x 4 ¦ 5.

An ornamental vertical line at the end of the lines marks the end of a chapter. On the evidence of comparable leaves, there was probably another such line following after the blank space to the right of it, and another portion of text to the right of that.
lyockwā tā: the long ā's are left-bound (see above).

translation.line: ... should she do ... [to] the female disciple ...
... should she do ... – pātayantika [offence].
... the nun six ...
... should she do ... [to] the female disciple ...
... year ... female teacher ...
... she will remove her ...
... – pātayantika [offence].

comments.comment: places this fragment in the section of the pātayantikas about the ordination ritual (; Pāt.106-125 of the Sarvāstivādins). In particular, he adduces ṣäk 'six' and p_ukäl 'year'. While ṣäk 'six' might lead to a refinement of the classification, p_ukäl 'year' occurs too often to be of any help. A further indication of appurtenance to the ordination section is upādhyāyi 'female teacher', which appears to be the Tocharian A equivalent of Skt. upādhyāyā 'female teacher'.

The lower margin of the recto (upper of the verso) is preserved. In one frame with - and -. suggests that and may belong to the same leaf as is this fragment; he further considers the possibility that also and belong to the same leaf. Since this fragment belongs to the vinaya, it is assumed that it belongs to manuscript A 415-416, not to A 406-408.
ākläṣlyāṃ: this is probably the attestation noted in as "Frgm.".

ākläṣlyāṃ yāmitär: ākläṣlyāṃ is an obl.sg.; probably, the phrase pattern goes kusne aśi ... ākläṣlyāṃ yāmitär, meaning 'Which nun does (ordination) to a female disciple who ...', i.e. 'Which nun ordinates a female disciple who ...' (cf. also a4).
ṣäk mä(rkampaläntu): cf. 'welche nicht zwei Jahre lang die sechs dharmas studiert hat', which occurs e.g. Sarv.Pāt.111, 112, 121, 122 (.

wikāṣṣ-ä(ṃ): pace , who claims that ṃ is excluded, the paper on top of the _ṣ_ṣ_a is abraded and an anusvāra may be lost. However, it cannot be ruled out that the word division is rather wikāṣ ṣä ///. As remarks, this will be the attestation wikāṣṣä .. noted in as "Frgm.".

translation.line: Girl, I ask you, how the matter is, so say it! Don’t [tell] lie[s] to me!’

line.tr: Girl, I ask you, how the matter is, so say it! Don't [tell]124 lie[s] to me! (cf 377)
Mädchen, ich frage dich: Wie die Sache ist, so sage! Nicht [sage] mir eine Lüge!
Girl, I ask you: As the matter is, so tell [it]! [Do] not [tell] me a lie!
(Warum(?)) ... hast du mir (dreierlei) Wasser gebracht? Verkünde mir den Grund [dafür]!
(Why(?)) ... did you bring me (three kinds) of water? Tell me the reason [for this]!
